results.title: Seema Verma previews Medicare agenda
results.body:
The omnibus passed, but the push for ACA stabilization died again in Congress, and a late-night attempt to pass right-to-try failed in the Senate.

But first: a look at the news coming out of the Hubert H. Humphrey building.

SEEMA VERMA PREVIEWS MEDICARE AGENDA -- The CMS administrator on Thursday offered a high-level preview of upcoming Medicare payment regulations, with an eye toward ensuring "sustainability of the program," Verma told POLITICO's Rachana Pradhan and other reporters.

-- CMS wants to "double down" on price transparency, with a goal of helping enrollees understand their costs. "You're going to see us just get started on that with the payment rules but there's a lot more coming around that," Verma said. "When we look at the Medicare system, we all know that if you go to one place it might be cheaper than another place."

-- The agency intends to reduce burden on providers, partly by shrinking their reporting measures and changing the conditions they must meet to participate in the Medicare program. Verma also suggested that the agency is pursuing changes related to Stark laws, which govern physician self-referral for Medicare and Medicaid patients. "We've heard that that's a big barrier for providers when they're trying to do value-based payment arrangements," she said.

-- Verma also plans to build on interoperability of electronic health records through the MyHealthEData initiative, which aims to help patients have better access to their own health records, that she announced last month. "You will see the actual actions that we are taking around interoperability this year," she said.

-- When to watch: Annual rules affecting Medicare payment rates for hospital inpatient services, nursing homes and rehab facilities typically are proposed in April, and ones affecting physicians and outpatient settings are released by June or July.

MORE GUIDANCE FROM VERMA -- The CMS chief weighed in on multiple issues, including:

-- She's weighing more exemptions to the ACA individual mandate. "That is something that we're giving a lot of consideration to," Verma told reporters, declining to specify when the Trump administration could decide on changes to the individual mandate. More for Pros.

-- There could be Medicaid work requirements in non-ACA expansion states. Some non-expansion states have sought work requirements for low-income parents and caretakers, who tend to be poorer than the newly eligible adults who obtained coverage under the health law.

Meanwhile, POLITICO scooped details on high-profile changes in HHS' senior ranks:

COMING: NEW ADVISER TO AZAR ON DRUG PRICING -- CVS Caremark Vice President Daniel Best has been hired to head up the department's effort to lower drug prices, a source with knowledge of the hire told POLITICO's Adam Cancryn. Best is also in HHS' publicly available staff directory as a senior adviser to Azar.

While CVS confirmed the hire, an HHS spokesperson told POLITICO that Best is not currently an HHS employee. "While we do not generally comment on personnel matters, there are several individuals being considered for senior roles in the department," the spokesperson wrote.

-- Why he's coming on board: Best, who has led industry relations for CVS' Medicare Part D business, will take charge of HHS' day-to-day work on initiatives aimed at cutting pharmaceutical costs -- a goal that Azar has made a top priority amid President Donald Trump's vows to rein in the drug industry.

-- More hires to come: Best is one of four senior staffers that Azar is expected to name in the coming weeks, each of whom will be serve as a point person for one of the department's major priorities, according to multiple sources familiar with the matter. More for Pros.

LEAVING: HHS OFFICIAL WHO APPROVED TOM PRICE's FLIGHTS RESIGNS -- John Bardis, the assistant secretary of administration, is resigning effective April 6, HHS confirmed to POLITICO on Thursday.

"I am deeply grateful to President Trump, Secretary Azar, Secretary Price, and Deputy Secretary Hargan for the opportunity to work on the American people's behalf at HHS," Bardis said in a statement, calling his year-plus in government "the privilege of a lifetime." An entrepreneur who founded MedAssets, Bardis signaled that he's returning to the private sector. More for Pros.

-- Eric Hargan sings his praises. "John Bardis is a truly transformative leader, and HHS has benefited greatly from his dedicated work over the past year," the deputy secretary said in a statement.

-- One big question: What will the OIG say about Bardis? His office has been the focus of a probe about whether Price's use of charter-jet flights for routine domestic travel -- which cost more than $400,000 -- complied with federal regulations. As ASA, Bardis signed off on those flights with the office of general counsel.

The HHS inspector general, which is conducting an internal probe of Price's travel, told POLITICO that its final report is expected this spring.

-- The other big question: Who takes over Bardis' portfolio? It's unclear whether it will be Jon Cordova, Bardis' deputy, who returned to HHS this month after being placed on leave for spreading conspiracy theories.

-- Flashback: Bardis warns HHS staffers not to leak. He was the narrator of a video that all employees were required to watch last fall. The video suggested that the leaking of sensitive information could lead to terrorist attacks.

THANK GOODNESS IT'S FRIDAY PULSE -- Where, speaking of Tom Price, we hope you got this $1,000 clue on Jeopardy correct last night.

(PULSE missed the episode; he was joining his colleagues to wish POLITICO's Brett Norman a happy birthday. Luckily there wasn't any breaking science news that Brett had to run out and cover last night.)

** A message from PhRMA: Analysis finds commercially insured patients at 340B hospitals are prescribed more medicines and/or more expensive medicines. This may result in higher cost sharing and higher premiums if the hospital does not pass the 340B discounts through to the patient or the payer. Let's fix the 340B program. http://politi.co/2IqKpF3 **

PULSE CHECK: WHAT IT'S LIKE TO WORK ON HEALTH CARE INSIDE THE TRUMP WHITE HOUSE -- That's what Paul Winfree, who spent a year as a top policy adviser to President Donald Trump, explained on this week's episode of POLITICO's "Pulse Check" podcast.

Among the takeaways: Paul thinks there was too much deferring to HHS on Obamacare last year, even as the White House got caught in the middle of "shuttle diplomacy" with Congress.

He also expressed dismay over Congressional leaders' push for rapid, tightly controlled bills, saying that legislation will fail "when the process is all being driven at the top, and it's not open." Instead, Paul stressed the need for rank-and-file lawmakers to have transparency into legislation, rather than being surprised at the last minute. "What needs to happen is members need to talk to other members about what their actual concerns are," he mused. Listen here.

KAISER TRACKING POLL: NEARLY THREE-QUARTERS OF AMERICANS THINK DRUG FIRMS HAVE TOO MUCH SWAY IN DC -- That's one of the findings in the latest Kaiser Family Foundation tracking poll, with 72 percent of respondents saying that drug firms have too much influence in Washington. (For contrast, 52 percent of respondents said the same about the NRA.) More.

Senate fails to add Obamacare stabilization to omnibus. Sen. Patty Murray on Thursday afternoon halted a last-ditch bid to add Republicans' Obamacare stabilization package to the omnibus spending bill.

Murray objected to Sen. Susan Collins' attempt to add the bill as an amendment, calling it a "last-minute partisan proposal" and urging lawmakers to instead resume work toward a bipartisan agreement on shoring up the health law. She then offered a competing stabilization amendment. That was quickly shot down by Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

-- What it means: The back-and-forth ensured that Congress won't fund any efforts to stabilize Obamacare as part of its massive spending bill, H.R. 1625 (115), POLITICO's Adam Cancryn writes. More for Pros.

Ron Johnson fails to pass House version of right-to-try by unanimous consent. After the omnibus passed in the middle of the night, the Wisconsin Republican pitched a vote on the bill -- which was quickly halted after an objection from Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer.

"I am disappointed the Senate would not pass the House version of right to try, but now the path is clear," Johnson said in a statement. "I call on my colleagues in the House to take up and pass S. 204 (115), which passed the Senate unanimously last year," he added, touting his own version of the bill.

Calls for MACRA reform fall on deaf ears on Capitol Hill. A recommendation two years in the making to eliminate a new quality payment scheme for doctors landed with a giant thud on the steps of the U.S. Capitol, POLITICO's David Pittman reports.

Members of Congress who spent close to a decade working to repeal Medicare's sustainable growth rate formula barely acknowledged the call from the Medicare Payment Advisory Committee to nix the new Merit-based Incentive Payment System, which replaced it. Instead, policymakers have focused on tweaking the program.

-- What lawmakers are saying: "We just provided some significant flexibility," said Rep. Frank Pallone (D-N.J.), referring to last month's changes to the 2015 MACRA law . Like other members of Congress who clearly can't contemplate another major payment reform effort, Pallone appeared puzzled by MedPAC's position, David writes. More for Pros.

ICYMI: Health department leaders go on opioid road show. The president's Monday speech to lay out his opioid plan kicked off an ambitious travel schedule for HHS political leaders, who have hit the road this week to stump on key opioid issues.

Among the stops:

-- Deputy Secretary Eric Hargan went to Illinois and Wisconsin to talk about local opioids response. More.

-- SAMHSA's Elinore F. McCance-Katz visited West Virginia to announce a $330,000 grant. More.

-- NIH Director Francis Collins was in Ohio to celebrate innovative projects and products to treat opioid misuse. More.

-- Surgeon General Jerome Adams was in Michigan to discuss the epidemic with students. More.

Maine governor resists ballot measure expanding Medicaid. Back in November, Maine voters ordered Gov. Paul LePage to expand the state's Medicaid program through a first-of-its-kind ballot initiative. But months later, the brash tea party Republican still hasn't done it, underscoring the potential pitfalls of the ballot strategy health care advocates are pushing in red states this year, POLITICO's Rachana Pradhan writes.

-- LePage had vetoed Medicaid expansion bills on five previous occasions. And this time, he's resisted implementing the optional Obamacare program until lawmakers meet his demands on how to fund it. Expansion supporters in Maine say LePage has a legal obligation to expand the program -- and is inviting a lawsuit if he blows through a key deadline less than two weeks away. More for Pros.

By Mohana Ravindranath

Omitting crucial data on death certificates about which drugs led to overdoses could mean that medical examiners and researchers are undercounting opioid-related deaths, NPR reports. More.

An uptick in mumps could be tied to weakening response to the vaccine, The New York Times reports. More.

Texas is asking the White House to restore funds for its Medicaid-funded family planning program, a move one researcher says could avert future health care expenses, Kaiser Health News. More.

A recent study says that genome sequencing might not prompt patients, or their doctors, to seek countless expensive follow-up tests even if they're told they have a predisposition to certain conditions, Stat reports. More.

Corrections departments collaborating with health care agencies could reduce communicable diseases and reduce the likelihood of repeat offices, Stateline reports. More.

** A message from PhRMA: Created a quarter of a century ago, the 340B program is greatly in need of a number of fixes to ensure it is targeted toward true safety-net entities and vulnerable or uninsured patients as intended when the program was developed. Independent economists, GAO and OIG have all raised concerns with the program and Congress has now echoed those concerns. Too many hospitals are profiting off a program meant to support needy patients. Learn why now is the time to fix the 340B program and how members of Congress are leading the charge through new legislation. http://politi.co/2IqKpF3 **

results.title: DCCC adds 9 to 'Red to Blue,' spurned candidates blast committee
results.body:
With Kevin Robillard, Zach Montellaro, Daniel Strauss and Elena Schneider

The following newsletter is an abridged version of Campaign Pro's Morning Score. For an earlier morning read on exponentially more races -- and for a more comprehensive aggregation of the day's most important campaign news -- sign up for Campaign Pro today. (http://www.politicopro.com/proinfo)

GETTING THE NOD -- "DCCC adds 9 candidates to 'Red to Blue' list," by POLITICO's Elena Schneider: "The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee announced its fourth round of 'Red to Blue' candidates today, adding nine House challengers to its program that indicates the committee's top-tier prospects in Republican-held seats. The committee is wading into the Texas runoffs by backing Colin Allred and Gina Ortiz Jones, two candidates that must face Democratic opponents in May. But the DCCC didn't give that designation to Lizzie Pannill Fletcher in Texas's 7th District, where the committee dropped opposition research against her opponent, Laura Moser, before this month's primary." Full story.

-- BUT WAIT -- "Spurned candidates blast DCCC after primary opponents earn 'Red to Blue' designation," Schneider reports: Candidates left off the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee's 'Red to Blue' list protested the intervention in their primaries in statements released today. Lillian Salerno, a Democrat challenging DCCC-backed Colin Allred in a May runoff in Texas, said in a statement, 'Folks here are sick and tired of a bunch of Washington insiders trying to make their decisions for them.' ...

"In Wisconsin, Cathy Myers attacked the DCCC for 'picking sides' after the committee announced they would support her opponent Randy Bryce, whom 'local voters have emphatically rejected three times,' her statement said. Myers and Bryce are both running to take on House Speaker Paul Ryan." Full story.

-- CPC PAC announces House endorsements: The Congressional Progressive Caucus PAC rolled out its endorsements in a slate of House races, including Brent Welder (KS-03), Debbie Mucarsel-Powell (FL-26), Sylvia Garcia (TX-29) and Scott Wallace (PA-01).

POWER PLAY -- Uihlein-funded PAC buys pro-Rosendale ad in Montana: Richard Uihlein, the GOP mega-donor who is shaping up to be one of the biggest players in the 2018 elections, was the subject of a POLITICO profile earlier this week. Uihlein's stable of Senate candidates has expanded in the days since: a super PAC heavily funded by Uihlein has now booked advertising time in favor of Republican Matt Rosendale in Montana, POLITICO's Kevin Robillard reports. The super PAC, called Restoration PAC, "has purchased over $230,000 worth of television time to air an ad boosting Rosendale and attacking Sen. Jon Tester (D-Mont.), according to Advertising Analytics. The 30-second ad features a male narrator praising Rosendale over b-roll of the Republican meeting with voters: 'Matt Rosendale is the real deal. Unlike Jon Tester, he believes you deserve to keep more of your hard-earned money. And unlike Tester, Matt believes it's wrong to hand over $1 million to the number one state sponsor or terror.'" Full story.

THE DOGHOUSE -- "Ethics panel reproves two Illinois Democrats for House rules violations," By POLITICO's John Bresnahan: "The House Ethics Committee found that two Illinois Democrats violated chamber rules and must personally repay thousands of dollars for their actions. Yet in the case of Rep. Bobby Rush, the Ethics Committee will allow him to be repaid by his campaign committee for any personal cost, so the end result is that Rush won't be out of pocket at all. Rush and Rep. Luis Guti√©rrez were formally reproved by the Ethics panel for the violations, findings that were announced on Thursday by Reps. Susan Brooks (R-Ind.) and Ted Deutch (D-Fla.), the chairwoman and ranking member of the committee. Both cases were initially investigated by the Office of Congressional Ethics, the independent ethics watchdog, which found 'substantial reason to believe' that Rush and Gutierrez had violated House rules." Full story.

Days until the 2018 election: 229

Upcoming election dates -- Indiana, Ohio, North Carolina and West Virginia primaries: May 8.

BETTER LATE ... -- "NRSC raises $5.1M in February," by Robillard: "The National Republican Senatorial Committee raised $5.1 million in February, its best fundraising total in months and matching the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee's haul, according to an FEC filing. The DSCC still has a significant cash on hand advantage, with $25.7 million in the bank to the NRSC's $15.3 million. The NRSC spent $5 million in February, with most of the money going toward a $3 million debt payment. The committee now has $4 million in debt remaining." Full story.

JERSEY DRAMA -- "Former Bergen GOP chairman rips McCann over ties to former Trump adviser," by POLITICO New Jersey's Matt Friedman: "The former chairman of Bergen County's Republican Party is slamming a congressional candidate for raising money with Sebastian Gorka, a one-time adviser to President Donald Trump who wore a medal associated with a Hungarian group that collaborated with Nazi Germany. 'It's absolutely despicable. It shows that I have to assume that John McCann approves of this man,' said Bob Yudin, who chaired the Bergen County GOP from 2008 to 2016 and backs McCann rival Steve Lonegan for the GOP nomination in the 5th Congressional District. ... Gorka, a former deputy assistant to Trump and a frequent commentator on Fox News, endorsed McCann this week and has scheduled a fundraiser with him in Bergen County on Wednesday." Full story.

UP ON THE AIRWAVES -- Debbie Mucarsel-Powell releases new TV ad in FL-26: Democrat Debbie Mucarsel-Powell is out with a TV and digital ad about her father's death by gun violence, airing during the coverage of the "March for Our Lives" this weekend. "October 18th, to most it's just another day, but to me, it isn't," Mucarsel-Powell said. "It's the day my father was shot and killed by a criminal with a gun," adding that she "won't rest until there's real change." Watch the ad here.

-- Senate Majority PAC goes up in North Dakota: Senate Majority PAC, which is controlled by allies of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, has reserved more than $400,000 worth of airtime in North Dakota starting tomorrow, according to Advertising Analytics. Americans for Prosperity, which is backed by the Koch Brothers' network of conservative donors, started airing ads attacking Heitkamp over tax reform earlier this week.

DEWINE DEFENSE -- "RNC co-chair defends DeWine, bashes pro-Taylor ad in Ohio" by Campaign Pro's Daniel Strauss: "Republican National Committee co-chairman Bob Paduchik released a statement today denouncing an attack ad on Ohio state Attorney General Mike DeWine aired by supporters of Lt. Gov. Mary Taylor, DeWine's opponent in the May 8 gubernatorial primary. 'I'm disappointed in Lt. Governor Mary Taylor's negative attack ad against Mike DeWine because it is both false and misleading,' Paduchik said in the statement." Full story.

PRIMARY CONCERNS -- "Republican Andy Taggart eyeing challenge to Cindy Hyde-Smith for Cochran's Senate seat," by the Clarion-Ledger's Geoff Pender: "Author and attorney Andy Taggart, a Republican patriarch in Mississippi, said Thursday he is 'very seriously considering running' for the U.S. Senate seat being vacated by Thad Cochran. ... Taggart's statement comes a day after Republican Gov. Phil Bryant announced he will appoint Agriculture Commissioner Cindy Hyde-Smith to Cochran's seat temporarily and support her election to the post in November. It also comes amid Bryant facing some Republican backlash over his choice. ... Taggart in recent days on social media had obliquely questioned Bryant's choice..." Full story.

ENDORSEMENT WATCH -- Sen. Kamala Harris is set to endorse Democrat Ben Jealous in the Maryland Democratic primary for governor, according to two sources familiar with the plans for the upcoming endorsement. A formal announcement is set for Friday. The news was first reported by Buzzfeed.

-- Winning for Women endorses in six races: Winning for Women, the new group backing female Republican candidates, unveiled six endorsements on Thursday. The group is backing State Sen. Leah Vukmir in Wisconsin's Senate race, plus Tiffany Shedd in Arizona's 1st District, Lea Marquez Peterson in Arizona's 2nd District and Debbie Lesko in the state's 8th District. They're also supporting Carla Nelson in Minnesota's 1st and Carol Miller in the race to replace Rep. Evan Jenkins in West Virginia's 3rd District.

STEYER WATCH -- "Billionaire Steyer targets $3.5M at Michigan," by The Detroit News' Melissa Nann Burke and Jonathan Oosting: "Billionaire activist Tom Steyer plans to spend at least $3.5 million in Michigan to engage and register young voters ahead of the 2018 election as part of a larger $30 million campaign to flip statewide and congressional seats for Democrats in 10 states. Steyer's NextGen America said this week it will target a minimum of 700,000 young Michigan voters through mail and digital outreach." Full story.

STAFFING UP -- Tallahassee Mayor Andrew Gillum's Florida gubernatorial campaign has added Phillip Jerez as political director and Lindsay Pollard as deputy finance director. Jerez recently worked for Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz in Florida and graduated with a degree in Psychology from Columbia University. Pollard is the co-founder of Diverse Strategy Group where she works as its finance consultant. It was called 'marketing aromatics,' or the use of smells to make consumers spend more money. In the decades since, the Eton-educated British businessman has styled himself as an expert on a wide variety of 'mind-bending' techniques -- from scents to psychological warfare to campaign politics." results.title: Plenty of cyber nuggets in the omnibus
results.body:
OMNICYBER -- The reaction to the omnibus spending bill deal, H.R. 1625 (115), that included $380 million for voting machine upgrades has been widely positive, even if some observe that the job isn't finished. National Association of Secretaries of State President Connie Lawson, also Indiana's secretary of state, said states will be "investing those dollars in system upgrades, voting protections, and voter education." Top House Homeland Security Democrat Bennie Thompson, who helped lead a House Democrat task force on election security, praised the inclusion but added that the money is "just a down payment towards securing our elections." Other Democrats involved in overseeing election security offered similar sentiments. A senior Democratic aide mentioned the $380 million as a "Democratic win" in the bill, although at a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing this week, lawmakers noted that Republican Chairman Richard Burr fought hard for the money, too.

MC hit some of the highlights of the bill Thursday morning, but there are other cyber provisions. The same senior Democratic aide heralded a $307 million increase beyond what President Donald Trump requested for the FBI's counterintelligence efforts to fight Russian cyberattacks. The legislation would also bar State Department and foreign aid funding from going to any country found to assist North Korean cyberattacks. It also prohibits Commerce, Justice, NASA or the National Science Foundation from purchasing any major information systems without first conducting reviews of the security of its suppliers.

Additionally, it orders a report on Pentagon plans for a multibillion-dollar cloud computing contract. And it includes the CLOUD Act, S. 2383, which establishes standards for governments to request data in other countries -- in a way that deeply worries privacy advocates.

HAPPY FRIDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! Rube Goldberg machines are the best, and this one is full of surprises. Send your thoughts, feedback and especially tips to tstarks@politico.com and be sure to follow @POLITICOPro and @MorningCybersec. Full team info below.

BOLTON TAGS IN FOR MCMASTER -- "John Bolton, President Donald Trump's pick to replace H.R. McMaster as his national security adviser, could bring a vastly different approach on Russia's election meddling to the White House," Cory reports. "In their public comments, McMaster and Bolton have presented a stark contrast in their views on Moscow's involvement in the hacks and online trolling that roiled the 2016 presidential election. While McMaster has taken a hard-line stance in blaming Moscow for orchestrating the digital disruption campaign, Bolton has made headlines by casting doubt on Russia's role." After initially suggesting the hacking of the Democratic National Committee was a "false flag" operation, though, he later appeared to endorse the notion that Russia was behind the 2016 digital meddling.

SENATORS MAKE PLAY ON ELECTION SECURITY -- Congress is the closest it's been since Election Day 2016 to actually moving legislation that would protect future contests from outside interference. A bipartisan group of Senate lawmakers on Thursday introduced a revised version of an election security bill, with new backing from the leaders of the influential Senate Intelligence Committee, that would establish an election security grant program to give states money to implement voluntary recommendations. The legislation, known as the Secure Elections Act, "helps the states to prepare our election infrastructure for the possibility of interference from not just Russia, but possibly another adversary like Iran or North Korea or a hacktivist group," Sen. James Lankford, one of four ideologically diverse Republicans backing the bill, said in a statement.

The overhauled bill -- which also has four Democratic co-sponsors -- shifts control of grant funding from the Homeland Security Department to the Election Assistance Commission, an agency House Republicans have tried to eliminate in the past. It also scraps a proposed voluntary "Hack the Election" program that would have given rewards to ethical hackers who unearthed digital flaws in election systems.

The measure's rollout was the latest in a series of steps the upper chamber has taken on election security this week, starting with the Intelligence Committee releasing its own election security ideas as part of the panel's probe into Russia's 2016 election meddling and possible collusion between Moscow and the Trump campaign. The panel held a hearing to discuss its suggestions where it became clear that a consensus was forming around the revised bill dropped Thursday.

And despite the inclusion of $380 million for election security grants in the omnibus spending deal, the bill's backers argued more action is required. "It's not enough," Sen. Amy Klobuchar said in a statement. "There are 227 days until the next federal election and primaries have already begun. Congress should pass the bipartisan Secure Elections Act immediately."

** A message from OWI: KNOW Identity Conference 2018 offers a unique & immersive event that convenes the world's smartest minds to shape the future of identity and security. March 26-28, 2018 | Washington, DC. Register Today!! Government discounts available. **

LEST WE FORGET THE PEOPLE'S HOUSE -- Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee also stumped for a federal election security grant program in a report released Thursday summarizing findings from the House's investigation into Russia's election-year meddling. The report was made public after the Intelligence Committee voted along party lines to end the panel's probe and issue their conclusions. Democrats did not participate in the final report, arguing the panel had failed to conduct a serious investigation.

Regardless, the finished product included some bipartisan ideas, including the recommendation that Congress "encourage" states to adopt cybersecurity standards developed by the technical standards agency NIST, which are already followed by the Election Assistance Commission. Lawmakers should also "consider a one-time grant to state and local election agencies to conduct a [cyber] risk assessment" of their systems, the report suggested.

Additionally, the House report called for additional NIST funding for the agency to boost outreach to state and local officials, along with "strengthening" the 2002 Help America Vote Act, which provided over $3 billion in grants to help states purchase new voting equipment. Meanwhile, the findings faulted the FBI for not notifying election hacking victims swiftly and the government's intelligence agencies for not sharing enough technical data on online disruptors with state election officials.

YEAH, ABOUT THAT -- In the same report, Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee argued that they saw no evidence of collusion between Trump campaign officials and the Russian government. But a liberal watchdog group said they didn't look very hard. "There were at least 70 known contacts between Trump's team and Russia-linked operatives during the campaign and transition, including 22 meetings," the Moscow Project said in a blog post prior to the release of the GOP findings. "In 81 percent of these cases, the House Intel committee obtained either no or partial information from the relevant Trump representative."

The Intelligence panel "failed to interview the Trump representative involved" in 60 percent of known Trump-Russia contacts, according to the Moscow Project. And in more than a fifth of cases, the group said, Democrats asked their GOP counterparts to schedule follow-up interviews with witnesses who either lied, "invoked a nonexistent privilege to avoid answering questions" or were subsequently described in media reports that raised further questions. The panel "clearly hasn't done their job," the group said, "so don't fall for any 'conclusions' they might be pushing today." Rep. Adam Schiff, the Intelligence Committee's top Democrat, tweeted, "The lack of a serious investigation by the GOP is an invitation to the Russians to do it again."

THIS WILL NOT STAND -- The Trump administration on Thursday slammed China for hacking American companies to steal their intellectual property as Trump authorized $60 billion in annual tariffs punishing Beijing. "Experts have acknowledged that China's cyber activities represent a grave threat to U.S. competitiveness and the U.S. economy," the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative said in a report about its investigation of China's trade practices. "Evidence from U.S. law enforcement and private sources indicates that the Chinese government has used cyber intrusions to serve its strategic economic objectives."

In 2015, facing the threat of major U.S. sanctions, Chinese President Xi Jinping promised not to use his hacker army to benefit Chinese businesses. Thursday's report is the Trump administration's first major assertion that the 2015 deal has not halted Chinese intellectual property theft. "The evidence indicates that China continues its policy and practice, spanning more than a decade, of using cyber intrusions to target U.S. firms to access their sensitive commercial information and trade secrets," the USTR said in its report, which chronicled years of Chinese government intrusions into American firms.

ATLIENS -- The city of Atlanta on Thursday suffered a ransomware attack that led to outages for a number of services, including those that customers use to access court information or pay bills. At a news conference, city officials said they didn't yet know the full extent of the damage, but emphasized that water, airport and public safety agencies are "operating without incident," according to Richard Cox, chief operating officer. Atlanta has been collaborating with the Homeland Security Department, FBI, Microsoft and Cisco. "We've been working diligently all day long to come to some type of resolution," said Atlanta Mayor Keisha Bottoms. Officials wouldn't predict when the situation might come to an end, and whether the city would ultimately pay the ransom.

RECENTLY ON PRO CYBERSECURITY -- "A voting technology vendor is pushing back against an effort by members of a government advisory group to restrict wireless capabilities in future voting systems in light of recent Senate recommendations." ... The House Energy and Commerce Committee will summon Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to testify about Cambridge Analytica, the Trump campaign data firm that obtained Facebook user data surreptitiously. ... House Intelligence Republicans, meanwhile, voted down a Democratic proposal to bring in Zuckerberg and other tech CEOs. ... The IRS says cyber criminals are stealing an increasing amount of private taxpayer data from tax practitioners' office computers.

-- Rob Wainwright, executive director of Europol, is joining Deloitte as a senior partner in the company's European cybersecurity practice, the firm announced Thursday.

QUICK BYTES

-- Guccifer 2.0, the hacker of 2016 election fame, accidentally revealed himself to be a Russian intelligence officer, according to The Daily Beast.

-- Mozilla is pulling its Facebook advertising.

-- How the United States can go on cyber offense, by Harvard's Michael Sulmeyer. Foreign Affairs.

-- Secure messaging app Telegram must hand over its encryption keys, a Russian court ruled. Threatpost.

-- Americans spent $1.4 million on credit freeze fees after the Equifax breach. Krebs on Security.

-- Here's what the Global Commission on the Stability of Cyberspace is doing. Register.

results.title: Inside the Facebook Hill briefings
results.body:
A daily download of technology news from Washington and Silicon Valley

With help from Margaret Harding McGill, John Hendel, Steven Overly and Ashley Gold

INSIDE THE FACEBOOK HILL BRIEFINGS -- Facebook's Cambridge Analytica briefings on the Hill have centered heavily on content that's already been shared in the company's public blog posts, leaving many questions about the scope of the problem unanswered, according to Congressional aides familiar with the meetings. Facebook this week sent staff including Associate General Counsel Molly Cutler and Deputy Chief Privacy Officer Rob Sherman to huddle with representatives from the Intelligence, Judiciary and Commerce committees in both chambers as it faces a firestorm over revelations that Trump-linked Cambridge Analytica improperly obtained information on some 50 million users of the site.

-- Reply hazy, try again later: One aide noted that Facebook didn't have much to add when pressed about whether the researcher who allegedly sold data to Cambridge Analytica could have shared it with other parties. Aides also said that information about previous audits Facebook has done on its data practices seemed hazy, even as the company made promises to parse through how its apps have gathered information.

-- About that consent decree: In its briefing with the Senate Commerce Committee, Cutler argued that Facebook did not violate a 2011 consent decree with the FTC, according to a source in the meeting. Under its 2011 settlement with the agency, Facebook agreed to get express permission and notify users before sharing their data with third parties. The FTC is now looking into whether Facebook has adhered to this agreement in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica controversy. Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), who attended the briefing, also raised a question about the company's timeline for notifying users who may have been affected by Cambridge Analytica's collection of data. Sherman said he couldn't provide specifics yet, adding that it was a technical challenge the company was still working through. Offices on both sides of the aisle seemed keen to hold a hearing on the recent revelations, the source said.

-- Speaking of hearings, the jockeying for Zuck has begun: House Energy and Commerce leaders on Thursday announced their plans to formally invite Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to testify in front of the panel, potentially kicking off a debate about which Congressional panel should have jurisdiction over such a hearing. Lawmakers across the Judiciary, Commerce and Intelligence Committees in the House and Senate have expressed an interest in a hearing that will put Zuckerberg in the hot seat, leading MT to wonder how the committees will duke it out. (House Intel Republicans on Thursday did vote, however, to shoot down a Democratic proposal for such a panel.)

-- "There's always jurisdictional debate, there's no committee that's invested as much time and effort into what's happening," Senate Intel's top Democrat Mark Warner told Ashley. Blumenthal, a member of the Senate's Commerce and Judiciary committees, has said he thinks both of those panels could provide the ideal forums for such testimony. Of course, the general counsels from Facebook, Twitter and Google did end up making the rounds at multiple committees when they hit the Hill last fall, so it's possible that Zuckerberg could potentially go that route if he committed to making an appearance.

-- Facebook's take on the briefings: "While our internal and external reviews are still ongoing, we appreciated the opportunity to explain what we know as well as to outline both the steps we have already taken and those we will take to address these challenges," a spokesman from the company said in a statement.

OMNIBUS SPEEDS AHEAD -- The Senate in the wee hours of the morning passed a $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill, H.R. 1625, that will keep the government funded through September 30, sending it to the president's desk. The omnibus contains several measures for techies to watch, including $600 million in dedicated spending for a rural broadband pilot program, FCC reauthorization and a bill that would govern law enforcement access of data that's stored overseas, called the CLOUD Act (S. 2383 (115)).

COFFMAN EYES APRIL FOR FINALIZING OPEN INTERNET BILL -- Don't take recent silence from Rep. Mike Coffman (R-Colo.) to mean inactivity. He told John on Thursday that his office remains at work drafting a bill to enshrine strong net neutrality protections, which he says should include a ban on paid prioritization. "The goal is certainly to preserve the principles of net neutrality but to modernize it by creating a separate title, a new title for broadband," said Coffman, who bucked his fellow Republicans by opposing the FCC's December repeal of the Obama-era rules. He initially hoped to release a bill tentatively titled the 21st Century Internet Act by end of February and still predicts the introduction would be "fairly soon," with a goal of releasing it next month after Congress' two-week recess.

-- Internet service providers are at the table, Coffman added: "We're listening to their concerns. Obviously they prefer simply the fact that it's been repealed. They'd rather have the status quo but the fact is, they're participating and listening to our concerns as well. I appreciate that. Whether we come to any kind of agreement, I can't speak to that."

OSTP DIRECTOR LIMBO -- Sens. Mark Warner (D-Va.) and Gary Peters (D-Mich.) are pressing the White House to nominate a director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, a key advisory role that's remained vacant for more than a year. "We believe it is critical to appoint a well-qualified individual, with a background in science or engineering, to this role as soon as possible," the lawmakers wrote in a letter on Thursday, adding that the OSTP director serves as a vital partner for Congress. A spokesman for OSTP told MT there were no updates on the position at this time. Recall that MT previously reported that White House Deputy CTO Michael Kratsios is currently the highest-ranking political appointee at the policy shop and helping run its operations on a day-to-day basis.

GOOD FRIDAY MORNING and welcome to Morning Tech, where our brackets are just barely hanging on. Send your tech tips to lzhou@politico.com Catch the rest of the team's contact info after Quick Downloads.

Got an event for MT's tech calendar? Email us the details at techcalendar@politicopro.com.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

** A message from CTIA and America's wireless industry: The global race to 5G is on -- and America needs to win. FCC rules modernizing the federal review process move U.S. wireless companies closer to investing $275 billion to build these networks - creating more than 3 million jobs, and adding hundreds of billions to the economy, according to Accenture. Learn more at raceto5G.CTIA.org. **

TAKING THE STAND -- The first witness in the AT&T-Time Warner merger trial faced attorneys Thursday. Suzanne Fenwick, vice president of content acquisition for Cox Communications, was called upon by the Justice Department to explain how the proposed merger would give Time Warner greater leverage in television licensing negotiations. Fenwick told the court Time Warner could offer a "horribly ugly deal" and shut off its programs if Cox doesn't consent. That could drive Cox customers to rival DirecTV, which AT&T owns, and subsequently drive Cox out of business, she warned. "We are very concerned for what that will mean for us in our next negotiation," Fenwick said.

-- Then, Daniel Petrocelli, the litigator representing the companies, was unleashed. In a series of rapid questions, Petrocelli asked Fenwick what "homework" she had done to substantiate her fears -- projections of subscribers who would walk or calculations of money her company would lose. Fenwick had none. "You think you can just come in here and give your opinion" without hard evidence to back it up, Petrocelli asked.

-- The proceedings continue Monday with testimony from Warren Schlichting, group president of Dish Network-owned SlingTV, and John Martin, the chief executive and chairman of Turner.

ROSENWORCEL TAKES ON FCC SECURITY -- FCC security officials had surrounded a woman in the audience of the agency's meeting Thursday and were removing chairs from around her when Democratic Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel stopped her statement opposing the 5G infrastructure order to intervene. Rosenworcel asked security why they were removing someone who was behaving, and said, "I would just ask that we not remove people from the room who are quietly listening." The woman had previously applauded during Commissioner Mignon Clyburn's dissent on the order, which excludes small cell wireless antennas from federal environmental and historic reviews. A man who voiced concerns about cell phone radiation was removed by security shortly afterward.

-- The man was removed because he disrupted the vote by speaking loudly, an FCC spokesman said. The woman was told by security she wasn't allowed to stand up and block the view of other audience members, and she was approached by security again because she stood up repeatedly, he said.

MATSUI PREPARING 'SPECTRUM NOW ACT' -- Rep. Doris Matsui (D-Calif.) is putting together legislation to ensure federal agencies can use cash from the 14-year-old Spectrum Relocation Fund to properly research what government-held spectrum might be freed up or shared with commercial entities. "Current law limits how much of existing SRF funds can be used for this research and related activities," Matsui, co-chair of the Congressional Spectrum Caucus, said Thursday during an unrelated legislative hearing. "This has created an unintended situation that could prevent agencies from accessing existing SRF funds and potentially prevent more spectrum entering the commercial marketplace." She said she's crafting legislation to address the problem. The Competitive Carriers Association backs the effort, Senior VP Tim Donovan told her during the hearing: "That research is money well spent."

CCIA ADDS LEGAL VOICE TO NET NEUTRALITY BATTLE -- The tech trade association, which counts Google and eBay among its members, filed a motion Thursday to intervene in support of the lawsuit challenging the FCC's repeal of its net neutrality regulations. Consumer groups, state attorneys general and tech companies including Etsy have filed suit against the repeal, with the Internet Association also seeking to support the challenge this week. "CCIA looks forward to offering strong, substantive legal arguments about the importance of an open internet for the digital economy and America's global competitiveness," CCIA President Ed Black said in a statement. Industry trade groups NCTA, CTIA, and USTelecom are backing up the FCC in the legal battle.

ROBOCALLED OUT -- The FTC and FCC are huddling this morning for a policy forum aimed at addressing illegal robocalls, an issue that both agencies receive a high number of complaints about every year. Both FCC Chairman Ajit Pai and FTC Acting Chairman Maureen Ohlhausen are due to deliver remarks at the event, along with FCC Commissioners Clyburn and Brendan Carr, and FTC Commissioner Terrell McSweeny. Watch the livestream beginning at 9:30 a.m., here.

CARDENAS HAS CONCERNS ABOUT SINCLAIR-TRIBUNE -- Rep. Tony C√°rdenas (D-Calif.), co-chair of the Multicultural Media Caucus, is voicing concerns about the Sinclair-Tribune merger, in a letter to DOJ antitrust chief Makan Delrahim that's been signed by over 35 lawmakers including Reps. Yvette Clarke (D-N.Y.), Jan Schakowsky (D-Ill.) and Anna Eshoo (D-Calif.). "We believe the merger should be rejected outright," they write. "If the merger is approved, it will have substantial negative competitive consequences nationwide, resulting in higher consumer prices and lower quality and less local content." The lawmakers also question whether the divestiture of television stations is being handled properly, citing examples of potential Sinclair influence over stations even after they've been purportedly divested.

SILICON VALLEY MUST-READS

-- How IBM perpetuated age bias: "As it scrambled to compete in the internet world, the once-dominant tech company cut thousands of U.S. workers, hitting its most senior employees hardest and flouting rules against age bias," ProPublica reports.

-- Dropbox's opening day: "Dropbox raised $750 million ahead of an opening day of trading on Friday in an IPO that will be closely watched across Silicon Valley to gauge the health of the tech economy," Recode reports.

-- Huawei takes another hit: "Best Buy Co. plans to stop selling phones in the U.S. made by Huawei Technologies Co., according to a person familiar with the matter, the latest blow for the Chinese wireless-equipment giant in the U.S.," The Wall Street Journal reports.

TRANSITIONS -- Parita Shah, previously chief of staff at the Millennium Challenge Corporation during the Obama Administration, heads to Pandora as its new head of public affairs on the government relations and public policy team.

QUICK DOWNLOADS

Google's EU privacy plans: "Alphabet Inc.'s Google will ask web publishers to obtain consent on its behalf to gather personal information on European users and target ads at them using Google's systems, according to people familiar with the matter, part of a plan to keep up with data-privacy rules in Europe," The Wall Street Journal reports.

Instagram updates feed: "Instagram isn't quite bringing back the chronological feed, but it will show more new posts and stop suddenly bumping you to the top of the feed while you're scrolling," TechCrunch reports.

Experts react to self-driving accident: "Video of the first self-driving car crash that killed a pedestrian suggests a 'catastrophic failure' by Uber's technology, according to experts in the field, who said the footage showed the autonomous system erring on one of its most basic functions," The Wall Street Journal reports.

Tips, comments, suggestions? Send them along via email to our team: Eric Engleman (eengleman@politico.com, @ericengleman), Kyle Daly (kdaly@politico.com, @dalykyle), Nancy Scola (nscola@politico.com, @nancyscola), Margaret Harding McGill (mmcgill@politico.com, @margarethmcgill), Ashley Gold (agold@politico.com, @ashleyrgold), Steven Overly (soverly@politico.com, @stevenoverly), John Hendel (jhendel@politico.com, @JohnHendel) and Li Zhou (lzhou@politico.com, @liszhou)

** A message from CTIA and America's wireless industry: We need new rules for new 5G networks. FCC rules modernizing federal environmental and historic preservation reviews of new wireless infrastructure are a critical step. We need similar action by cities, states, the FCC and Congress to update local siting rules. Identifying a pipeline of new low-, mid-, and high-band spectrum is the other piece of the puzzle. These key steps will allow U.S. wireless companies to invest $275 billion, create more than 3 million jobs, and add hundreds of billions to the economy, according to Accenture. This will drive breakthrough advancements in remote health care, connected vehicles, energy, education and beyond -- making our lives better and safer. But the race to deploy 5G wireless networks is underway -- and policymakers must act this year so that the U.S. can maintain our global leadership in wireless. The EU, China, Japan, South Korea and others are doing everything they can to win. Learn more at Raceto5G.CTIA.org. **

results.title: Health IT groups happy with the omnibus
results.body:
HEALTH IT GROUPS MOSTLY HAPPY WITH THE OMNIBUS: Experts tell POLITICO that the spending deal the Senate passed late last night is favorable for federal health IT groups, though funding for ONC and OCR remains flat.

Congress rejected a White House budget proposal that slashed ONC's budget to $38 million for fiscal 2018, and instead allotted about $60 million to the agency. The White House had requested $33 million for OCR; the omnibus keeps it at its current level, $38.7 million.

Despite discrepancies in actual dollar amounts, the omnibus mirrors the White House's recent commitments to health data and making patient records more easily accessible, HIMSS vice president for government relations Tom Leary tells POLITICO.

Congressional staffers told him they were "made aware" of that effort when working on the bill, Leary said. President Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and CMS Administrator Seema Verma made an ambitious but detail-scarce promise to revamp health IT at HIMSS earlier this month.

Once Trump signs the budget, Leary said, HIMSS will make a push to tell lawmakers how important ONC is in coordinating standards and fulfilling the 21st Century Cures Act.

MORE REACTIONS TO THE BILL:

-- The Medical Informatics Association supports the full funding of ONC, CDC, AHRQ and the FDA, as well as the $3 billion boost to the NIH, according to a statement from the group. "While there continues to be a tug-of-war between White House and Congressional funding and policy priorities, this budget will give HHS agencies and offices a few months of consistency," they said.

-- Rep. Doris Matsui (D-Calif.) was especially encouraged by a $100 million boost for community behavioral health clinics, she said in a statement. Matsui recently unveiled an amendment to the Ryan Haight Act that would authorize mental health clinics to coordinate video consultations with remote providers so they can prescribe controlled substances to their patients.

-- Research!America president and CEO Mary Woolley said the boost for NIH funding could lead to solutions to the opioid epidemic. Additional funding for AHRQ represents a "sound investment to achieve higher quality, lower cost health care," she said.

-- Rep. Joe Manchin, D-W.V., scored a victory with the inclusion of "Jessie's Law," which would ensure that care providers have knowledge of patients' opioid abuse history if the patient decides to share that data. The eventual goal, according to Manchin's office, is to flag the patient's record if they've experienced an opioid addiction, just as a record might note an allergy. Manchin called the measure "bipartisan, commonsense legislation."

SEEMA VERMA PREVIEWS MEDICARE AGENDA -- The CMS administrator shared a preview of upcoming Medicare payment regulations, with an eye toward ensuring "sustainability of the program," she told our colleague Rachana Pradhan and other reporters yesterday.

-- CMS wants to 'double down' on price transparency, with a goal of helping enrollees understand their costs. "You're going to see us just get started on that with the payment rules but there's a lot more coming around that," Verma said. "When we look at the Medicare system, we all know that if you go to one place it might be cheaper than another place."

-- The agency intends to reduce burden on providers, partly by shrinking their reporting measures and changing the conditions they must meet to participate in the Medicare program. Verma also suggested that the agency is pursuing changes related to Stark laws, which govern physician self-referral for Medicare and Medicaid patients. "We've heard that that's a big barrier for providers when they're trying to do value-based payment arrangements," she said.

-- Verma also plans to build on interoperability of electronic health records through the MyHealthEData initiative, which aims to help patients have better access to their own health records, that she announced last month. "You will see the actual actions that we are taking around interoperability this year," she said.

CALL FOR MACRA REFORM FALLS ON DEAF EARS: Policymakers have largely ignored calls from the Medicare Payment Advisory Committee to eliminate the new Merit-based Incentive Payment System and have instead focused on tweaking it, our colleague David Pittman reports.

In last month's two-year budget deal, lawmakers "provided some significant flexibility" in the program, according to Rep. Frank Pallone, D-N.J.

"Anytime MedPAC makes a recommendation, I think we should look at it seriously," Pallone, who is the top Democrat on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, told David. "But whether or not we follow up on it, at this point, I couldn't say."

-- Dr. Tom Frieden @DrFrieden Encouraged to see Congress believes @CDC should continue their global health security work by providing $50M in FY18 with three-year spending authority. These programs keep Americans safe, and help the world better prepare for the next epidemic. http://ow.ly/he9i30j6dHC

-- Arien Malec @amalec Somebody should work on a secure digital standard to get data from practice to practice built into #EHR @DrDannySand Only in healthcare would this be seen as an #innovation. From the cover page of a fax I received today in my practice. What is wrong with our industry? #StuckInThePast #WelcomeToThe90s [links to an image notifying the recipient of the VNA of Boston's transition from receiving documents via mail to fax.]

AZAR TAPS CVS VICE PRESIDENT TO LEAD DRUG PRICING PROGRAM: HHS Secretary Alex Azar is bringing on CVS Caremark Vice President Daniel Best to head up the department's effort to lower drug prices, a source with knowledge of the hire tells our colleague Adam Cancryn reports.

Best has led industry relations for CVS' Medicare Part D business and will oversee HHS' day-to-day work on initiatives aimed at cutting pharmaceutical costs, Adam reports. Best joined CVS as part of the company's 2011 acquisition of Universal American's Part D operations, and previously worked for Pfizer.

Adam's full story, for Pros, here.

NY TOUTS PDMP IMPROVEMENTS: New York is touting some improvements in its state prescription drug monitoring program. According to a release Thursday, the database is now interoperable with 25 states plus DC.

New York has been active in deploying IT solutions to the opioid crisis; it also recently implemented mandatory e-prescriptions of drugs, as well as mandatory checks of the state PDMP. The release claims that since the legislation putting those requirements in place, doctor shopping has declined by 98 percent.

FDA LAUNCHES MOBILE APP FOR DRUG INFO: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday unveiled "Drugs@FDA Express," an app that lets users search a database of FDA-approved brand and generic drugs and therapeutic products. The FDA already has a website dedicated to this database, but the app is a streamlined version, according to the agency. The app doesn't have everything, though -- mobile users won't be able to access approval letters, for instance, unless they go to the web page. The app represents FDA's effort to "bring information to consumers in more accessible formats," Commissioner Scott Gottlieb said in a release.

COMMENTS ON PRICE TRANSPARENCY EFFORT DUE TODAY: A bipartisan group of Senators has been gathering information from patients, providers and insurers about ways to increase price transparency, and comments are due today.

Sen. Bill Cassidy has established a working group on price transparency that includes Sens. Todd Young, Chuck Grassley, Michael Bennet, Tom Carper and Claire McCaskill. The goal is to craft legislation that would make pricing data widely available.

The group has posed several tough questions to stakeholders, including who should be responsible for making health data available, and how to ensure that reporting requirements don't place an unnecessary burden on providers and payers.

results.title: We've got the BEAT
results.body:
BEAT DOWN: It's one of the most complex parts of the Republican tax overhaul -- the base erosion and anti-abuse tax, or BEAT. Our Brian Faler unpacks the provision this morning and finds that it's become "a four-letter word" for many in the tax world. "Corporate tax departments, Wall Street, K Street, law school professors and others are now grappling with, and sometimes cursing, what some say is a brutally complicated new tax," Brian writes.

In a nutshell, the BEAT is intended to keep U.S. companies from fleeing to greener pastures now that we have a territorial tax system, which generally won't tax what multinationals earn abroad. The BEAT is a form of minimum tax that requires companies to pay at least 5 percent this year and 10 percent on taxable income next year. Companies must do multiple calculations to arrive at how much they owe, if anything. (See Brian's story for more details.)

"It is the most consequential and poorly thought out of all the major business tax provisions" in the new tax law, Ed Kleinbard, former head of the Joint Committee on Taxation, told Brian. "Any multinational is at risk of having a large BEAT liability because of its unpredictability."

Corporations and tax experts hoping that the Treasury Department will clarify things with regulations will have quite a wait. "International experts there have been focused on developing regulations regarding the law's one-time tax holiday on companies' overseas earnings because that has a more immediate effect on their taxes. Details on how the BEAT will be implemented are not expected until later this year."

WELCOME TO THE (ALMOST) WEEKEND. I'm pinch hitting for Bernie today as he kicks back for a few days. Other guest writers will be coming your way Monday and Tuesday. But don't wait for him to get back to give us your tips, compliments and -- if you must -- complaints.

OMNIBUS UPDATE: The reviews are rolling in on the tax provisions of the massive spending bill that the Senate cleared early this morning to fund the government for the rest of the fiscal year. Not surprisingly, the happiest folks in town (and beyond the Beltway) are the companies that will be able to compete on a more level field with farm co-ops now that the "grain glitch" is fixed, and low-income housing advocates, who won a provision to make housing tax credits more attractive under the new tax law.

But some people are happy with what was left out. The Baptist Joint Committee for Religious Liberty, which advocates the separation of church and state, said it and likeminded groups "can breathe a sigh of relief" since the legislation didn't abolish the "Johnson Amendment," which prohibits politicking by tax-exempt churches and other religious groups. President Donald Trump, House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady, many other Republican lawmakers and some other churches have been pushing to get rid of the amendment, named for Lyndon B. Johnson when he pushed it through as a senator. "Some hoped they could slip a bad policy change into must-pass legislation, but advocates for keeping nonprofits nonpartisan spoke up and prevailed," Amanda Tyler, executive director of the Baptist Joint Committee, said in a statement.

SPEAKING OF WHICH: The Joint Committee on Taxation has tallied up the costs of the tax provisions in the omnibus, Brian reports. Grand total: $2.7 billion over 10 years. The low-income housing credit sweetener would cost $2.8 billion. But fixing the grain glitch would generate $108 million.

NEW! Pro Tax has launched a new Tax Tracker to help you follow the implementation of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the most sweeping overhaul of federal tax law in more than a generation. To be notified of new developments, customize your settings to include the Tax Tracker tag here.

** A message from the Intuit Tax and Financial Center: This tax season, government and industry are engaged in a system-wide collaborative known as the Information Sharing and Analysis Center or "ISAC." The IRS, state revenue agencies and leading industry members are all working together to protect taxpayers and eliminate cyberfraud from the tax filing process. To learn more, visit http://bit.ly/2G5x7zz **

STOCKING UP: Not One Penny, a coalition opposed to the new tax law, circulated an article from Vox that examined corporate stock buybacks spurred by the tax cuts in the GOP overhaul. As if on cue, Sen. Tammy Baldwin (D-Wis.) introduced legislation to put the brakes on the practice. Our Aaron Lorenzo reports: "Baldwin's bill, titled the Reward Work Act, includes provisions that would prevent corporations from buying back their stock on the open market and would repeal a 1982 rule from the SEC that helps corporations avoid manipulation charges in open-market repurchases. Corporations would still be able to buy back their stock through tender offers under the legislation, but it would also subject a third of corporate boards to direct election by a company's employees."

Now, that bill is going nowhere in a Republican Congress. But it's one more arrow in the Democrats' quiver to fire at the tax law in the run-up to the midterm elections, and another preview of what they would try to do to the tax law if they take over Congress.

SPEAKING OF THE STOCK MARKET: Trump's decision to slap $60 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports rattled Wall Street, with the big three market indexes plunging Thursday. Brady and other GOP lawmakers were tempered in their response. In a statement, Brady said Trump was right to "take a hardline against China's dishonest trade practices" but added: "Tariffs are taxes, so the next 30 days of input are crucial to make sure we don't punish American workers and families for China's misbehavior."

At the same time, the administration exempted the European Union, Australia, Argentina, Brazil and South Korea from steel and aluminum tariffs that take effect today.

NO REST FOR THE WICKED: Less than a month to go for the tax filing season, and fraudsters are working overtime. The IRS says taxpayer info is being pilfered from the office computers of tax practitioners at a growing rate. Aaron reports that "75 tax practitioner firms reported data thefts in January and February, a nearly 60 percent increase compared to the same type of crime over the same period last year." Watch out for the "New Client" scam, where impostors try to insert malware on computers by posing as customers in emails that include infected attachments.

INTERNATIONAL UPDATE

THAT DIDN'T TAKE LONG: Congress' top tax writers are not amused by the European Union's newly introduced tax on digital revenues, which would hit some 150 companies, half of them American. "It's a revenue grab, pure and simple," Brady told Aaron. Senate Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch chimed in: "Countries eager to raise more revenue ought to pursue the taxation of items or services that have a clear and concise definition within today's global economy," he said. "To attempt to tax items with a so-called 'digital presence' or another questionable definition is counterproductive and should be further vetted before it is seriously pursued."

STATE NEWS

OPPORTUNITY KNOCKS: Local officials are bullish on the new Opportunity Zones included in the GOP tax law, which will use tax incentives to lure investments to low-income urban and rural areas. This week, governors selected the census tracts that they want to be part of the zones in their states. There are plenty of skeptics who say that the zones will end up doing no more to help struggling areas than similar programs have in the past. But the Urban Institute's Brett Theodos thinks the initiative "could become the nation's largest economic development 'program'" if done right. Theodos writes in Urban Wire that the group has prepared a "dataset" ranking eligible tracts based on commercial, multifamily, single-family and small business lending, along with a gauge of whether they've had a lot of socioeconomic change. "Decisionmakers can use our data to determine which areas are undergoing natural change or gentrification (where Opportunity Zone distinctions would likely be unnecessary), as opposed to areas in more need of a tax incentive to boost investment," Theodos writes.

QUICK LINKS

The Washington Post Fact Checker gives Trump two Pinocchios for his claim that California has the nation's highest taxes.

Nederland, Colo., hosts an annual Frozen Dead Guy Days festival to honor Bredo Morst√∏l, a 110-plus-year-old cryogenically frozen resident of the town. It features coffin races, icy turkey bowling and a slushie-fueled Brain Freeze Contest.

** A message from the Intuit Tax and Financial Center: This tax season, government and industry are engaged in a system-wide collaborative known as the Information Sharing and Analysis Center or "ISAC. The ISAC's mission, is to combat tax cyberfraud by securely sharing information via a public/private partnership, harnessing the expertise of Federal and State tax authorities and the private sector tax services industry to work together to protect the American tax system from cybersecurity threats, leveraging applied data science and analysis to defeat strategic threats. Within the program's first year, ISAC helped reduce tax identity theft by 40% and protected an estimated $6 billion of refunds from fraud. Learn more about the effort at http://bit.ly/2G5x7zz **

results.title: Compromise 'fix' for public service loan forgiveness
results.body:
With help from Benjamin Wermund, Caitlin Emma and Mel Leonor

BREAKING ON THE HILL: The Senate early Friday on a 65-32 vote cleared a sweeping $1.3 trillion fiscal 2018 spending bill, averting a government shutdown. The legislation, H.R. 1625 (115), comes more than six months into the current fiscal year, and extends funding through Sept. 30. President Donald Trump has said he will sign it into law.

OMNIBUS INCLUDES COMPROMISE 'FIX' FOR PUBLIC SERVICE LOAN FORGIVENESS: Student loan borrowers working in public service jobs who may lose out on federal loan forgiveness because they selected the wrong repayment plan will get a second chance to get their debt canceled under the omnibus government spending bill. The funding measure includes a provision creating a limited, one-time-only expansion of the federal Public Service Loan Forgiveness program.

-- The problem: Federal law requires borrowers to make 10 years' of monthly payments under a qualified repayment plan before having the remaining balance of their debt forgiven. But several reports surfaced over the past year of borrowers unknowingly selecting a non-qualifying repayment plan and being rejected for loan forgiveness as a result. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau last year issued a report blaming "student loan servicing practices" in some cases for putting borrowers in a repayment plan that didn't count toward forgiveness.

-- The omnibus creates a new one-time $350 million fund that's meant to make it easier for borrowers to access loan forgiveness under the program. The fund will cover the government's cost of canceling the loans of borrowers who otherwise would qualify for public service loan forgiveness had they not selected a non-qualifying repayment plan.

-- But the new program comes with some limitations: First, the loan forgiveness will be offered on a first-come, first-serve basis until the fund runs out. And some borrowers who selected the "wrong" repayment plan to qualify for loan forgiveness still wouldn't be eligible. The Education Department, under the bill, would compare a borrower's most recent monthly payment (and the monthly payment one year prior) to what they would have paid under the "correct" plan. Borrowers that would have been required to pay more won't qualify for the loan forgiveness.

-- Sen. Elizabeth Warren, who along with other Democrats had pushed for a more sweeping expansion of eligibility for the program, on Thursday praised the limited reprieve in the omnibus. "I'm very glad that, for the first time, we got some money to help public servants unfairly trapped under a mountain of debt -- but this fight isn't over," Warren said in a statement. "We need a permanent fix that ensures every single teacher, nurse, police officer, and firefighter gets the student loan forgiveness that we promised them and that they earned."

-- The limited expansion of public service loan forgiveness in the bipartisan bill comes even as some Republicans have sought to kill the program, arguing that it isn't well-targeted or an effective use of taxpayer dollars. The Trump administration has proposed eliminating the program entirely, as does the House GOP bill rewriting the Higher Education Act.

-- But Education Secretary Betsy DeVos would now be forced to take steps to publicize the program under the omnibus appropriations bill. The legislation sets aside $2.3 million for the Education Department "to conduct outreach to borrowers" about the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program. It includes a requirement that the secretary "shall" tell all federal student loan borrowers about the requirements of the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program and make it easier for all borrowers to enroll in it.

GOOD FRIDAY MORNING AND WELCOME TO MORNING EDUCATION. Drop me a line with your tips and feedback: mstratford@politico.com or @mstratford. Share event listings: educalendar@politicopro.com. And follow us on Twitter: @Morning_Edu and @POLITICOPro.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

CONGRESS EYES NEW STUDY ON SECLUSION AND RESTRAINT: The $1.3 trillion spending bill unveiled by lawmakers this week orders congressional investigators to study data reported to the Education Department's civil rights arm on how often schools use seclusion or restraint on students, isolating students or physically holding them. An explanatory document accompanying the omnibus says, "There is concern that seclusion and restraint issues continue to be chronically underreported." The omnibus instructs the Government Accountability Office to look at how schools can improve their data collection and avoid restraint and seclusion, which advocates say can cause trauma and physical harm and should only be used if a child truly poses physical harm to themselves or others.

-- Advocates for students with disabilities are praising the study. "Anything we can do to illuminate the extent these dangerous practices are imposed on students in our schools is welcome and much needed," said Denise Marshall, executive director of the Council of Parent Attorneys and Advocates.

D.C. AREA UNIVERSITIES BACK MARCH AGAINST GUN VIOLENCE: The leaders of D.C.'s 14 area universities signed a letter supporting this weekend's march and ran it as an ad in today's Washington Post. "No student, regardless of race, income, or zip code, should live in fear of gun violence. We call for our elected leaders to act now," the letter says. "We recognize that the young people who are marching this weekend may be further developing their talents at our institutions in the coming years. We wish you a safe, productive visit to our region, we stand with you, and thank you for making your voices heard."

WHITE HOUSE DISCUSSES CAMPUS 'CRISES': According to Kellyanne Conway, college campuses currently face two crises: Opioids and free speech. The counselor to the president moderated a panel with Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar and a Department of Justice spokeswoman about the two subjects at a White House millennials event Thursday. Conway referred to them as "crises -- plural -- on campuses."

-- But the point was undercut by the president himself, who spoke just before the panel and seemed to downplay any crisis of speech on college campuses that conservatives often lament. "I think it's highly overblown," Trump said when asked for advice for young conservatives on campuses who feel like they're being silenced by administrators.

-- Trump's full response: "I think the numbers are actually much different than people think. I think we have a lot of support. If they have one campus or two campuses -- that we know what they are -- it gets all the publicity. We have campuses where you have the vast majority of people that are perhaps like many of the people in this room -- you could call it conservative, you call it whatever you want, but they're people that want free speech. If you look at what's going on with free speech with the super left, with antifa with all of these characters -- I tell you what, they get a lot of publicity, but you go to the real campuses and you go all over the country, you go out to the Middle West, you go out even to the coast in many cases, we have tremendous support. I would say we have majority support. I think it's highly overblown, highly overblown."

-- The president's comments seem to counter his administration's stance that too many colleges are suppressing speech. Trump himself said as much on the campaign trail and seemed to threaten the University of California-Berkeley on Twitter last year. Attorney General Jeff Sessions has said "we have too much suppression of free and open speech on college campuses today" and his Justice Department has sided in court with conservative student groups in free speech cases. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has urged lawmakers to use the "bully pulpit" to protect free speech on campus, saying "we have seen, in far too many cases, an intolerance toward listening to and at least hearing from others who have different perspectives than ours."

-- Of note: A recent survey of college students by Gallup and the Knight Foundation found that 61 percent of students believe that their campus environment prevents people from speaking their mind, compared with 54 percent of students last year. Nearly 70 percent of students, however, believe that conservatives are able to openly and freely express their views, while 92 percent believe that liberals and other campus groups are able to do so, the survey found.

-- As for opioids, Azar said "the millennial generation is getting hit very hard" and noted that "among ages 25 to 34, drug overdose is the No. 1 cause of death from injury." He warned against getting hooked on prescription medication: "If you get a 90-count prescription for your wisdom teeth and you use two of them, don't keep 88 of them for a rainy day." And he said "the country has not yet waken up to this scourge of fentanyl as the superpower opioid that it is," warning that marijuana and other drugs can be laced with it.

-- Are those really the top crises facing college students? Some were skeptical. "Opioids? Free speech? Kellyanne has no clue," Trinity Washington University President Pat McGuire wrote on Twitter. "I just was with a group of students and their main concerns are debt load, food security, housing, transportation, child care...."

ALSO FROM THE WHITE HOUSE'S MILLENNIAL EVENT: Trump took another swipe at community colleges, saying again that he prefers the term "vocational": "We need vocational schools. Now they call them a lot of times community colleges - I don't think it's an accurate definition." It's becoming a recurring talking point for the president, who last month said that "Vocational is a much better word in a lot of cases than community college."

-- Ivanka Trump praised a funding boost for an early education grant program included in the omnibus. She called the proposed doubling of funding for Child Care and Development Block grants a "vast expansion" that would help ensure young children receive care in an enriching environment. The grant program awards funding to states to expand child care programs. "We spend so much as a country trying to remediate, and trying to get a student on the right track when they've fallen behind ... and we don't focus nearly enough on that really critical period between ages 0 to 5." Congress also gave a $610 million boost to Head Start and preserved funding for the Preschool Development Grants program, which the Trump administration proposed to ax in its budget request.

-- Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta touted the administration's push to boost apprenticeships and said four-year colleges need to do a better job of preparing students for the workforce. "Here's the question: Are universities teaching the skills that are being demanded by the current workforce? Are universities serving the students well?" he said. "Unfortunately that emphasis on preparing individuals for family sustaining jobs is not out there."

-- Acosta also talked about "excessive" occupational licensing, arguing that state-to-state licensing requirements make it difficult for teachers to move. "We talk about, 'We need more teachers.' So why are we making it so difficult for teachers to move?" Acosta said. "We've gotta reform this."

REPORT ROLL CALL

-- The advocacy organizations Rights4Girls and the Georgetown Juvenile Justice Initiative are out with a new report detailing the overrepresentation of African American girls in D.C.'s juvenile justice system.

MOVERS AND SHAKERS

-- Brigid Ahern has been tapped as president and CEO of the nonprofit Turnaround for Children, effective in June.

SYLLABUS

-- Kansas lawmakers advance first part of school funding fix: The Associated Press.

-- Michigan House OKs bill allowing districts to describe charter schools as "public schools" on ballots: The Associated Press.

-- Student shot at Maryland school will be taken off life support, family says: The New York Times.
