results.title: Idaho park renaming nearly upends entire omnibus
results.body:
With help from Alex Guill√©n, Emily Holden and Annie Snider

OMNI-SURE-DONE: Shortly after midnight, the Senate cleared by a 65 to 32 vote a massive $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill largely devoid of environmental policy riders and that rejected the deep cuts for energy programs sought by the Trump administration. A plot twist emerged late Thursday when it emerged an irate Sen. Jim Risch was holding up the bill over a provision renaming the White Clouds Wilderness in Idaho after a political rival, former governor and Interior Secretary Cecil Andrus. Turns out Rep. Mike Simpson slipped the language changing the name of wilderness area into the omnibus. Senate leadership eventually passed language addressing Risch's issue, though the House isn't expected to act on it before the bill becomes law. More on the Senate hiccups here.

One thing that does appear clear is that after relentlessly demanding deep cuts to EPA's staffing and funding over the past decade, Republicans seem increasingly concerned that further hacks at the agency could hit popular grants or cleanup programs, your ME host and Emily Holden report. The omnibus H.R. 1625 (115) keeps EPA spending levels about the same as fiscal 2017, while resisting the White House's calls to trim the agency by around a third. "It suggests we know that they have a role to do and, as long as they are performing that job with the people they have, then that probably starts justifying the size," senior Energy and Commerce Republican John Shimkus told ME. Jeff Holmstead, who was assistant administrator of EPA's air office under George W. Bush, said both Republicans and Democrats understand that while some of EPA's work is controversial, "a lot of it is just basic good government" services.

It's not a universal position among GOPers. "Whether it's a sweet spot or not, I don't know," Rep. Mike Simpson, a senior EPA Appropriator, told ME. Rep. Ken Calvert, who oversees the agency funding on the Appropriations Committee, said lawmakers have worked with Administrator Scott Pruitt to give him the resources to run the agency. "He's been making efficiencies within the department," Calvert said. "I think there's still some efficiencies to create."

Democrats spin things differently. Some see it as recognition that Republicans don't want to gut the agency. "Underneath a lot of the invective, there's a lot of recognition by Republican colleagues that the work EPA and our science community do is very valuable and they would like to continue to support it," Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse told ME. Others said it was Democrats using their leverage against a divided Republican party. "The Republican caucus is not able to pass a spending bill with their own votes so they need Democratic votes. And when they need Democratic votes we get to ask for things like protecting EPA funding," Rep. Ted Lieu said.

Key stat: EPA's workforce has dropped to 14,056, down 1,400 from when President Donald Trump took office and well below 17,417 at the beginning of the decade, according to the agency.

Speaking of staffing, Pruitt took to Portland-based KXL radio Thursday to boast EPA staffing has fallen to Reagan-era levels. He said coverage of his international first-class flights has been "very gratuitous with respect to certain media," and claimed some outlets don't like that EPA is rolling back regulations and shrinking its footprint. "We're getting more done with less," he said. He also said he will issue a memo "pretty soon" to require any scientific studies the agency uses must disclose all their data, following up on his announcement of the new policy earlier this week.

IS THIS THING ON? REMEMBER ME? For one day and one day only, I'm your guest host Anthony Adragna, and API's Khary Cauthen was first to identify Anne Royall as the first female journalist to interview a president. For today: Which member of the Cabinet was co-owner of a minor league baseball team from 2003 through 2010? Give me a holler at aadragna@politico.com and show us a little love by following us on Twitter @AnthonyAdragna, @kelseytam, @Morning_Energy, and @POLITICOPro.

CLOTURE FILED ON WHEELER: Just before 1 a.m. Friday, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell filed cloture on the nomination of Andrew Wheeler to be deputy administrator of EPA. While the exact timing of floor consideration remains unclear, the move likely tees up a vote on Wheeler's selection in the coming weeks.

STRIKING BACK: China plans to hit back on Trump's steel and aluminum tariffs with 15 percent duties on products including U.S. exports of modified ethanol and seamless steel pipes, Pro Trade's Adam Behsudi reports, citing a Chinese Ministry of Commerce release. The first stage of tariffs would include a 15 percent tariff on steel oil and gas pipeline and drill pipe coming from the U.S., according to an informal translation of the document. China is the third-largest market of U.S. pipe steel, according to a December 2017 report from the International Trade Administration. The plan splits tariffs on 128 products in two groups, 120 of which would see the 15 percent duty.

PERRY DEFENDS SAUDI NUCLEAR TALKS: Failure by the U.S. to engage in talks with Saudi Arabia about providing them with nuclear reactors means the job will likely go to countries without requirements the technology not be used to build nuclear weapons, Energy Secretary Rick Perry said Thursday. "Either Russia or China is going to be a partner in building civil nuclear capability in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, or the United States [is]," Perry said at the Senate Armed Services Committee. "I think it's important for us to negotiate in a really good and a powerful way, but recognizing that the alternative of who they're going to be doing business with is of great concern to me." That came after Sen. Jack Reed, ranking member of the panel, warned he would oppose any agreement without nonproliferation guarantees "and I think many others would to."

Agrees Russian cyber attacks an 'act of war': Perry agreed under questioning from Sen. Richard Blumenthal that repeated Russian efforts to penetrate the electric grid constituted "an act of war." He declined to say publicly what efforts the U.S. had done in response but said he had taken "every effort to protect the electrical grid from those kinds of attacks."

** A message from Chevron: Chevron and local partners are helping to provide DOERS with the hands-on technical training needed for today's jobs in the manufacturing and energy industries. Watch the video: http://politi.co/2FGfTFv **

LET'S BE BRIEFED: House Oversight Chairman Trey Gowdy has requested a briefing from Interior about the $139,000 it spent for new doors for Secretary Ryan Zinke's office suite. In a letter, Gowdy asked for a briefing on the need to replace the doors and information on the acquisition process.

CONFIRMED: The Senate late Thursday confirmed Anne White to be assistant secretary for environmental management by voice vote. Her nomination had been held by Senate EPW Chairman John Barrasso over DOE's practice of selling excess government-controlled uranium onto the market, which the Wyoming Republican said was hurting the domestic uranium sector.

MARKET MOVER: PJM Interconnect CEO Andy Ott isn't concerned about the recent attacks on markets -- such as Perry's rebuffed NOPR -- and he thinks markets like his can easily integrate energy storage. After all, PJM, which keeps the lights on in the nation's capital and 13 Mid-Atlantic and Rust Belt states, already has demand response built into its market. "It's the same stuff. Folks out West haven't seen demand response because they don't have organized markets. I'm trying to change that, of course, but the point is the phenomena we've already seen happen, it's just [about] what technology is the best, most competitive way to do it."

Go West. Mr. Ott: PJM is working with western reliability manager Peak Reliabiity to explore a partnership in the Western states. He said he was approached by western utilities and Peak and he thinks there's a "niche" for PJM. "Frankly the California governance issue where the [Energy Imbalance Market] is viewed by many of the neighboring regions as [being designed] and built to benefit California consumers as opposed to everybody. And what we're saying is we can have a broad stakeholder process to say let's develop a slate of rules that work for all the customers and neighboring regions." Read Pro's Eric Wolff's interview with Ott here.

RENEWABLES FEAR A BEAT-DOWN: A new levy on multinational corporations included in the GOP's tax revamp -- known as the base erosion and anti-abuse tax, or BEAT -- is giving much of the tax world fits, including those who fund renewable energy projects and who aren't sure if they'll get hit by it, Pro Tax's Brian Faler reports. Companies must do some complicated calculations to see if they'll get hit by the BEAT and there's widespread confusion about how the specifics will work. "The BEAT is a disaster," Charles MacFarlane, head of Chevron's tax department said at a tax conference last month.

HAPPENING TODAY: Pruitt joins Vice President Mike Pence for an event promoting the recently enacted tax package with the pro-Trump outside group America First Policies today at 3:30 p.m. in Atlanta. Ethics officials cleared the appearance because 501(c)(4) organizations like America First Policies aren't considered partisan political groups for the purposes of the Hatch Act. More here.

WHY HAVE 18 SCIENTISTS WHEN YOU CAN HAVE 29? Pruitt appointed 11 new members on Thursday to the Science Advisory Committee on Chemicals, joining the 18 members appointed in January 2017 who provide independent advice on chemicals' risk and approaches to regulation. Among the new appointees: a scientist from Noble Energy, Inc., the Army's top toxicologist and a researcher from the Silent Spring Institute that focuses on links between chemicals and breast cancer. The agency said it was adding the new members "to be consistent with statutory requirements" that require the committee have representatives who offer diverse perspectives.

THEY WANT TO BREAK FREE: With Sen. Dean Heller scoring a victory by keeping Yucca Mountain nuclear repository funding out of the omnibus, Rep. Shimkus is urging the Nevada Republican to drop his hold on GOP Nuclear Regulatory Commission nominee Annie Caputo. "In all reality, Dean Heller has got a win and that should be enough to help him start moving these nominees," Shimkus said. "We got to have an operating NRC. We can't not have that."

SPEAKING OF FIRE: House Natural Resources Chairman Rob Bishop isn't thrilled with omnibus provisions fundamentally altering how the federal government funds fighting forest fires. "I'm extremely disappointed in what was in there and it does not solve the problem," he told ME. Bishop argued many important reforms were left out of the final package due to objections from East Coast Senate Democrats. "I don't blame Western Democrat senators. [Senate Energy ranking member Maria] Cantwell tried but was not heard," Bishop said. "We need a forest fire in [Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer's] damn tunnel in New Jersey so he understands what this issue is."

That criticism comes despite the praise of conservation and forestry groups, as well as a number of Western lawmakers. "Common sense has finally prevailed when it comes to how the Forest Service pays to fight record-breaking forest fires that devastate homes and communities in Oregon and the West," Sen. Ron Wyden said in a statement.

JUDGES TO WEIGH FEDERAL COAL LEASING PROGRAM'S CLIMATE IMPACT: The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals this morning will take up an environmentalist lawsuit seeking to force the Interior Department to re-do the environmental analysis for its decades-old coal leasing program to consider climate change. Not updating the "stale" 1979 review that guides Interior's broad process in order to incorporate greenhouse gas emissions violates the National Environmental Policy Act, the green groups argue. Interior, echoing a lower court's favorable ruling from 2015, says the leasing program's NEPA review is not a new and final agency action that can be challenged in court. Each individual leasing decision is subject to NEPA on its own anyway, including climate impacts, the agency added. The hearing is 9:30 a.m. at the Prettyman Courthouse, before Judges Karen LeCraft Henderson, Sri Srinivasan and Harry T. Edwards.

CORTEZ MASTO PRESSES PRUITT ON VEGAS LAB CLOSURE: Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto wants Pruitt to explain EPA's recent move to completely shut down operations at its Las Vegas laboratory. The move sent dozens of EPA workers and contractors, some of whom are adjuncts at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, scrambling, she wrote in a letter on Thursday. "As you are well aware, several of my constituents now have many life-changing decisions to make in a short timeframe that not only effects them, but their families, other professional commitments, as well as the outcome of their ongoing research efforts," Cortez Masto wrote.

LAWSUIT WATCH -- WAR OF ROSE (BOWL): Public Citizen, on behalf of an investigative journalist, filed a lawsuit under the Freedom of Information Act on Thursday seeking records of Pruitt's travel and attendance at the 2018 Rose Bowl. Read it here.

Try again: A group of conservation organizations filed a lawsuit Thursday challenging the Trump administration's issuance a waiver to speed construction of a border wall in New Mexico. A federal judge rejected similar legal arguments last month in California.

IMPERILED: After a year-and-a-half long feud with Michigan, the state of Ohio backed down Thursday and declared the western portion of Lake Erie impaired, Pro's Annie Snider reports. Both states, in conjunction with EPA, will now write a Total Maximum Daily Load -- essentially a pollution diet -- for Lake Erie.

MAIL CALL! Sens. Mark Warner and Gary Peters sent a letter urging the White House to appoint a director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. "We believe it is critical to appoint a well-qualified individual, with a background in science or engineering, to this role as soon as possible," they wrote.

MOVER, SHAKER: Kenneth Graham becomes the next director of NOAA's National Hurricane Center starting April 1 in Miami. He was previously meteorologist-in-charge of the National Weather Service's New Orleans office since 2008.

-- California water district rejects Cadiz Inc.'s proposed Mojave Desert water project. Desert Sun.

-- John McCain tells energy chief Rick Perry lawmakers will help him 'correct course' on waste. Washington Examiner.

-- Lawmakers press FEMA on restoring power to Puerto Rico. The Hill.

-- Saudi energy minister says Saudi Aramco could go public this year, but waiting for optimal time. CNBC.

-- Tennessee Tech board will oversee investigation into controversial emissions research. The Tennessean.

THAT'S ALL FOR ME!

** A message from Chevron: See how Chevron with local partners are helping DOERS get the hands-on technical training needed for jobs in the energy and manufacturing industries. Watch the video: http://politi.co/2Gtfesj **

results.title: OIG: Emanuel violated ethics pledge
results.body:
OIG: EMANUEL VIOLATED ETHICS PLEDGE: NLRB member William Emanuel violated President Donald Trump's ethics pledge when he participated in a December case involving a client of his former law firm, according to an Office of Inspector General report obtained by POLITICO. The 11-page report by IG David Berry chastised Emanuel for carelessness but acquitted the former management-side attorney of the most serious charge: lying to Congress or the OIG about whether he was aware of a possible conflict of interest.

The case at issue, December's Hy-Brand Industrial Contractors, narrowed the circumstances under which businesses can be held liable for violations committed by franchisees and contractors. Emanuel, appointed by Trump, was a key vote in the case, which overturned Browning-Ferris, an Obama-era decision that broadened the definition of "joint employment," making it easier to sue. In response to a written set of questions prior to his confirmation, Emanuel noted that his former law firm had been involved in Browning-Ferris. But in January, in response to questions from Democratic members of Congress, Emanuel said he didn't know that the firm had been involved in Browning-Ferris.

In reviewing Emanuel's email traffic, the IG concluded that Emanuel demonstrated a "genuine lack of recall" about his firm's connection to Browning-Ferris, even though he'd earlier informed Congress of it. Even so, the IG found that Emanuel clearly violated Trump's ethics pledge, which requires a two-year cooling off period for administration appointees. "The pledge obligates the subject to commit himself to not participate in particular matters involving the parties that are represented by Littler Mendelson," the report says. "Because of that commitment, the subject is not afforded the privilege to ignore or forget in what cases Littler Mendelson represents parties." An earlier IG report concluded that Emanuel should have recused himself from the decision to overturn Browning-Ferris and found "a serious and flagrant problem and/or deficiency" in the way the board handled conflicts of interest.

In response to the findings, House Education and the Workforce ranking member Bobby Scott (D-Va.) re-upped a call for hearing on the matter, saying in a statement late Thursday that Emanuel "has undermined the public's confidence in the Board's ability to protect workers' rights in an impartial manner." Read the full report here, and an earlier article by ProPublica on Emanuel here.

GOOD MORNING! It's Friday, March 23, and this is Morning Shift, POLITICO's daily tipsheet on employment and immigration policy. Send tips, exclusives and suggestions to thesson@politico.com, ikullgren@politico.com, ahanna@politico.com and tnoah@politico.com. Follow us on Twitter at @tedhesson, @AndrewBHanna, @IanKullgren and @TimothyNoah1.

WHAT'S NEXT FOR 'DREAMERS'?: The Senate approved a $1.3 trillion spending bill early this morning, H.R. 1625 (115), that devotes $1.6 billion to border security, including 95 miles of new and replacement fence and barriers along the U.S.-Mexico border. In addition, the legislation increases DHS funding levels by 13 percent compared with the enacted levels a year earlier, with similar spikes at the enforcement agencies.

What's not in the bill is any sort of codification of the DACA program, which offers work permits to young undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children. Both parties say they want to write DACA into law, but one (the GOP) demands steep concessions in return while the other (the Democrats) has grown weary of haggling.

"Trump himself made a last-minute push for a DACA deal in recent days," writes Seung Min Kim in the Washington Post. "The White House pitched $25 billion in border wall funding and three years of protections for current DACA permit holders, an estimated 690,000 young immigrants who had enrolled in the nearly six-year-old program. But Democrats rebuffed the offer, declining to agree to any temporary extension of DACA permits for only the current program enrollees. Democratic leadership countered with a plan to pair the $25 billion in border wall cash and a pathway to citizenship for a broader dreamer population of about 1.8 million immigrants. The administration rejected that approach, too. Trump was willing to accept a pathway to citizenship for the expansive pool of dreamers if he secured other significant immigration changes, not solely for the wall, one senior White House official said." More from the Post's Kim here.

When President Trump announced in September that he would phase out the program, he carved out a six-month window to find a legislative solution. A 9th Circuit ruling in January largely mooted the March 5 deadline by ordering the Trump administration to restart DACA renewals, but there was still some lingering hope that Congress would codify DACA in the omnibus spending bill sent to Trump's desk early Friday morning -- likely the last piece of major legislation Trump will sign before the midterm elections. Now that hope is dashed, leaving DACA's fate in the hands of the courts. Oral arguments in the 9th Circuit case will take place in May. Separately, a Brooklyn-based judge also blocked the DACA rescission in February, prompting an administration appeal to the 2nd Circuit.

"There's just a lot of different permutations about how the litigation efforts could unfold," says Marshall Fitz, managing director at the Emerson Collective. If the appeals courts allowed DACA termination to move forward, that could "create a new sense of urgency," he said. But would the Trump administration dare terminate DACA? That's hard to calculate without knowing how DACA will play in the midterms. DACA could play a role in House districts with a significant number of immigrant and Latino voters. But Senate Democrats in Trump Country may be wary of embracing undocumented immigrants of any kind. "I think it's going to be very localized and contextualized," Fitz said. Even so, Trump's September decision to terminate the program, Fitz said, could be used to mobilize progressive voters by fleshing out the theme that Trump "has systematically gone after and attempted to marginalize immigrants and refugees." Read more about the Senate omnibus vote from POLITICO here.

NLRB MOVES TO CLOSE HEALTH UNIT: The NLRB will dismantle its internal health service for employees in an effort to cut costs, the agency's union told Morning Shift. The health unit, housed at the national headquarters in Washington, D.C., is set to close at the end of March pending ongoing negotiations. The union representing NLRB employees called it an "unlawful, unilateral and premature" move. "Our nurse has saved lives by diagnosing people and sending them by ambulance to the hospital when they wouldn't otherwise have gone," said NLRB Professional Association President Karen Cook. The agency did not respond to a request for comment.

UNIONS PRAISE CHINA TARIFFS: The AFL-CIO lauded Trump's threat to impose tariffs on $50 billion worth of Chinese goods, a global shakeup that led the Dow Jones Industrial Average to fall more than 700 points on Thursday. The president said the tariffs were a response to China's improper efforts to obtain U.S. technology and would "make us a much stronger, much richer nation."

Trump found an ally in AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka, who said "[the] tariffs will put needed pressure on China to play fair." Teamsters President James Hoffa also applauded the move and urged the president to "fulfill his campaign promise" to label China a currency manipulator. Read more about the tariffs from POLITICO's Adam Behsudi here and the stock market reaction here.

BIDEN SIDES WITH ACOSTA AND IVANKA TRUMP: Occupational licensing reform inspired some rare bipartisan talk Thursday, with former Vice President Joe Biden, Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta, and first daughter Ivanka Trump all offering their thoughts at separate events. Biden -- speaking at a workforce development event at the Newseum -- criticized the "impediments we put in place" with too much licensing, especially for veterans trying to reenter the workforce. A little further up Pennsylvania Avenue, Acosta told a gathering at the White House that over-licensing stifles innovation. He used the example of a town that began licensing dog walkers in response to a new smartphone app. "Every time you see a new idea, there is a barrier to change," he said. Ivanka Trump backed up Acosta at the White House event. "It really is remarkable how insane it's become," she said. "It is disproportionately hurting those who can least afford it an pretty much put a ceiling on upward mobility." Ivanka also talked about the burden of licensing on military spouses (more than 90 percent of whom are women) if they need to move from place to place.

Don't get too excited, though. The Obama administration made no secret of its opposition to occupational licensing that it deemed excessive. And since occupational licenses are regulated at the state and local level, there's not much opportunity for meaningful bipartisan legislation on the problem.

DOES BLS NEED A RAISE?: Near-flat funding levels at the Bureau of Labor Statistics over the past decade have put the agency "on the path to irrelevance and operational failure," Erica Groshen, a former commissioner during the Obama administration, told Morning Shift. The omnibus spending bill would increase BLS funding by $4 million, but Groshen said that's far from sufficient. "If you had adjusted the 2009 budget for inflation... in 2019, you'd be getting something like $715 million," she said. Instead, the omnibus bill designates only $612 million.

The federal government relies on BLS for employment data, IRS calculations, and the inflation index. "If BLS makes one tenth of a percentage point mistake in the [Consumer Price Index], the federal government is going to overpay or underpay beneficiaries by a billion dollars," Groshen said. The bureau has cut programs and left vacancies open longer to economize, but weak funding puts the future of the agency in jeopardy, Groshen said, delaying IT modernization and other initiatives.

REPORT: IBM TARGETED OLDER WORKERS: IBM "eliminated more than 20,000 American employees ages 40 and over" in the past five years, according to an estimate from ProPublica's Peter Gosselin and Ariana Tobin -- "about 60 percent of its estimated total U.S. job cuts during those years." Gosselin's and Tobin's investigation probes IBM's strategy to "correct seniority mix" to better compete with other tech companies.

"In making these cuts, IBM has flouted or outflanked U.S. laws and regulations intended to protect later-career workers from age discrimination, according to a ProPublica review of internal company documents, legal filings and public records, as well as information provided via interviews and questionnaires filled out by more than 1,000 former IBM employees," the outlet reports. One finding: Big Blue "encouraged employees targeted for layoff to apply for other IBM positions, while quietly advising managers not to hire them and requiring many of the workers to train their replacements." More here.

TRUMP GOLF COURSE SEEKS GUEST WORKERS: "The Trump National Golf Club in Westchester County, New York, is once again seeking permission to bring in foreign workers to serve as waiters, waitresses and cooks," BuzzFeed News reports, citing petitions posted on the Labor Department website this week. The club wants to hire 10 waiters and four cooks through the H-2B visa program, which is available to businesses seeking seasonal, non-agricultural workers.

"The fancy private club is located just 35 miles from New York City and its vast labor market," BuzzFeed News writes. "The petition to the Labor department effectively attests that there are no qualified American workers who want the jobs. The cooking jobs pay $14.36 an hour. The serving jobs pay $15.20 an hour. Both jobs are eligible for overtime."

Trump-owned or -branded businesses have hired more than 400 guest workers since he started his presidential campaign, according to BuzzFeed. The H-2B visa program typically offers 66,000 visas annually, but the spending bill approved by the Senate this morning would renew a provision that allows the DHS secretary to approximately double the number of available visas this fiscal year. Read more from BuzzFeed here.

EOIR GETS A BUMP: The spending bill would increase funding for the federal immigration courts by 15 percent over enacted levels the previous year -- a nod to the Trump administration's attempt to reduce a massive case backlog. The money would pay for 100 new immigration judge "teams," but it's not clear how many judges are in that tally (the administration asked for 75 judges and associated positions in its fiscal year 2018 budget request). The immigration court backlog stands at nearly 668,000 cases, according to the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse at Syracuse University. The Senate Appropriations Committee summarized the spending bill's funding for the Executive Office for Immigration Review here.

CALLS FOR INVESTIGATION OVER ICE RESIGNATION: A dozen Senate Democrats sent a letter Thursday to the DHS Office of Inspector General that requests an investigation into the resignation of James Schwab, a spokesperson for U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement in California. Schwab told the San Francisco Chronicle that he quit earlier this month because he "didn't want to perpetuate misleading facts." In particular, he said he was frustrated that administration officials said roughly 800 undocumented immigrants escaped arrest because Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf publicized an ICE operation before it could take place.

Sens. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) and Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) spearheaded the call for a DHS watchdog investigation. "We have serious concerns that Trump administration officials are misrepresenting the facts and statistics surrounding this enforcement action for political purposes," they wrote. Read the letter here.

DEATH BY A THOUSAND EMAILS: A new book by Stanford professor Jeffrey Pfeffer argues that workplace stress is the fifth leading cause of death in the United States, and also increases healthcare costs. The book, "Dying for a Paycheck," centers on "a 2015 paper that said more than 120,000 deaths a year and roughly 5 to 8 percent of annual health care costs may be attributable to how U.S. companies manage their workforces," Jena McGregor writes in the Washington Post.

"A core argument: Instead of adding wellness programs or yoga classes," the Post reports, "companies need to focus more on the management practices that lead to substantial health issues, such as layoffs, job insecurity, toxic cultures and long hours -- not only for their own bottom lines but so they don't offload those costs to broader society." Read more from the Post here and find the book here.

MICHAELS ON DUPONT INCIDENT: David Michaels, Obama's OSHA administrator, published an article earlier this week in Harvard Business Review in which he recalled the failure of DuPont to make its facilities safer. "I watched with concern as the company, under pressure from activist shareholders to increase profits, cut costs and let its safety program deteriorate," he writes. "Needed repairs and upgrades were delayed, worker training postponed, and risk assessments overlooked. The culmination was an incident at an insecticide plant in LaPorte, Texas, where, as a result of a basic process safety management failure, an extremely toxic chemical -- methyl mercaptan -- was released and two workers were overcome. With inadequate equipment, others rushed in to save their colleagues. In all, four workers were killed." More here.

USCIS TESTS NEW WEBPAGE: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services on Thursday launched a redesigned webpage to track processing times for various forms. The reworked tool "displays the data for all forms in an easier-to-read format and also tests a new way of collecting data and calculating the processing times for some forms," according to USCIS. Take a look here.

COFFEE BREAK:

-- "More companies teach workers what colleges don't," from the Wall Street Journal

-- "Fed's mission improbable: lift unemployment -- but avoid recession," from the Wall Street Journal

-- "'Proxy for U.S. layoffs remains low," from the Wall Street Journal

-- "Hispanic Dems probe immigration agency on internal oversight division," from the Hill

results.title: China puts U.S. steel, pork and wine in the crosshairs
results.body:
With help from Adam Behsudi and Sabrina Rodriguez

CHINA PUTS U.S. STEEL, PORK AND WINE IN THE CROSSHAIRS: Beijing is firing back against U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs by considering raising duties on $3 billion worth of U.S. exports ranging from steel to pork. The action against 128 types of U.S. products is just the first response from the Asian economic giant. Still to come is how Beijing responds to the even bigger and China-focused Section 301 action under which the Trump administration is expected to slap tariffs on $50 billion worth of Chinese imports.

The U.S. imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum in the name of protecting national security. China says it doesn't buy that argument and is treating the U.S. tariffs as a safeguard action. That gives Beijing the leeway to follow a process sanctioned by World Trade Organization rules that allows a country, after a period of consultation, to seek compensation for another country's trade restrictions. It also gives China the ability to claim it is staying within the bounds of international rules.

China's "compensation" list includes 128 products split among two groups. The first group of exports, worth nearly $1 billion, includes 120 tariff lines covering fresh fruit, dried fruits and nuts, wine, modified ethanol, American ginseng and seamless steel pipes, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce said in a media release. Those products will face a 15 percent tariff.

China is considering a 25 percent tariff on a second group of eight different product categories, valued at nearly $2 billion total, covering pork, recycled aluminum and other items, according to an informal translation of the ministry's statement.

The National Pork Producers Council was quick to raise the alarm after the news broke. "We sell a lot of pork to China, so higher tariffs on our exports going there will harm our producers and undermine the rural economy," NPPC President Jim Heimerl said in a statement. More from Pro Trade's Adam Behsudi here.

IT'S FRIDAY, MARCH 23! Welcome to Morning Trade. Guess what Sen. Orrin Hatch got for his birthday yesterday? Tariffs on Chinese technology goods! Not really, but his Senate Finance Committee colleagues did take time out from yesterday's hearing to sing "Happy Birthday," much to Hatch's embarrassment. The Utah Republican explained he doesn't really celebrate birthdays. "It's a crazy psychological thing," he said. Hey, we can relate. Any trade news? Send it my way: dpalmer@politico.com.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers depend on free trade to export more than $100 billion of products annually. With farm incomes declining, exports help keep farms and rural communities afloat. But some in Washington support restrictive trade policies that would be devastating. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade. Learn more here. **

TRUMP THREATENS TO VETO SPENDING BILL: President Donald Trump tweeted early today that he is "considering a VETO" of the $1.3 trillion spending bill, hours after it cleared Capitol Hill by virtue of a 65-32 vote in the Senate. Trump said the legislation does not address DACA recipients and does not fully fund his proposed border wall.

The White House had previously reassured lawmakers that Trump would sign the omnibus measure, which must pass to avoid a government shutdown that would start on Saturday. Capitol Hill was unprepared for the threat, as members of the House and Senate were scattering across the country as Congress heads into a two-week recess.

CHINA READY TO GO TO THE MATTRESSES: If the rhetoric indeed meets reality, the U.S.-China trading relationship could be looking at an even wilder ride after Trump announced Thursday that he would hit Beijing with tariffs and investment restrictions in response to China forcing U.S. companies to give up technology and other intellectual property. As expected, China didn't shy from a strong response.

"China does not want a trade war with anyone," the Chinese Embassy said in a two-page statement. "But China is not afraid of and will not recoil from a trade war. China is confident and capable of facing any challenge. If a trade war were initiated by the U.S., China would fight to the end to defend its own legitimate interests with all necessary measures."

The Chinese government also called the administration's actions "self-defeating" because they would harm U.S. consumers, companies and financial markets.

"We urge the U.S. to cease and desist, make cautious decisions, and avoid placing China-U.S. trade relations in danger with the purpose of hurting others that eventually end up hurting itself," the embassy said.

A 301 ACTION TIMELINE: The proclamation signed by Trump sets in motion a number of timelines for the U.S. Trade Representative's Office and the Treasury Department to act on the three-pronged attack against China. The actions are in response to the findings of a 200-page USTR report that found evidence of China coercing U.S. companies to hand over valuable technology.

Tariffs: The administration has already calculated that annual damage to U.S. companies as a result of forced technology tops $50 billion. The White House said it will impose a 25 percent tariff on an equivalent value of Chinese imports. Within 15 days of Trump's announcement, USTR will release a proposed product list, which will be subject to a 30-day notice and comment period. Still unclear is how long USTR will take to finalize the list once it concludes the public process.

Investment restrictions: The Treasury Department is already hard at work trying to figure out how exactly it will restrict Chinese investment. The memorandum directs Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin to report back to Trump on that process 60 days after Thursday.

WTO case: USTR will also start the process of launching a WTO case challenging China's allegedly discriminatory licensing practices. Lighthizer will be required to report progress on the case 60 days after Thursday.

ICYMI, read the story on Thursday's China actions here.

BUSINESS ROUNDTABLE CRITICIZES TRUMP'S CHINA TACTICS: Trump's decision to threaten to impose tariffs on at least $50 billion worth of Chinese goods could backfire badly on the United States without solving any of the underlying problems that prompted the move, Joshua Bolten, president and CEO of the Business Roundtable, told Morning Trade.

"Pressure from the U.S. alone is unlikely to succeed, said Bolten, who served as White House chief of staff to President George W. Bush from 2006 to 2009. "It's most likely to result in punishment of U.S. companies to the benefit of our European, Japanese, and other competitors." The Trump administration is right that Chinese intellectual property theft, forced technology transfer and related concerns are serious problems, but they don't appear to have a "coherent strategy" to get China to change, he said.

"What you need to do is put together the list of specific actions you want the Chinese to take, in what time frame, with what consequence will occur if they do not. Line up your allies for support in that and then sit down with the Chinese and have a serious negotiation. It is frustrating, very hard work, but that is the work of trade diplomacy that needs to be done. It does not do any good to just shoot first and hope the other guys understand what they need to do," he said.

U.S. BUSINESSES WITH CHINA STAKES STRIKE CAUTIOUS TONE: As the administration considers what products to hit with tariffs, U.S. business groups that represent firms operating in China are urging caution.

"American business wants to see solutions to these problems, not just sanctions such as unilateral tariffs that may do more harm than good," U.S.-China Business Council President John Frisbie said in a statement. "We urge the two governments to engage in results-oriented dialogue to bring about real, positive change."

The Semiconductor Industry Association, which represents U.S. companies that have major investments in China, encouraged "an outcome that protects U.S. intellectual property in a manner that avoids a costly trade conflict."

The aerospace industry, which the administration is trying to protect through the tariffs, could also see blowback as China could retaliate by dropping its orders for hundreds of Boeing commercial aircraft. Boeing remained mum on Thursday's announcement but another industry titan, Lockheed Martin, was front and center as company CEO Marillyn Hewson accepted the pen Trump used to sign the memorandum.

The industry's trade group, the Aerospace Industries Association, highlighted state-sponsored cyber threats and IP theft as national security issues. "We look forward to working with the administration to determine strategic and effective deterrents and countermeasures," an AIA spokesman told Morning Trade.

LABOR GROUP RALLIES BEHIND TARIFFS: Richard Trumka, president of the AFL-CIO labor federation, welcomed Trump's latest actions, which he said would "put needed pressure on China to play fair" if the administration works in coordination with allies and is committed to comprehensive trade reforms. "Discussions and strongly worded letters have not stopped the IP theft or unfair tactics. Tariffs, investment restrictions and a WTO case might. Tariffs aren't an end goal, but an important tool to end trade practices that kill American jobs and drive down American pay," Trumka said.

SENATORS PLAN BEIJING SWING: The same day the White House ratcheted up a retaliation-inducing trade action against China, a group of Republican senators from farm states announced their plans to travel to China and South Korea.

The trip has been in the works for the past six months, but Trump's announcement could sharpen their focus on addressing China trade issues. The lawmakers who will make the trip include Sens. Chuck Grassley, Steve Daines, Ron Johnson, David Perdue and Ben Sasse.

"Today, the president announced a series of tariffs on China in response to concerns over the country's trade practices," the lawmakers said in a joint statement. "Given this announcement, we look forward to engaging in strategic discussions about how best to ensure free and smart trade."

The senators said they would prioritize in discussions with Chinese leaders the four main concerns the administration raised in its Section 301 investigation. Those include forced technology transfers, discriminatory licensing restrictions, state-supported acquisition of advanced technologies and cyber intrusions aimed at stealing intellectual property.

TRUMP TEMPORARILY EXEMPTS EU, 4 OTHER ALLIES FROM STEEL, ALUMINUM TARIFFS: U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer confirmed on Thursday that the U.S. would temporarily exempt the European Union, Australia, Argentina, Brazil and South Korea from steel and aluminum tariffs that went into effect early today.

The president "has decided to pause the imposition of the tariffs with respect to those countries," Lighthizer told lawmakers at a Senate Finance Committee hearing.

Trump made it official late Thursday night by issuing a proclamation saying the tariffs would be delayed for those allies until May 1 to give Lighthizer time to negotiate agreements with each trading partner to address U.S. national security concerns in some manner. The proclamation also covers Mexico and Canada, which Trump previously said would be temporarily exempt. Duties on other steel and aluminum exporters, such as China, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates and Japan, took effect shortly after midnight.

The tariffs have infuriated long-standing allies, many of whom threatened harsh retaliatory measures against U.S. products. Trump initially announced that he would exempt Canada and Mexico, pending the outcome of the NAFTA renegotiation. The U.S. imports the majority of its steel from Canada, Brazil, South Korea and Mexico.

The Business Roundtable's Bolten said that he was encouraged by the decision to exempt the allies, even if it's only temporary. "By our calculation that means that two-thirds of steel and 54 percent of aluminum imports will not be affected by the tariffs," he said. The remaining tariffs are still "a big mistake, but it's a smaller mistake than it was two weeks ago." Pro Trade's Sabrina Rodriguez has more.

CHINA TARIFFS STRIKE FEAR IN AGRICULTURE: U.S. farmers and members of the administration fully expect that agricultural exports will bear the brunt of retaliatory measures now that Trump has announced his tariffs on Chinese goods. China's decision to slap tariffs on pork, fruit and wine in response to Trump's steel and aluminum duties only adds to farmers' fears that commodity crops like soybeans, corn and wheat could be next.

Retaliation caused by Trump's China crackdown "will cost many farmers their livelihoods," said John Heisdorffer, president of the American Soybean Association.

The Trump administration has previously acknowledged the negative effects that its tariff actions could have for agriculture, but has not specified how it will help combat retaliatory efforts. Ray Starling, special assistant to the president for agriculture, trade and food assistance, said on Wednesday that the White House would deal with any retaliatory measures against U.S. farmers on a "case-by-case basis, as those threats materialize."

American farmers will have to concentrate on diversifying their markets to help support prices and minimize any damages that come from retaliation, said Tom Sleight, president of the U.S. Grains Council. "We are well aware this work will be an uphill battle because our reputation as a reliable supplier has come into question," he said.

ROSS TRIES TO SOOTHE FEARS: Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross was also on Capitol Hill on Thursday, trying to reassure members of the House Ways and Means Committee that U.S. manufacturers and farmers wouldn't get more than a few minor bruises as a result of Trump's trade actions. "I believe the actual outcome of all this will be far less severe than things that people are worried about," Ross told the largely skeptical panel.

GOP Rep. Sam Johnson, a World War II veteran and one of the oldest members of Congress, told Ross that he thought the administration's premise for imposing the tariffs was completely bogus.

"There's simply nothing to suggest that these imports pose a risk to national security. Instead these tariffs pose a serious risk to our economy, they could trigger a trade war and they could damage our relations with key allies," the Texas lawmaker said. However, the growing list of country exemptions likely reduces some of those concerns. To read Doug Palmer's full story on the hearing, click here.

LIGHTHIZER: NEW TRADE AGREEMENTS COMING SOON: USTR will begin consulting with the Trump administration and Congress as soon as next week to determine which countries the U.S. should pursue new free trade agreements with, Lighthizer said.

"If I have my way, it's not going to be a five-year negotiation," Lighthizer told Senate Finance lawmakers Thursday. "It's going to be a focused negotiation, where we get something very quickly for agriculture as well as other parts of the U.S. economy and increase exports."

The Trump administration has previously expressed an interest in exploring bilateral deals with the remaining Trans-Pacific Partnership countries, like Japan and Vietnam, but has said it will take time as the 11 countries are in the process of ratifying and implementing the recently signed deal.

GUAJARDO MET WITH LIGHTHIZER (AGAIN): Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo met with Lighthizer on Thursday afternoon to discuss progress on the NAFTA renegotiation, Mexican newspaper Reforma reported. Guajardo was accompanied by Mexico's chief NAFTA negotiator, Kenneth Smith Ramos, deputy chief negotiator Salvador Behar Lavalle and Mexican Ambassador Ger√≥nimo Guti√©rrez.

USTR and Mexico's Economy Ministry did not release details on the meeting. However, both trade leaders specified at the end of the seventh round of talks in Mexico City earlier this month that they would be speaking and meeting frequently over the next five weeks before the next round. The eighth round of talks is expected to be held in the second week of April in the Washington area, but officials have yet to publicly confirm those dates.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

-- The GOP's revamp of the tax code created a new levy on multinational corporations, known as the base erosion and anti-abuse tax, or BEAT, that some critics say violates WTO agreements, POLITICO Pro reports.

-- Ross says U.S. hopes steel, aluminum tariffs will spur global action on overcapacity, POLITICO Pro reports.

-- Brady calls for steel, aluminum tariffs to sunset in 1 year, POLITICO Pro reports.

-- Stocks tumble to worst day in six weeks after Trump tariff action, Reuters reports.

THAT'S ALL FOR MORNING TRADE! See you again soon! In the meantime, drop the team a line: abehsudi@politico.com and @abehsudi; mcassella@politico.com and @mmcassella; dpalmer@politico.com and @tradereporter; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny. Also follow us @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Trade.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers are the most productive in the world. Our farmers and ranchers exported more than $129 billion worth of products in 2016, accounting for 20% of all farm revenue in the U.S. Agricultural exports also support more than one million American jobs - most of them in the nonfarm sector. These jobs provide stability for rural families and communities. Free trade is essential to maintaining the strength of our agriculture economy. But some in Washington now support policies that would restrict trade. That would be devastating to family farms across the country, and would cause higher prices for consumers. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade to keep our agriculture economy strong. Learn more here. **

results.title: White House lawyer McGahn eager to exit
results.body:
The departure would come amid a shakeup of Trump's legal team for the Russia probe.

President Donald Trump's top White House lawyer, Don McGahn, is expected to step down later this year, though his resignation is contingent on the president finding a replacement and several other factors, according to four sources familiar with McGahn's thinking.

McGahn, according to two of the sources, has signaled interest in returning to the Jones Day law firm where he previously worked and reprising a role he had during the 2016 campaign by handling legal matters for Trump's re-election.

But the exact timing for McGahn to make any move remains in flux. He's told associates he'd like to leave the White House by the summer, but it could also be put on hold through the 2018 midterms.

Concerned about the velocity of turnover inside his White House and beyond -- Trump personal lawyer John Dowd resigned on Thursday, and the president has made changes atop the State Department, CIA and the national security adviser slot -- sources said Trump wants to have a new White House counsel in place who he's comfortable with before clearing McGahn for the exits.

"I think it's all up in the air," said a source close to McGahn. "I think he'd like to quit very much. The president doesn't want him to quit. The president wants him to stay. I don't think he knows who will replace him."

McGahn, a former Federal Election Commission member, was one of Trump's earliest political advisers, signing on even before the Republican announced his presidential campaign in the spring of 2015.

As White House counsel, McGahn has played a prominent but controversial role shepherding Trump's Cabinet picks through confirmation, as well as notching lifetime appointments for 29 federal judges, including Supreme Court Associate Justice Neil Gorsuch. McGahn has also been central to the reversal of myriad Obama-era policy regulations dealing with the environment and energy, health care, financial services and other industrial sectors.

"He can look at his first 14 to 16 months and say he's probably had a pretty good run," said a second McGahn associate.

A third McGahn associate said his departure also may hinge on whether there's another opening for Trump to fill on the Supreme Court -- an impossible-to-predict scenario but one that could present a unique legacy opportunity for the White House counsel. "I think if we had a possibility of getting another Supreme Court justice, I think he'd hang in," the source said.

A White House spokesman declined comment. McGahn did not respond to requests for comment about his job plans or a potential return to Jones Day, where he was paid an annual salary of $2.4 million as a partner before joining government, according to a 2017 financial disclosure form filed with the Office of Government Ethics.

McGahn's departure would also free him from some of the daily turmoil associated with playing a prominent role in special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation.

The White House counsel told the president in January 2017 that then-national security adviser Michael Flynn had misled both the FBI and Vice President Mike Pence about his interactions with the Russian ambassador to the U.S., which led to Flynn's firing.

On Trump's orders, McGahn tried without success last March to stop Attorney General Jeff Sessions from recusing himself from the whole probe. McGahn also had a role in last May's firing of FBI Director James Comey. And Trump tried to get McGahn in June to press the Justice Department to examine potential grounds for firing Mueller.

McGahn ignored the president's requests, telling then-White House chief of staff Reince Priebus and then-senior strategist Steve Bannon that he'd resign if the president didn't stop asking him about the issue.

The Russia portfolio shifted out of McGahn's hands last summer with the arrival of Ty Cobb, whose daily responsibilities included White House document production and lining up current aides to meet with Mueller for interviews.

But Cobb and McGahn still clashed over whether Trump should be so cooperative with the special counsel. McGahn urged the president to assert executive privilege on some documents being sought, but Trump followed Cobb's counsel and did not block any document production, according to sources familiar with the president's legal strategy.

McGahn has met on at least two occasions for interviews with Mueller's prosecutors. During a recent visit he shared details about the president's reaction to a January New York Times story that described how McGahn had resisted his order to fire Mueller.

Trump denied that he'd made any such request and asked then-White House staff secretary Rob Porter to get McGahn to issue a statement disputing the article. If McGahn refused, Trump told the aide that he could be fired.

The Trump and McGahn relationship is by many accounts a complicated one. Two sources said they speak infrequently. Another noted that McGahn remains close to White House chief of staff John Kelly and that Trump does indeed rely on his top counsel.

"It's hard to explain, but I think [Trump] values Don and his advice, and part of it isthat Don is probably one of the only people who's ever said 'no' to him," one of the McGahn associates said.

A list of candidates to replace McGahn remains a work in progress.

Several elite attorneys, including former George W. Bush solicitor general Ted Olson, Robert Giuffra Jr. and Reid Weingarten, declined job offers from Trump last spring to work on his Russia response. Former George W. Bush attorneys Bill Burck and Emmet Flood also rejected overtures for the position that Cobb accepted to work in the White House.

Flood subsequently met with the president earlier this month at the White House, though it's unclear if that has led to a job offer. Another name mentioned this week by a source close to Trump: Jay Clayton, the current chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Said one former senior White House lawyer, "Coming in now, it would take a brave soul."

results.title: Trump threatens to veto spending bill, risking shutdown
results.body:
President Donald Trump yanked the government back to the brink of a shutdown on Friday morning with a tweet threatening "a VETO" of a $1.3 trillion spending bill that Congress had cleared just hours earlier.

Trump's declaration of a possible veto -- citing the spending bill's lack of full funding for his border wall and attention to undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers -- comes as many lawmakers who would have to override his rejection or pass a stopgap funding measure are already on the way out of Washington for a two-week recess. The president's top aides said Thursday he would sign the bill, but his threat was a reminder that only Trump truly knows what the White House is doing at any time.

Trump's tweet caught many in the West Wing and on Capitol Hill by surprise, sending them scrambling to determine how serious he is about vetoing the bill, while White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders added a Friday afternoon briefing. Illustrating the degree to which Trump had upended his own staff once again, one West Wing official said on Friday morning that the likelihood of a shutdown is "extremely high."

There remains hope in the White House that the defense community, including Secretary of Defense James Mattis -- who is slated to meet with Trump on Friday -- could convince Trump that whatever stopgap spending agreement results from a shutdown threat would not deliver the high level of defense spending provided by the omnibus.

But Trump's frustration is severe, the West Wing official said. The president has been concerned by conservative outcry on Fox News, about the amount provided for the border wall and interior enforcement and the way in which Amtrak funding is being framed as a victory for Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.).

In fact, both Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill had joined White House aides on Thursday in touting gains for both parties in the spending deal, which the Senate approved on a 65-32 vote after midnight on Friday morning.

"Ask Republicans. It's their problem," one senior Democratic aide said of the veto tweet. "He's just trying to get a reaction from Democrats over something that's demonstrably false."

But fiscal conservatives in Congress who had opposed the spending package urged Trump to follow through with the veto threat, concerned over the bill's high price tag bloating the debt.

"Please do, Mr. President. I am just down the street and will bring you a pen. The spending levels without any offsets are grotesque, throwing all of our children under the bus. Totally irresponsible," tweeted Sen. Bob Corker of Tennessee.

Trump's frustrations with the bill were well-known in the White House, but West Wing aides and members of Congress believed they had convinced the president to go along with the measure.

The White House released a statement Thursday saying the administration supports passage of the bill and it declared in a separate statement that the legislation is a "win for the American people."

"Let's cut right to the chase. Is the president going to sign the bill? Yes. Why? Because it funds his priorities," White House Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney told reporters on Thursday, while acknowledging the final product was imperfect.

results.title: Conway on W.H. communication job speculation: 'I will do whatever is best'
results.body:
Counselor to the president Kellyanne Conway left open the possibility on Friday that she could become the next White House communications director, telling Fox News that she will fulfill "whatever my best and highest use is here."

"I'm here to support the president however he sees is most important. I don't have any personnel announcements at this time," she told "Fox & Friends" in response to a question about talk that she might fill the soon-to-be-vacant communications director post. "I will do whatever is best, whatever my best and highest use is here."

The position of White House communications director has been a particularly quickly revolving door since President Donald Trump took office last year. Trump has had four communications directors through his first 14 months in office, including former press secretary Sean Spicer, who held the job twice in his six months in the West Wing, and Anthony Scaramucci, who famously held the job for 11 days before resigning after an expletive-filled interview with The New Yorker.

The job of communications director was most recently filled by Hope Hicks, who held the position longer than any of her Trump administration predecessors. Hicks announced her resignation late last month, although the White House said at the time that her official departure date was yet to be determined but would be in the upcoming weeks.

While Conway has officially served in a policy-facing role as counselor to the president, she has remained one of the most public-facing members of the Trump administration, doing regular interviews on "Fox & Friends," where the president receives almost unflinchingly positive coverage, while also appearing on other TV networks, albeit less frequently.

She heaped praised Friday morning on the White House communications staff for its work and said that work on that team also requires the type of policy knowledge required by her current position.

"As counselor to the president, that takes on any number of different tasks and one has been in terms of policy. That's been my major portfolio here," she said. "But I think to be effective communication directors, as we've seen, you also have to know policy, you have to be read-in. But we have very talented people here."

THE BUZZ: -- ON THE ROAD Twelve hours in a Honda Odyssey with "The Former College Drop-out Who Would Be Dianne Feinstein,' by POLITICO's David Siders in Santa Ana:

-- Fourteen people and three rescue cats were awaiting Kevin de Le√≥n when he pulled up to a PetSmart and stepped inside through drizzling rain. In his briefing folder, an aide had included a note titled, "Cat puns you can use, if you're feeling festive!" De Le√≥n hit nearly all of them. "Meow is the time," he told the members of Kitty Devore Rescue, describing himself as an "alley cat." Grateful for de Le√≥n's attention, a woman beamed back at him, "Someone knows our name!"

-- "It had been two weeks since de Le√≥n impressed a crowd on a more brightly lit stage. In a coup at the California Democratic Party's annual convention last month, de Le√≥n -- until Wednesday the Democratic leader of California's state Senate -- deprived Dianne Feinstein of her own party's endorsement by outpolling the state's senior senator by 17 percentage points in the delegate vote. Although de Le√≥n fell short of the 60 percent threshold necessary to claim the party's backing himself, he embarrassed Feinstein and put a California institution on her heels.

-- "For de Le√≥n and his supporters, the convention marked a turning point not only in his quixotic campaign to unseat Feinstein, but also in a generational struggle among Democrats in the nation's most populous state. For decades, Feinstein and her centrist brand of politics have appeared as immovable as House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and California's fourth-term governor, Jerry Brown. For once, a restless, more progressive class of Democrats had unsteadied the establishment. De Le√≥n skewers Feinstein for her moderation and depicts her as unfit to battle President Donald Trump. He is also testing the muscle of the nation's newly emboldened left. Full story in POLITICO

PUSHBACK WHILE UNDER FIRE -- ASSEMBLYWOMAN CRISTINA GARCIA, who's under investigation for sexual harassment complaints, claims the #METoo label in a new video called "I stand with Cristina' which was posted this week on her Facebook campaign web page. But it make no mention of Garcia's current troubles: She's on leave and under investigation following a POLITICO report of sexual harassment claims -- including that she groped a young former legislative staffer, Daniel Fierro, following a legislative softball game, and that an inebriated Garcia made a lewd sexual suggestion and attempted to grope a Sacramento lobbyist at a political fundraiser in March 2017. results.title: Shutdown averted
results.body:
SHUTDOWN AVERTED! -- While you were (hopefully) sleeping, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell convinced his Kentucky colleague Rand Paul to drop his threat to drag things out through Saturday (and cause a brief shutdown) and the Senate passed the $1.3 trillion spending package at 12:39 a.m. by a vote of 65-32.

POLITICO's Burgess Everett has the details of the mini-drama: "[I]t was a tricky road to avoid a government shutdown, requiring ... McConnell to privately telephone Paul and let him vent about the Senate rules, then satisfy [GOP Sen.] James Risch's objections to a wilderness area being named after a dead Idaho governor.

"'This is ridiculous. This is juvenile,' fumed Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), who asked McConnell for an explanation of why the chamber was in at midnight. 'What has occurred over the last 11 hours that keeps us here voting on a bill that we all know is going to pass?'

TRUMP ROCKS MARKETS -- The era of Donald Trump's unusual approach to the presidency not spooking the stock market is over. Trump's announcement of $60 billion in new tariffs against China helped drive the Dow down over 700 points on Thursday.

It didn't help matters that Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross went on CNBC immediately after the announcement and said, sure, China is likely to retaliate and that could hurt our farmers and airplane exporters and everyone else who exports to the world's second largest economy. But it probably won't destroy the global economy.

"I think there will be some ultimate retaliation. But I don't think it's going to be the end of the earth," Ross said. That comment sent free traders inside the Trump administration over the edge with one asking MM, "Is that the new standard for U.S. policy? That it probably won't be the end of the world?"

The Dow is now off 10 percent since hitting its high point of the Trump presidency, 26,616 on Jan. 26 just before the era of neo-mercantilism began with the announcement of steel and aluminum tariffs. The S&P is off around 8 percent over that period. The Nasdaq is off around 5 percent.

It's not just Trump, of course. Markets are also worried that a potentially more hawkish Fed, rising inflation and profit margin erosion. But this new generalized vulnerability means that markets' ability to shake off Trump's erratic nature and protectionist approach is largely gone.

"What I've noticed is that market reaction to news now is far more aggressive every day than it would have been a year ago. This same kind of news a year ago wouldn't have done much at all," Leuthold Group's Jim Paulsen told me. "It's a situation where the market is more vulnerable, so interest rate news, or Trump news, or Facebook news is having much more impact."

Paulsen's outlook? It could get scarier before it gets better: "It could be that we get a very significant correction, and a scary one, and then we go back up and wind up mostly unchanged for the year. Or it could be that we just keep doing what we are doing since late January and just wind up going nowhere."

FLASH BACK -- Here's what I wrote a couple weeks back for POLITICO Magazine in a piece about why Trump's unusual presidency had not freaked out Wall Street. Seems about where we are now: "But there's another possibility: that Wall Street has it all wrong.

"If Trump really were the black swan he seemed on election night, it's possible that the kinds of risk he presents -- a constitutional crisis, a neomercantilist trade battle, even a nuclear war -- just aren't the kind of things that the markets can price in. And what I found is that some investors are wondering whether the market really is missing something, and that destabilizing moment might still be in our future." Read more.

WHAT THE TARIFFS WILL HIT -- Pantheon's Ian Shepherdson: "Yesterday's announcement that the administration plans to imposes tariffs worth about $60B per year -- that's 0.3% of GDP -- on an array of imports of consumer goods from China is a serious escalation. It's not quite a trade war, yet, but this is a much more serious engagement than the skirmishing over steel and aluminum.

"These tariffs, if fully implemented, will hit items as diverse as clothing, furniture, shoes, electronics and plastic products. People will notice, and the margins of importers, wholesalers and retailers will be squeezed. .. [M]aking U.S. consumers pay more for Chinese-made TVs, at a time when the U.S. is seeking help from China over North Korea, seems an unlikely mechanism for persuading China to change its behavior."

SPEAKING OF CHINA -- AP/Beijing: BEIJING (AP) - "China raises tariffs on U.S. pork, aluminum and other goods in response to Trump tariff hikes." This was about the aluminum and steel tariffs, not those aimed at China announced on Thursday.

Via the Chinese Embassy in DC: "China is not afraid of and will not recoil from a trade war. China is confident and capable of facing any challenge. If a trade war were initiated by the U.S., China would fight to the end to defend its own legitimate interests with all necessary measures."

MARKETS KEEP DROPPING -- Bloomberg: "Stocks tumbled round the world after ... Trump's slapped tariffs on China and Chinese policy makers took retaliatory steps of their own, sparking fears a trade war could hurt global growth. Treasuries extended gains and the dollar fell.

"Equity indexes from Tokyo to Shanghai tumbled well over 3 percent. U.S. stock futures also declined, signaling a further retreat for the S&P 500 Index after it closed down 2.5 percent, the most in six weeks. As investors dumped stocks, they rushed to the safety of Treasuries, where yields dipped below 2.8 percent, and the yen, which jumped past 105 per dollar for the first time since November 2016." Read more.

REMEMBER THE STEEL AND ALUMINUM TARIFFS? -- One argument for not freaking out about the China tariffs is that Trump has now removed much of the steel and aluminum tariffs. As of Thursday, the administration has now exempted Canada, Mexico, the EU, Australia, Argentina, Brazil and South Korea. The biggest steel and aluminum exporters to the U.S. are Canada, Brazil, South Korea and Mexico.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, U.S. Steel has given up all of its stock market gain since news of the tariffs first began to circulate. It dropped 11 percent on Thursday. Nucor has also lost all its tariff-related gains.

CITI TAKES ACTION ON GUNS -- POLITICO's Victoria Guida: "Citigroup Thursday announced a new policy aimed at pushing its clients to place restrictions on the sale of firearms, becoming the nation's first large lender to take action on guns.

"The move by Citigroup, the fourth-biggest U.S. bank by assets, comes two days before major nationwide rallies on gun control are scheduled to take place. The bank will require retail clients to only sell guns if the customer has passed a background check, to restrict sales to people under 21, and to refuse to sell bump stocks or high-capacity magazines." Read more.

DETAILS ON THE SPENDING SPREE -- POLITICO's Sarah Ferris: "A Republican-led Congress [passed] a mammoth spending bill that broadly rejects the Trump administration's attempts to downsize the federal government and even surpasses former President Barack Obama's requests.

"The $1.3 trillion bill, H.R. 1625 (115), is stuffed with new cash for programs that President Donald Trump and his Cabinet have protested -- national parks, renewable energy programs, the Army Corps of Engineers -- while delighting Democratic leaders. 'This spending agreement brings that era of austerity to an unceremonious end and represents one of the most significant investments in the middle class in decades,' Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer declared on the floor." Read more.

SHERYL SANDBERG SPEAKS -- Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg broke her silence and lamed in an interview with CNBC that she hadn't spoken out sooner on the data scandal roiling the social media giant: "This was a huge breach of trust. People come to Facebook every day and they depend upon us to protect their data and I am so sorry that we let so many people down. ...

"We definitely didn't realize the gravity of this issue sooner. ... Sometimes, and I would say certainly this past week, we speak too slowly. If I could live this past week again, I would have definitely had Mark and myself out speaking earlier, but we were trying to get to the bottom of this and make sure we could take strong action."

McMASTER OUT -- POLITICO's Cristiano Lima, Matthew Nussbaum and Andrew Restuccia: "President Donald Trump announced on Thursday that he would replace national security adviser H.R. McMaster with John Bolton, a former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, marking the latest high-level shake up in a White House that has seen unprecedented levels of turnover in Trump's first 14 months in office.

"McMaster's exit brings an end to his uneven tenure as leader of the NSC, marked by internal clashes with the president and other top administration officials and months of swirling speculation about his looming departure He never quite meshed with the president, aides say, and at times clashed with him on foreign policy matters." Read more.

WORLD'S WEALTHIEST LOSE $71B IN SELLOFF -- Bloomberg's Tom Metcalf and Jack Witzig: "The fortunes of the world's 500 richest people tumbled $71 billion on Thursday as markets plunged on heightened prospects for a trade war. Berkshire Hathaway Inc. Chairman Warren Buffet led with a $3.02 billion decline, followed by $3.01 billion for Amazon.com Inc.'s Jeff Bezos.

Tencent Holdings Ltd.'s Ma Huateng lost $2.16 billion, the most among Asia's richest. Just 52 of the world's 500 richest people added to their net worth on the day, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average sank more than 700 points, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. "On trade, 'We have one particular problem, and I view them as a friend. ... And that's China,' President Donald Trump said Thursday, adding that America has an 'out of control' trade deficit with the country. Mr. Trump made the announcement at the White House, where he signed a presidential memorandum that cites Section 301 of a 1974 U.S. trade law, a broad tool that allows unilateral actions against allegedly unfair trade policies abroad." And consumers could feel the impact -- AP's Christopher Rugaber: "White House officials say they will try to minimize any price increases for American shoppers. Instead, they suggested Thursday that the tariffs would mostly target products that businesses, rather than consumers, buy: Computers, information technology products, industrial machinery and aircraft parts. 'If they had done it on clothing, footwear and iPhones, that would have more of an immediate impact,' Chad Bown, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, said. The three largest U.S. banks by assets have added more than $2.4 trillion in domestic deposits over the past 10 years, a 180 percent increase, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of regulatory data. That amount exceeds what the top eight banks had in such deposits combined in 2007." Read more.

In an annual proxy filing after the market close on Wednesday, the biggest U.S. bank by assets said that its chairman and CEO was paid $28.3m last year, or 364 times the median employee, who received $77,799, including firm-paid benefits.

"Mr. Dimon's pay ratio of 364 times the median worker puts him second in the list for the big banks, according to Autonomous Research, behind Citigroup chief Mike Corbat, whose pay of $17.8m last year was 369 times the median worker. Charlie Scharf of Bank of New York Mellon, a prot√©g√© of Mr. Dimon who arrived at BNY in the summer of last year, ranks third, with a $20m package 354 times the average worker." Read more.

Warding off market cheaters in digital currencies is among the Securities and Exchange Commission's major concerns as it monitors those assets, according to Brett Redfearn, head of the regulator's Division of Trading and Markets. 'We are concerned about a lot of the issues around manipulation, whether it's spoofing, or any other forms of market manipulation that are out there,' he said Thursday at an event in New York. Just how much fintech firms are subject to federal oversight varies -- whether that's securities regulators, federal regulators, or even state regulators.

"This regulatory structure comes with its share of challenges, the GAO adds: "With numerous regulators, fintech firms noted that identifying the applicable laws can how their activities will be regulated can be difficult."
