results.title: What's in the omnibus for health care
results.body:
WHAT'S IN THE OMNIBUS -- The $1.3 trillion spending bill was posted last night, with Congress now rushing to pass it by Friday midnight. If they don't, prepare for a possible third government shutdown of the year.

-- $10 billion more for HHS. The agency overall would receive $88.1 billion in fiscal 2018, according to Senate appropriators, representing a $10.1 billion increase compared with fiscal 2017 levels.

-- More funding for research too. NIH would receive a nearly 9 percent bump to $37.1 billion -- including $100 million toward developing a universal flu vaccine. More for Pros.

CDC would receive $8.3 billion under the legislation, a $1.1 billion boost and a sharp departure from the nearly $900 million in cuts that the White House proposed last month. More for Pros.

Drilling down:

-- $4 billion to fight opioid crisis. The funding -- for prevention, treatment and law enforcement -- is spread across agencies including HHS, Homeland Security, Justice and Veterans Affairs. It represents a $3 billion increase over what lawmakers committed last year to addressing the addiction epidemic. More for Pros.

-- Bioterrorism, public health response efforts see major funding boosts. Efforts to stockpile drugs, vaccines and other efforts to shield the nation from possible bioterrorism or another public health emergency are all set to receive boosts in funding under the bill, H.R. 1625 (115), to fund the government through September. More for Pros.

-- More payment for a handful of new drugs. Less than two dozen products are estimated to benefit from the change in the omnibus that allows for five years of pass-through status actually limited to two years because the bill specifies that it only applies to drugs that lost pass-through status on Dec. 31, 2017 and for which payment was bundled into a group of services under Medicare policies beginning Jan. 1. More for Pros.

-- $335 million for CDC's workplace safety office. Congress rejected the Trump administration's proposed 41 percent cut to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health and also rebuffed the White House's attempt to move NIOSH out of the CDC. More for Pros.

-- More money for abstinence education. Lawmakers agreed to boost funding for abstinence education by two-thirds, to $25 million.

-- More info on ACA workers. The budget requires the Trump administration to publish information on the number of employees and contractors involved in "implementing, administering, enforcing, or otherwise carrying out" the Affordable Care Act.

MEANWHILE: WHAT WASN'T IN THE OMNIBUS

-- Congress nixed a series of anti-abortion riders, including a bill expanding conscience protections.

-- Congress rejected the White House's plan to gut drug policy office. The Trump administration had proposed a 95 percent cut to the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy. It was the second straight year that lawmakers have rebuffed the attempt to gut the office, which sets drug-fighting strategy across the government and is popular on the Hill.

-- Congress reiterated: No money for Obamacare's risk corridors. Once again, lawmakers prohibited money from being spent to make risk corridor payments to insurers. The program, which expired after 2016, was supposed to cushion the financial blow for insurers that attracted disproportionately expensive customers. Because Republicans required the program to be budget neutral, however, payments came up $12 billion short. Dozens of insurers have filed lawsuits to recover the funds.

** A message from PhRMA: There is currently no requirement that hospitals pass 340B program savings along to patients, and economists suggest 340B may actually contribute to higher out-of-pocket costs for patients. Let's fix the 340B program. http://politi.co/2IqKpF3 **

WHAT'S NEXT AFTER HOUSE PASSES RIGHT-TO-TRY -- The chamber in a party-line vote approved a bill designed to let very sick patients request access to experimental medicines without government oversight.

-- It's a victory for the Goldwater Institute and the White House. The small libertarian think tank crafted the proposal and the administration vigorously campaigned for the law. Meanwhile, it's a blow for the many policy wonks who opposed the idea, saying it would weaken patient protections. Many pharma companies also opposed the bill, whose benefits are not as straightforward as they may seem.

-- Up next: the Senate, which passed Sen. Ron Johnson's slightly different version of the legislation last summer under unanimous consent. The Wisconsin Republican said he plans to push for immediate passage of the House bill in the Senate, despite some disappointment that his version wasn't adopted.

-- What policy wonks are saying: They're critiquing the broader anti-regulatory health agenda pushed by the Goldwater Institute.

"I think this is the first step, for sure. Tear down as many regulations as possible, take away all oversight, and let it be the Wild West of medicine," said Andrew McFadyen of the rare disease patient group Isaac Foundation. Keep reading: More.

MEDICARE HONCHO: "DON'T WORRY" ABOUT PAYMENT REFORM EFFORTS -- CMS' No. 2, Demetrios Kouzoukas, tried to assure lawmakers that the Trump administration wasn't taking its foot off the gas in the move to value-based care, telling one member of Congress when pressed: "don't worry about that." Multiple Democrats expressed concern during a Ways and Means Committee hearing Wednesday that CMS was abandoning the bipartisan goal of changing the way health care is paid for.

"Our goal is to make sure the health care system ... is the one that's right for each patient," Kouzoukas told Rep. Ron Kind (D-Wis.), who asked about an Obama-era goal of having half of Medicare payments going to something other than fee-for-service by the end of this year. The Trump administration has backed off the goal, but Kouzoukas didn't acknowledge any sort of target on Wednesday.

ACOs HAVE BEEN "DISAPPOINTING" FOR NURSING HOMES -- Accountable care organizations have largely given the cold shoulder to nursing homes, despite their potential to reduce hospitalizations with a small amount of investment, David Gifford, senior vice present for quality and regulatory affairs at the American Health Care Association, said during a POLITICO Live event Wednesday. "They've not partnered with the post-acute side," Gifford said. "A handful have, and when they have, it's been really successful." Overall, hospitals and doctor practices view nursing homes as a cost, not a chance to save on money.

The nursing home community is in a "watchful waiting" mode to see where new HHS leadership will take the CMS Innovation Center, Tricia Neuman, head of Medicare policy at the Kaiser Family Foundation, said during the event. While acknowledging there are "nuggets [of ACOs] that are very promising," she said it's still too early to judge overall success.

View the full event here.

IT'S OFFICIAL: ROBERT REDFIELD TO RUN CDC -- The University of Maryland AIDS researcher was formally tapped by the Trump administration on Wednesday, five days after POLITICO scooped that he was favored to run the agency.

And that's not sitting well with some researchers, who issued a last-minute flurry of warnings despite Redfield's longtime prominence. "This appointment would be disastrous," warned Peter Lurie, head of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, citing Redfield's lack of public health leadership experience and "history of scientific misconduct." More. (While the Army acknowledged there were accuracy issues with Redfield's work on an HIV vaccine, they didn't find misconduct.)

-- But a slew of policy wonks and politicians, including Democrats, offered a character defense. "He is somebody who cares deeply about serving those who are sick and in need," said Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, Maryland's former lieutenant governor who served on the board of the Institute of Human Virology with Redfield. "He's very devoted to Catholicism, and I think that sense of social justice permeates his every fiber," Kennedy Townsend added, describing Redfield's work to combat AIDS in Africa.

Keep reading: More.

-- What HHS leadership is thinking: They were prepared for the criticism of Redfield, chalking some of it up to long-held disputes among researchers, according to an individual with knowledge of HHS leadership strategy.

But the administration is hoping that, like Scott Gottlieb -- who faced ample criticism over his industry conflicts before taking the helm of FDA, where he's won bipartisan kudos -- Redfield can win over critics by finding areas of consensus.

California: Lawmaker pushes bill to address "patient brokering" -- State Sen. Ricardo Lara today plans to introduce a bill, CA SB1228 (17R), that would require licensed recovery programs to refer patients to certified facilities. The goal: To crack down on low quality unlicensed sober-living homes, which have been known to pay addicts -- "junkie hunters" or "interventionists" -- to recruit new patients in a unsavory practice known as patient brokering.

"California needs to raise the bar for patient care and protect people in recovery from patient brokering, where quality care takes a backseat to profits and insurance fraud," said Lara, whose bill also requires certified recovery centers to have naloxone, the opioid overdose antidote marketed to consumers as Narcan nasal spray, available on site. California lawmakers have already introduced more than a dozen other bills this session to address the opioid crisis.

March of Dimes launches new Center for Social Science Research today. The collaborative between the patient advocacy group and EMD Serono, a division of Darmstadt, Germany-based Merck KGaA, aims to produce research that helps improve the health of mothers and children. More.

Judy Stecker set to officially join HHS. The incoming HHS communications head will officially leave her current role at the American Enterprise Institute on Friday, she wrote in an email, calling her departure "bittersweet."

Stecker will start transitioning into her duties as HHS assistant secretary for public affairs next week, according to people familiar with the plan, and take over full time on April 2. Michael Pratt, AEI's director of digital strategy, will take over as the think tank's director of media relations and marketing, Stecker wrote.

** A message from PhRMA: Created a quarter of a century ago, the 340B program is greatly in need of a number of fixes to ensure it is targeted toward true safety-net entities and vulnerable or uninsured patients as intended when the program was developed. Independent economists, GAO and OIG have all raised concerns with the program and Congress has now echoed those concerns. Too many hospitals are profiting off a program meant to support needy patients. Learn why now is the time to fix the 340B program and how members of Congress are leading the charge through new legislation. http://politi.co/2IqKpF3 **

results.title: Trump's China trade action opens the retaliation gates
results.body:
TRUMP'S CHINA TRADE ACTION OPENS THE RETALIATION GATES: President Donald Trump will make his highly anticipated move against China today, and U.S. trade officials are already anticipating retaliatory measures aimed at crucial export sectors like agriculture. Trump is scheduled to sign a memorandum at 12:30 p.m. "targeting China's economic aggression," according to his daily schedule.

"We've certainly given a great deal of thought to what they might do and how they might react," an official from the U.S. Trade Representative's Office told reporters Wednesday afternoon.

The fear of reprisal, however, is not deterring the move. During a House Ways and Means hearing on Wednesday, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said that taking no action to avoid retaliation is not an option.

"That's how you end up having an $800 billion trade deficit which costs literally millions and millions of jobs in America," he told lawmakers. "You have to think about counter-retaliation, you have to think about programs for farmers who are in this situation. I mean, there's a lot of things that are outside of my realm that have to be considered." Read the full story here.

IT'S THURSDAY, MARCH 22! Welcome to Morning Trade, where your host's mind is blown over the Peruvian president's resignation less than a month before the Summit of the Americas in Lima. Any ideas on what the protocol is here, or what to expect from Trump's first trip to Latin America? Send theories, news and tips my way: srodriguez@politico.com or @sabrod123.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers depend on free trade to export more than $100 billion of products annually. With farm incomes declining, exports help keep farms and rural communities afloat. But some in Washington support restrictive trade policies that would be devastating. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade. Learn more here. **

LIGHTHIZER GETS EARFUL; ROUND TWO TODAY: Many House Ways and Means Republicans took on Trump's trade policy during a hearing Wednesday with Lighthizer, expressing concern and frustration about its impact on farmers and manufacturers. The airing of Republicans' grievances will likely continue today when Lighthizer returns to Capitol Hill for a hearing before the Senate Finance Committee.

"Look, we've got wheat sitting on the ground in Kansas," Senate Agriculture Chairman Pat Roberts (R-Kan.), a member of the Finance Committee, told reporters Wednesday. "It's that rough. We really have a challenge here. We've got an uphill battle."

Mexico is usually a big buyer for U.S. wheat and corn. But with Trump threatening to withdraw from NAFTA, Mexico has turned to other suppliers like Argentina and Brazil, Roberts said. In addition, after more than a year in office, Trump has failed to deliver on promises to negotiate new bilateral agreements to open markets to U.S. exports, he said.

"We haven't seen any trade bill yet," Roberts said. "There's a lot of frustration out there -- when are we going to see a major or even a minor arrangement for any product -- we just haven't seen it. It's been what? 14 months. Some of the frustration is just obvious. ... We are in danger of losing our reputation as a reliable supplier. Once you lose that and they start making agreements with other folks, you're in a world of trouble."

To read Doug Palmer's recap of the House Ways and Means hearing, click here.

GSP MAKES IT INTO OMNIBUS, BUT NOT MTB: The massive omnibus spending bill (H.R. 1625) released late Wednesday contains a three-year renewal of the Generalized System of Preferences program that waives duties on thousands of goods from developing countries to promote economic development and jobs.

But a renewal of the Miscellaneous Tariff Bill, which waived duties on raw materials and intermediate goods used by U.S. manufacturers, didn't make the cut. That means the Senate would have to pass it separately to get it to Trump's desk, since it has already cleared the House. The last MTB expired in 2012, and efforts to renew the measure got tangled up in the House Republican ban on earmarks. That prompted a change in how Congress decided which tariff codes would be included in the legislation.

The GSP program expired at the end of December, costing importers $77 million in taxes in the month of January alone, according to the Coalition for GSP. However, any duties collected since Jan. 1 will now be reimbursed.

The omnibus also contains GSP reform championed by Rep. Jackie Walorski (R-Ind.). GSP rules restrict imports of a particular product to certain dollar and percentage amounts called "competitive need limitations." USTR may grant a CNL waiver under certain conditions, such as U.S. national security interests, no domestic production, or low total imports. Previously, a waiver on the grounds of no domestic production could only be granted if there was no production on Jan. 1, 1995. The reform now allows a waiver to be granted if there was no production during the previous three years.

EU OPTIMISTIC ON TARIFFS EXEMPTION AFTER ROSS, MALMSTR√ñM TALKS: Recent talks between Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross and European Commissioner for Trade Cecilia Malmstr√∂m went unexpectedly well, leaving EU officials optimistic that the trading bloc could be exempted from Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum. Two European Commission officials told POLITICO Europe that an exemption for the European Union was now within reach, and a third official said there was reason to be hopeful.

Ross and Malmstr√∂m agree to try for a speedy resolution: "We have agreed to launch immediately a process of discussion with President Trump and the Trump administration on trade issues of common concern, including steel and aluminum, with a view to identifying mutually acceptable outcomes as rapidly as possible," the two trade leaders said in a joint statement Wednesday.

Timing on exemptions: Lighthizer told the Ways and Means panel that the process for excluding countries from the tariffs should wrap up by the end of April. He added he's in discussions to potentially exempt the EU, Australia and Argentina, and expects to start talks with Brazil. However, he said Trump will have the final say over whether the trading bloc will be spared from the duties, which take effect on Friday.

LIGHTHIZER HOPES FOR KORUS DEAL SOON: The United States and South Korea are close to a deal on revamping the six-year-old KORUS free trade agreement, Lighthizer said during his House hearing. South Korean Trade Minister Kim Hyun-chong "is in town right now. I think we're down to the last few issues and I'm hopeful that we'll be able to come to some agreement that will make the committee happy," he said.

Lighthizer defended the administration's decision to amend the pact through a mechanism provided in the KORUS agreement, rather than use trade promotion authority procedures that would give Congress a greater role in the process. He also noted that current talks with South Korea involve the country's desire to get an exemption from new steel and aluminum tariffs.

"In the opinion of many people, Korea is a particular problem in area of steel, primarily. But we're trying to work our way through all of those things. I'm hopeful that we can make headway on it," Lighthizer said.

LIGHTHIZER DEFENDS NAFTA FOOD LABELING PROPOSAL: Lighthizer defended a U.S. NAFTA proposal that would limit the types of warnings that could appear on food labels in Canada and Mexico, but he said it was about fighting protectionism rather than advocating junk food.

The Trump administration supports "the idea of putting limits on the ability of countries to put warning labels or symbols on product," Lighthizer said at the House hearing. "There are lots of examples of countries that are using this loophole to basically create a protectionist environment" against American food exports.

Rep. Lloyd Doggett asked about the issue, which was the subject of a recent New York Times story. The Texas Democrat said he was worried the Trump administration was advancing proposals that would make it harder to fight obesity.

"I'd like to put my office on the record as being against obesity," Lighthizer said.

"I'm glad to hear it," Doggett fired back. "The question is whether you're against things that prevent us from addressing that problem."

Lighthizer replied that USTR saw the issue in the more "nuanced" manner described above.

WTO HANDS CHINA PARTIAL VICTORY AGAINST THE U.S.: Amid all the trade news in Washington, the World Trade Organization ruled Wednesday that the United States did not fully comply with a 2014 ruling against countervailing duties on a range of Chinese products, Reuters reported from Geneva.

The case dates back to 2012 and involves duties that the United States imposed on Chinese solar panels, wind towers, steel cylinders and aluminum extrusions. "The WTO panel agreed that the United States had not correctly used third country prices to assess the subsidies, but supported the U.S. assertion that exporters were getting subsidies from Chinese 'public bodies,' despite Beijing's assertions to the contrary," Reuters reported.

"The WTO's panel findings represent a step forward and a step backward on appropriately addressing non-market behavior from China that harms America's workers," USTR spokeswoman Amelia Breinig told Morning Trade. "The United States is pleased that the WTO panel accurately concluded that China's state-owned enterprises are 'public bodies' under the WTO Subsidies Agreement, providing a massive number of subsidies. Unfortunately, the panel used a flawed Appellate Body approach from a previous dispute to fault the Department of Commerce's effort to measure subsidies when potential 'benchmark' prices are distorted by Chinese government intervention."

If China's complaint survives a potential appeal, it would move a step closer to retaliatory sanctions on U.S. trade, although the two sides would first have to settle on the value of sanctions, which would involve a round of legal argument, according to Reuters. Breinig did not say whether USTR would appeal the decision.

LIGHTHIZER: NAFTA AUTO RULES-OF-ORIGIN TALKS STARTING TO 'CONVERGE': The U.S., Mexico and Canada are moving closer to striking a deal on auto rules-of-origin, one of the thorniest issues in the ongoing NAFTA renegotiation, Lighthizer said Wednesday. While Lighthizer kept mum on the details of a possible compromise, he added that "I think we're in a good place."

"We're in a position that we're finally starting to converge," Lighthizer told lawmakers at the Ways and Means hearing. "We're working very closely with the U.S. industry. I had people on Monday, and I think even until yesterday in Detroit, trying to work out the details of this kind of agreement."

Mexico waits on U.S. ROO proposal: Mexico will hold off on presenting its automotive rules-of-origin proposal until the U.S. presents its updated plan. Mexican officials are currently crafting a proposal that would take from both the U.S.'s and Canada's proposals, but remains lower than the U.S.'s ask that 85 percent of the parts of a car be made in the three NAFTA countries.

"What's the necessity for me to put forth a Mexican proposal if the U.S. government and its industry still haven't come to an agreement? It would be poor strategically if I put forth a proposal before waiting for there to be one [from the U.S.]," Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo told reporters on Tuesday, according to Mexican newspaper Reforma.

DOUD VOWS TO KEEP CHALLENGING CHINA'S AG PRACTICES AT WTO: The Trump administration will continue to take on China by both challenging Beijing's agricultural market practices and pushing for new agricultural standards at the WTO, U.S. chief agricultural negotiator Gregg Doud said Wednesday. Doud emphasized that the U.S. will continue to pursue two ongoing Obama-era cases filed against China -- one over its farm subsidies and one on tariff rate quotas for rice, wheat and corn.

"We are calling for a reset of the agricultural negotiations [at the WTO], beginning with improved transparency and a more realistic understanding of who should and should not continue to claim things like developing country status," Doud said at the Agri-Pulse Ag and Food Policy Summit.

Former U.S. agricultural negotiator weighs in: Darci Vetter, a USTR chief agricultural negotiator in the Obama administration, said the U.S. shouldn't be "going it alone and defining it as an us vs. them issue" when it comes to China.

The U.S. should use the WTO when possible, and use "the pressure of our allies to say this kind of behavior has to change and we're prepared to act together," she added.

CIVIL SOCIETY GROUPS PUSH FOR A WORKER-FRIENDLY NAFTA: More than 1,000 civil society groups demanded that lawmakers push for an end to the investor-state dispute settlement process and advocate for strong labor and environmental standards in a new NAFTA. In a Wednesday letter to Congress, Citizens Trade Campaign, a coalition of labor, environmental and other civil society organizations, argued that a fair NAFTA would end rules that threaten food safety and labeling, add strong disciplines against currency manipulation and make medicine more affordable. The NAFTA renegotiation should also make room for more input from the public and lawmakers, the groups said.

"In the absence of a binding and easily enforced agreement based on these critical measures, Mexican workers will continue to be horribly exploited, American jobs will continue to be outsourced, the environment will continue to be degraded and the wages for workers in all three NAFTA countries will continue to decline," the letter said.

SENATORS PUSH FOR NEW 'COMPETITIVENESS' CHAPTER IN NAFTA 2.0: Sens. Ted Cruz, Cory Gardner and Steve Daines urged Trump on Tuesday to further advance the Republican economic policy agenda by including a "competitiveness" chapter in the NAFTA renegotiation. The Republican senators said that a modernized NAFTA should incorporate "both new rules that will enhance U.S. competitiveness abroad and structural reforms to ensure sustainable competitiveness at home."

"Rather than focusing on making it more difficult for companies to invest in other countries, we should instead make it easier for them to grow and invest here in the United States," the letter explains.

The chapter would create a coordinated permit system that speeds up infrastructure projects; codify regulatory reform measures to eliminate red tape; promote more participation in job training programs; and develop physical and digital infrastructure that expedites cargo movement, the senators said.

Mexico previously expressed interest in including a standalone chapter on competitiveness but did not give details. The senators added that their proposal would help ensure that a renegotiated NAFTA gets approved by Congress before November without a filibuster.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

-- Lobbyists want to use a new NAFTA to make it easier for U.S. companies to build factories, move cargo and export coal, Bloomberg reports.

-- The Federal Reserve raised rates for the first time this year, signaling it will act more aggressively to head off inflation, POLITICO reports.

-- Brazil claimed that the U.S. will suspend tariffs on the South American nation, but USTR declined to confirm that, Reuters reports.

THAT'S ALL FOR MORNING TRADE! See you again soon! In the meantime, drop the team a line: abehsudi@politico.com and @abehsudi; mcassella@politico.com and @mmcassella; dpalmer@politico.com and @tradereporter; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny. Also follow us @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Trade.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers are the most productive in the world. Our farmers and ranchers exported more than $129 billion worth of products in 2016, accounting for 20% of all farm revenue in the U.S. Agricultural exports also support more than one million American jobs - most of them in the nonfarm sector. These jobs provide stability for rural families and communities. Free trade is essential to maintaining the strength of our agriculture economy. But some in Washington now support policies that would restrict trade. That would be devastating to family farms across the country, and would cause higher prices for consumers. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade to keep our agriculture economy strong. Learn more here. **

results.title: Omnibus finally pulls in
results.body:
With help from Eric Wolff, Anthony Adragna and Alex Guill√©n

IT'S HERE! After days of waiting, Congress finally released the text Wednesday night of its $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill for fiscal 2018. Now the clock starts ticking toward passage of the legislation H.R. 1625 (115), which must happen before current funding runs out Friday to avert a government shutdown. The good news: The House Rules Committee has already waived the usual three-day waiting period required before legislation can receive a vote on the floor. Read more.

THE (SPENDING) LEVEL PLAYING FIELD: The 2,232-page document is no light reading. Instead, here's the break down: the Energy-Water appropriations came in at $43.2 billion, up from $37.8 billion in fiscal 2017, while Interior-Environment rose to $35.25 billion from $32.28 billion in FY 2017. Of course, there's far more to it than that, and POLITICO's Energy team is here to guide you through what you need to know:

EPA grants rise: The agency's operational budget would remain pretty much the same, but grant programs get a boost, Alex Guill√©n and Annie Snider report. That means the Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving funds are slated to get an extra $300 million each, for a total of $2.9 billion in funding. Another $50 million is set aside for new programs created in last year's water resources bill to focus on basic infrastructure and reducing lead in school drinking water.

Looking up for DOE: The Energy Department is one of the big winners: It would get $34.5 billion -- a $3.77 billion increase over fiscal 2017, Pro's Anthony Adragna reports. DOE's energy programs receive $12.9 billion, up $1.6 billion from the fiscal 2017 levels and $5.4 billion more than the Trump administration requested. Science research programs would receive $6.26 billion, $868 million above the fiscal 2017. Also of note: The Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy, which President Donald Trump wanted to eliminate, stays alive and gets $353.3 million.

Interior falls flat: Interior's budget remains near $13.1 billion, pushing aside Trump's request to cut it to $11.6 billion, Pro's Ben Lefebvre reports. The key takeaway for ME: Funding for agencies overseeing offshore oil and gas development and rig safety were boosted. For one, the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management would see $171 million, up from $112 million, while the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement would receive $186 million, up from $98 million approved last year.

Water infrastructure gets boost: The Army Corps of Engineers is set to receive a nearly $800 million boost to its budget, Annie reports, bringing it to $6.83 billion. Most of the agency's budget lines would see increases, including an additional $200 million for its construction account, and nearly $500 million more for operation and maintenance of its aging portfolio of locks, dams, levees and ports.

WHAT'S MISSING? A few policy riders ME has been watching didn't make the cut. Namely, Senate Appropriations Chairman Thad Cochran's controversial provision for a Mississippi flood control project. Another rider that would have delayed implementation of EPA's revised ozone standard for 10 years was axed, Anthony reports. The same with a rider that would have insulated repeal of the Waters of the U.S. rule from legal challenges.

-- "While I am disappointed that the Interior and Environment bill continues to be the target for poison pill riders, I am relieved that, once again, we were able to protect our bedrock environment and conservation laws," Sen. Tom Udall said in a statement. The agreement creates an emergency pot of money for the U.S. Forest Service -- which conservation groups are cheering -- to use when it exceeds its fire-suppression budget, Pro's Sarah Ferris and Kaitlyn Burton report.

PHEW! HAPPY THURSDAY! I'm your host Kelsey Tamborrino, and NRECA's Dan Riedinger is today's trivia winner. Congress passed all its required appropriations measures on time on only four occasions: in fiscal 1977 (the first full fiscal year under the current process), 1989, 1995 and 1997. And, a correction to Wednesday's trivia answer: While Tonie Nathan was the first Jewish politician to win an electoral vote in a presidential election, some of you pointed out Barry Goldwater was the first ethnically Jewish person to receive a vote. For today: What is the name of the first female journalist to interview a sitting president? Send your tips, energy gossip and comments to ktamborrino@politico.com, or follow us on Twitter @kelseytam, @Morning_Energy and @POLITICOPro.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

PRUITT'S SECURITY FLEW FIRST-CLASS TOO: EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt's security detail also flew first-class as the agency chief racked up more than $105,000 in first-class flights during his first year, according to a little-noticed disclosure in letters to House Oversight and Energy and Commerce Committees. Citing "specific, ongoing threats" to both Pruitt and his family as justifying the enhanced security procedures, the disclosure means the total tab for the trips is substantially higher.

Questions coming: Three senior Energy and Commerce Democrats said in a statement that Pruitt would face questions about his spending habits during an April 26 hearing. "What is clear is that while he makes extreme cuts to critical public health and environmental protection programs, the Administrator has taken a holiday from all fiscal responsibility when it comes to his own travel and personal convenience," Reps. Diana DeGette, Paul Tonko and Frank Pallone said in a statement. In response, EPA spokesman Jahan Wilcox said: "These security decisions are made by EPA's protective service detail and are similar to security protocols within the federal government."

NOT JUST A DISTANT MEMORY: Following continued reports of Pruitt's first-class travels, ABC News obtained a photo of Pruitt deplaning a military-owned plane in June last year at New York's JFK Airport. See it here.

** A message from Chevron: Chevron and local partners are helping to provide DOERS with the hands-on technical training needed for today's jobs in the manufacturing and energy industries. Watch the video: http://politi.co/2pcrPJ0 **

PRUITT HEADS TO WYOMING: The EPA chief will make a trip to Wyoming on March 29 to visit the state's coal-mining operations, the Associated Press reports. Senate EPW Chairman John Barrasso tells AP it'll be an opportunity to showcase the state's "world-class coal operations and cutting-edge energy research."

PERRY TALKS ATOMIC ENERGY: Energy Secretary Rick Perry will return to testify in Congress today. This time he'll appear before a Senate Armed Services panel reviewing the fiscal 2019 defense authorization request. Perry will be called upon to discuss challenges in DOE's atomic energy defense programs. Perfect timing, as the White House is looking to open up talks with Saudi Arabia over a potential atomic energy deal, and has called on Perry to play a role. Separately, the House Armed Services Committee will host Energy's Lisa Gordon-Hagerty and James Owendoff on the fiscal 2019 budget request for nuclear forces and atomic energy defense. If you go: The SASC hearing begins at 10 a.m. in 216 Hart, the HASC hearing at 9 a.m. in 2118 Rayburn.

MARKEY GOES NUCLEAR: Democratic Sen. Ed Markey is interested in finding out what's going on with the nuclear talks between the U.S. and Saudi Arabia. In a letter Wednesday to Perry, Markey requested the secretary immediately brief Congress on his trip to London, where the secretary led a delegation on a nuclear cooperation agreement, or 123 agreement, with the Saudis. Markey also questioned NRC Chairwoman Kristine Svinicki about the meeting Wednesday during a Senate hearing, where she confirmed that at least one NRC lawyer attended the February London meeting. Read it here.

NRC YOU SOON? Senior Republicans are upping their public pressure on one of their own, Sen. Dean Heller, to release his hold on Republican Nuclear Regulatory Commission nominee Annie Caputo ahead of a June deadline when the federal regulator would lose a quorum. Sen. Jim Inhofe told ME a quorum-less NRC would empower Svinicki to take unilateral steps toward the construction of Yucca Mountain, which Heller staunchly opposes. "What [opponents] don't want to happen is for June to get here and not have a quorum," Inhofe said. Not everyone, though, thinks that allowing the quorum to lapse would empower Svinicki. Barrasso said at a Wednesday hearing that while he continues to "work to resolve this situation," a quorum-less NRC would likely allow groups to "challenge the NRC's authority and ability to act." Heller's office didn't respond to request for comment.

COURT HEARS GREEN CHALLENGE TO EPA 'EXCEPTIONAL EVENTS' RULE: Environmental groups and EPA will duke it out in court today over whether a 2016 regulation makes it too easy for areas with high air pollution levels to get away with excess emissions from human-connected activity. The "exceptional events" rule defines certain causes of pollution that won't count against an area's air quality monitoring. The NRDC and Sierra Club argue the Clean Air Act limits exceptional events almost entirely to non-human-related causes like volcanic activity or forest fires. But the language of EPA's rule, they argue, means that exceedances that are partly natural and partly human-caused are wrongly counted as purely natural events. EPA argues that a "purity" test in which events must be "totally untouched by any human activity" would have left the law without any "practical meaning." The arguments start at 9:30 a.m. at the Prettyman Courthouse. The panel includes Judges Thomas Griffith, Gregory Katsas and Harry T. Edwards.

MORE NOMS: The Senate Energy Committee holds a markup to consider DOE nominees Theodore Garrish to be an assistant secretary for international affairs and James Edward Campos to be director of the Office of Minority Economic Impact. The committee will also consider the nomination of James Reilly to be director of the U.S. Geological Survey. Following the vote, the committee will hold a hearing on various bills, including S. 2539 (115), to amend the "Energy and Water Development and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2015," to re-authorize certain projects in the Colorado River System. If you go: The hearing starts at 10 a.m. in 366 Dirksen.

RIVERKEEPER: CAN FERC REGULATE THE COMPANIES THAT FUND IT? Delaware Riverkeeper and its compadres will argue today before the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals that FERC is hopelessly biased in favor of pipeline approvals since it's partially funded through a formula based on how much natural gas is transported through pipelines. The nonprofit alleges that the due process clause in the Fifth Amendment requires that agencies be neutral, and that FERC can't be neutral because it is funded by the companies it regulates.

MAIL CALL! GROUPS WANT METHANE RULE HEARING: Thirty-seven environmental and conservation groups wrote to Secretary Ryan Zinke requesting the Bureau of Land Management hold a public hearing on potential revisions to the methane and waste prevention rule. The letter also asks BLM to extend the public comment period by 60 days. Read it here.

OIL AND GAS LOBBYIST TAKES ON NAFTA: While the three countries involved are working to come to a deal on NAFTA, lobbyists are eyeing a potential rewrite as the perfect vehicle to get a host of broad legislation advanced -- namely, making it easier to export coal. Using the fast-track authority of the president, a trade bill could sail through Congress with a simple majority, Bloomberg reports.

Leading the effort, is a husband-and-wife duo with some oil and gas backing. Rebecca Rosen of Devon Energy Corp. and her husband Jeff Weiss, who spent 10 years in the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative and is now with Venable LLP, "have spent months quietly developing the strategy, honing the approach as they slowly widened the circle of advocates, drawing support from business lobbies, lining up a few influential Senate supporters and getting buy-in from key White House officials." Read more.

SPEAKING OF NAFTA: Republicans want USTR Robert Lighthizer to keep his hands off investment dispute-settlement provisions within the trade pact. More than 100 GOP members of Congress wrote to Lighthizer Wednesday, warning him not to drop the longstanding provisions, if he expects their support for a revamped agreement. Read more from Pro's Doug Palmer.

GETTING EXPENSIVE IN HERE: Last year was the "most expensive year on record" for extreme weather and climate events, the World Meteorological Organization said Wednesday, noting the raft of hurricanes, major monsoon floods and severe droughts. The findings are part of the U.N. weather agency's annual statement on the state of the global climate, POLITICO Europe's Kalina Oroschakoff reports.

BREAKING IT DOWN: U.S. natural gas exports surged in 2017, according to data from the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Check out how from Pro's DataPoint team here. Want to add DataPoint to your Pro account? Learn more.

RINSE CYCLE: The conservative Competitive Enterprise Institute petitioned DOE Wednesday to take action on what they say are "increasingly slow" dishwashers, a direct result of the department's energy efficiency standards. Specifically, CEI requested DOE create new standards for residential dishwashers that require just one hour to complete the job. Read the petition here.

-- Borrowing GOP playbook, Democratic states sue the government and rack up wins, The New York Times.

-- Atlantic Coast Pipeline can't enter some private properties, federal judge says, The News & Observer.

-- With rise of Russian and Chinese reactors, Perry fights to keep U.S. nuclear sector alive, Houston Chronicle.

-- Bad news for the climate: Coal burning, and carbon emissions, are on the rise again, The Washington Post.

THAT'S ALL FOR ME!

** A message from Chevron: See how Chevron with local partners are helping DOERS get the hands-on technical training needed for jobs in the energy and manufacturing industries. Watch the video: http://politi.co/2FPissj **

results.title: Inside the omnibus
results.body:
INSIDE THE OMNIBUS: Congressional negotiators released the text of a $1.3 trillion spending bill Wednesday night that would fund the federal government through Sept. 30. President Donald Trump "appears grudgingly willing to support the measure, which is likely the last major piece of legislation he will sign before the midterm elections," POLITICO reports. To avoid a shutdown, Congress will need to pass the bill (or a short-term funding extension) by midnight Friday.

Big boost for DHS: The Homeland Security Department would receive a roughly 13 percent funding increase in fiscal year 2018 compared with the previous year's enacted levels, according to a summary from the Senate Appropriations Committee. CBP would see a 15 percent funding spike under the spending agreement. ICE would get a 10 percent boost.

Border barriers, but not a wall: The spending bill devotes $1.6 billion to physical barriers and technology along the Southwest border. The funds cover 95 miles of "border wall system" -- 47 miles of new barriers plus 48 of replacement barriers, according to the Senate Appropriations Committee summary. Despite negotiations in recent months, the bill doesn't deal at all with "Dreamers" brought to the U.S. as children.

Steady going for DOL, NLRB: Trump proposed slashing Labor Department funding by 20 percent in his fiscal year 2018 budget plan, but congressional negotiators didn't cooperate in the omnibus. The bill set funding at $12 billion, a 1 percent increase. NLRB funding will remain at the previous year's level, skirting a 6 percent cut proposed by the White House.

Tip pooling provision: The bill includes a compromise aimed at preventing employers from stealing tips under a proposed DOL rule that would allow the redistribution of tip money to back-of-house workers. The language -- brokered by Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.) and Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta -- would give workers the right to sue employers for stolen wages, with damages. In addition, the Labor secretary would have the power to sue companies for stolen tips and impose civil penalties.

But House Democrats, including House Education and the Workforce Ranking Member Bobby Scott (D-Va.) have come out against the compromise. They say it would allow employers to simply reduce base pay and replace it with tips, effectively keeping the money for themselves. Scott said in a written statement that he's "unwilling to trade away the basic principle that workers are entitled to control the tips they earn."

H-2B visa expansion: The omnibus includes language that would allow DHS Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen to approximately double the number of H-2B guest worker visas available in fiscal year 2018. The visa program offers 66,000 visas annually to businesses that seek foreign workers in seasonal, non-agricultural roles. When Congress passed the last omnibus spending bill in May, it included the same rider. Then-DHS Secretary John Kelly (in consultation with the DOL) eventually agreed in July to add 15,000 additional visas -- what he called a "one-time increase."

Hardball on wages: Part of the spending bill targets the salaries of minor league baseball players, as Bloomberg Law's Chris Opfer highlighted in a tweet. "Tucked inside the omnibus spending bill (page 1,967) is a provision that allows pro baseball teams to stop paying minor league players minimum wages and overtime," he wrote Wednesday evening. The Washington Post reported earlier this week that the measure could surface in the legislation.

Relevant fact: Most minor league players earn poverty-level wages. "Starting pay for minor leaguers is between $1,100 and $2,150 a month, and only during the season, which can be as short as three months," Mother Jones reported in 2014.

Biden to talk jobs: Former Vice President Joe Biden and Chamber of Commerce President Thomas Donohue will participate in a roundtable about creating jobs for American workers. The discussion will be led by Virginia Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax, Prince George's Community College President Charlene Dukes, and Washington Center for Equitable Growth Executive Director Heather Boushey. The event starts at 10 a.m. at the Newseum. Watch a livestream here.

OKLAHOMA LAWMAKERS SCRAMBLE TO AVOID STRIKE: Oklahoma legislators have begun discussions around teacher pay raises to avoid a walkout similar to the one that closed West Virginia public schools for nearly two weeks in late February-early March. Public school teachers have vowed to strike by April 2 if the state does not increase pay and education budgets. One plan proposed by a GOP state senator would raise salaries by $6,000 over three years. Accompanying legislation would generate more than $900 million in new revenue to pay for the wage increases. More from News9's Chris Gilmore here.

HOMAN COULD GIVE 'SANCTUARY' TESTIMONY: Thomas Homan, the top official at ICE, will likely be called to testify in the administration's lawsuit against the state of California over its so-called "sanctuary" laws, Don Thompson reports in the Associated Press. U.S. Magistrate Judge Kendall Newman said it was his "strong inclination" to make Homan provide four hours of sworn testimony in the case, the AP reports.

"Homan must back up claims that the federal government is suffering 'irreparable harm' from three California laws that limit cooperation with federal immigration authorities by employers and state and local law enforcement agencies, Newman said," according to the AP. The judge rejected a DOJ attorney's argument "that such testimony would be too burdensome on a busy agency director." More here.

INSLEE SIGNS GENDER WAGE EQUALITY BILL: "[Washington State] Gov. Jay Inslee has signed a measure that seeks to reduce the wage gap between men and women and provide equal growth opportunities and fair treatment in the workplace," the Associated Press reports. "The measure modifies the state's Equal Pay Act by making several changes, including making it unacceptable for employers to retaliate against an employee for asking about their wages or the salary of other employees. It also provides additional protections under the existing law for employees whose professional opportunities are hindered because of their gender." More here.

UAW OFFICIAL CHARGED: A sixth high-level United Auto Workers official has been indicted for allegedly using illegal cash from Fiat Chrysler to pay for lavish personal expenses during contract negotiations, Robert Snell reports in the Detroit News. Prosecutors say the former official, Nancy Adams Johnson "spent tens of thousands of dollars in illegal payments from Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV on $1,100 designer shoes, first-class flights to California, resorts and limousines."

From Snell: "Adams Johnson traveled, golfed, dined and shopped with Fiat Chrysler money funneled through a training center for blue-collar workers under a policy created by the auto company's officials to keep UAW leaders 'fat, dumb and happy,' according to the government. The policy was designed to wring concessions favoring the automaker, according to the government."

The scandal has ensnared former UAW Vice President Norwood Jewell, who is accused of being given a birthday party with training center fees that included top-shelf liquor and "strolling models who lit labor leaders' cigars," according to the News. Adams Johnson is alleged to have spent $75,000 in training center money on personal items, "including $1,000 Christian Louboutin shoes, clothes, jewelry, luggage, meals and more."

The UAW called the allegations "appalling" but said "there is no evidence that compromised individuals involved in this investigation, including Ms. Johnson, in any way corrupted the negotiations of the terms of the collective bargaining agreement." More here.

FED RAISES RATES: "The Federal Reserve on Wednesday raised interest rates for the first time this year and signaled it will act more aggressively to head off inflation, potentially threatening [Trump's] hopes for faster economic growth," POLITICO's Victoria Guida reports. "Fed officials are now essentially split on the question of whether to hike interest rates a total of three times or four this year -- a response, in part, to recent tax cuts and increased spending by Congress, which the central bank fears could lead prices to spike." More here.

DIGGING INTO TRUMP'S NDAS: The New York Times explores Trump's use of non-disclosure agreements in a piece by Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Maggie Haberman, Michael Shear and Katie Rogers. In the early months of his presidency, Trump was "infuriated by leaks about everything from staff rivalries to his bathrobe-wearing, TV-viewing habits." He ordered then-chief of staff Reince Priebus to force aides to sign NDAs in an effort to stop the flow of inside information.

"To calm Mr. Trump, Donald F. McGahn II, the White House counsel, drew up a broad document barring White House officials from publicly disclosing what they heard and saw at work," the Times reports. "But he privately told senior aides that it was mainly meant to placate an agitated president, who was convinced that the people around him had to be pressured into keeping his secrets. Mr. McGahn made it clear the agreement could not ultimately be enforced, according to several people who signed."

"The nondisclosure agreement, presented by Mr. Priebus to the senior staff last April, did not specify any penalties -- financial or otherwise -- for breaking it," the Times reports. "But it was an early indication that Mr. Trump, who spent decades using pressure tactics and secrecy in his private life, wanted to do the same thing at the White House, breaking with tradition." More here.

COFFEE BREAK:

-- "U.S. companies are pressuring their workers on how to lobby and vote," from the Washington Post

-- "Welcome to Zucktown. Where everything is just zucky," from the New York Times

-- "Trump's immigration stance is making the Census more difficult than ever," from Bloomberg Politics

-- "Fred Savage accused of on-set harassment and battery," from CNN

-- "After Trump, an oratorio about 'Dreamers' changes key," from the New York Times

results.title: New PPIC poll: FEINSTEIN, NEWSOM with big leads -- SCHAAF pushes back at Trump -- ATKINS at the state SENATE Helm -- ZUCKERBERG open to congressional testimony, regulations
results.body:
THE BUZZ: A new Public Policy Institute of California poll shows Sen. Dianne Feinstein maintaining a wide lead over state Senate President Pro Tem Kevin de Le√≥n, a fellow Democrat, in the all-party Senate primary.

-- "Feinstein leads de Le√≥n 42 percent to 16 percent. Nearly four in 10 likely voters, 39 percent, are undecided. While being under 50 percent is typically a red flag for an incumbent, there are signs in the poll that Feinstein is in strong position. She leads de Le√≥n among Democratic voters, 66 percent to 20 percent. The vast majority of Republicans, 71 percent, are undecided -- and a liberal challenger could struggle to attract those voters against Feinstein".

SOME TOPLINES:

-- GAVIN BOUNCES BACK IN GOV'S RACE: Democratic Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom has pulled in front of the all-party primary field, the poll shows, with 28 percent. The poll also shows the GOP has a shot at a second-place finish and berth in the general election, with three candidates in a virtual tie for second in the survey, two of them Republicans.

-- GOPer COMES IN SECOND: Businessman John Cox is at 14 percent, followed by former Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa -- who was running neck-and-neck with Newsom for first place in January -- at 12 percent. GOP state Assemblyman Travis Allen is at 10 percent.

--Bringing up the rear: State Treasurer John Chiang is at 6 percent, and former state Superintendent of Public Instruction Delaine Eastin is at 5 percent. Nearly a quarter of voters, 24 percent, are undecided.

-- BOTTOM LINE: "Gavin Newsom and Dianne Feinstein have solid leads in the gubernatorial and senate races," said Mark Baldassare, president and CEO of the Public Policy Institute of California. "Yet many voters remain undecided, raising questions about the outcomes in the top-two primary."

-- BAD NEWS FOR THE GOP: "Democrats lead the generic congressional ballot in the state, 53 percent to 39 percent, the poll shows. Among likely voters in Democratic-held districts, the generic Democrat leads, 58 percent to 32 percent. In GOP-held districts, the Republican edge is smaller, 56 percent to 38 percent. Story for POLITICO Campaign Pro subscribers, via POLITICO's Steve Shepard. Full poll here.

-- THE CALBUZZ TAKE via Jerry Roberts and Phil Trounstine: "Prince Gavin Surges Past Tony V; DiFi Steady"- Story

BUENOS D√çAS, good Thursday morning. State Treasurer John Chiang sits down tonight with POLITICO's David Siders at USF's McClaren Center, 5 p.m. for "Conversations for the Common Good,'' sponsored by the McCarthy Center.

Where's Jerry: No public schedule.

QUOTE OF THE DAY: "I'll be all over the country. Kevin, you'll get me all over. Where is our Kevin? You're going to get me all over the country, Kevin? And I'll be complaining every single trip. But I'm going to get there." -- President Trump to House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy two nights ago at an NRCC fundraiser h/t Playbook's Anna Palmer, Jake Sherman and Daniel Lippman

TWEET OF THE DAY: Doug Sovern @SovernNation: "Is it too much to ask that the President at least learn how to spell the office of the person who could end his presidency? I mean, come on, @realDonaldTrump. It's special "counsel." It's a lawyer, not a govt body."

It's Thursday -- Got a tip? Feedback? News to share? Let us know. By email: cmarinucci@politico.com or dsiders@politico.com. Follow us on Twitter: @cmarinucci, @davidsiders and @POLITICOCA.

---OAKLAND STROKES -- Libby's Response -- "Oakland Mayor strikes back at Trump,'' by POLITICO's Carla Marinucci in Oakland: "A defiant Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf -- a target of the White House and conservative pundits since she warned residents in late February of a recent impending ICE raid -- pushed back hard Wednesday at fresh Trump administration attacks suggesting her actions allowed dangerous criminals to return to the streets, commit more crimes, and endanger the public.

-- "It is continued distraction. It is a continued perpetration of a racist lie, that immigrants are not valued members of our society,'' Schaaf told reporters following her launch of a new ballot measure to support early childhood education. "We in Oakland know better. We in Oakland have a community that welcomes and honors all people, no matter where they came from -- no matter how they got here.'' Story.

-- THE COMEBACK -- "ICE Defends Credibility, Warns Political Feud Is Hampering Operation -- but agency's leader is still picking a fight with Oakland's mayor,'' via KCBS's Doug Sovern: Homan implied (three undocumented immigrants) got away and offended again because Schaaf tipped them off. It wasn't until KCBS Radio inquired after the event that ICE confirmed that the three were in fact arrested weeks ago, and none was from Oakland. They were arrested March 2 in Sacramento (just two days after the ICE raids ended), March 5 in Los Banos, and March 10 in Tulare County. ICE has presented no evidence that they ever lived in Oakland, committed crimes in Oakland, or were aware of the Mayor's statement before last month's enforcement operation began." Story.

SCHAAF's OTHER CAMPAIGN -- Launched yesterday with state Assemblyman Rob Bonta -- the Oakland 2018 Children's Initiative, a ballot measure which she said Wednesday would expand access to high quality education and level the educational playing field for more than 10,000 Oakland kids. Signatures needed to make it to ballot: 35,000, to begin collecting Saturday.

MENLO PARK MIRACLE -- ZUCK SPEAKS -- "Mark Zuckerberg tells CNN he's 'happy to' testify before Congress,'' by CNN's Seth Fiegerman: Mark Zuckerberg apologized for the data debacle that has upended Facebook and left the door open to testifying before Congress. "The short answer is I'm happy to if it's the right thing to do," the Facebook (FB) CEO told CNN's Laurie Segall in an exclusive TV interview airing on "Anderson Cooper 360. ... What we try to do is send the person at Facebook who will have the most knowledge," Zuckerberg said. "If that's me, then I am happy to go." Story.

-- "Welcome to Zucktown. Where Everything Is Just Zucky,'' by David Streitfeld in the New York Times: "In Menlo Park, Calif., Facebook is building a real community and testing the proposition: Do people love tech companies so much they will live inside them?"Story.

GARCETTI WATCH:

-- "Garcetti edges toward presidential run with trip to Iowa," by POLITICO's Edward-Isaac Dovere: "The Los Angeles mayor and expected 2020 candidate is making a two-day swing through Iowa April 13-14, with stops in Des Moines, Altoona, Davenport and Waterloo, hitting a union event, a political fundraiser and local tours along the way." Story

results.title: House scrambles to pass omnibus spending package
results.body:
With government funding running out midnight Friday, House GOP leaders are scrambling to push a massive $1.3 trillion spending bill through the chamber today, only hours after unveiling its text.

But House Democrats, led by Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), are pushing back, trying to defeat the bill on a parliamentary vote this morning.

Top Republicans privately believe Pelosi's gambit will fail, but the last-minute maneuvering shows how confused the outlook for the omnibus package is on Capitol Hill at this moment.

While large majorities in both parties want the bill to pass -- and voted for the budget agreement that ended last month's government shutdown -- lawmakers are using what is likely the last "must pass" legislation of the year in order to move their own proposals or score some political points.

There also has been little time to review the huge bill, well over 2000 pages long, which has upset lawmakers in both parties.

Pelosi is urging her members to vote against the House rule to consider the omnibus -- the first step on the floor to debating the package -- after congressional leaders failed to secure protections for Dreamers in the funding bill.

While Pelosi is supporting the overall spending package -- she and other Democrats have bragged that they defeated many "poison pill" rides sought by Republicans -- the California Democrat is unhappy that there was no action on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. President Donald Trump has sought to end the program, although the issue is now likely heading for the Supreme Court.

"The Republicans could easily have joined us in providing real protection for the Dreamers but refused to do so," Pelosi said in a letter to her colleagues sent overnight.

Pelosi's position may be a problem for Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and his top lieutenants. A number of conservative Republicans, including the House Freedom Caucus, are opposed to the package. Republicans believe some Democrats will support the rule -- despite Pelosi's push -- because they want provisions in the omnibus.

Trump's apathy toward the omnibus package is also a potential issue. While he has publicly called for its passage, Trump on Wednesday vented to Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) that he wanted more money for his border wall with Mexico. Ultimately, Trump agreed to sign the bill once it's passed, but only after creating a panic with GOP leaders who had to scramble to convince the president that he had secured real legislative wins.

GOP conservatives have already come out against the bill in droves. It took just minutes after the bill's release for the House Freedom Caucus to formally oppose it.

Republican Study Committee Chairman Mark Walker said he and many of his members are leaning 'no.'

"There's good and bad and ugly, except the bad and ugly is really bad and ugly, so we'll see what happens," Walker said Wednesday night.

Congressional leaders considered several options for trading Dreamer protections for wall funding in the omnibus but ultimately couldn't come to a deal. The White House wanted full funding for the wall -- $25 billion -- but Democrats were only willing to consider that if Republicans agreed to offer Dreamers a path to citizenship, not just a temporary reprieve.

"While some may differ, many Dreamers and their supporters made it clear that they did not want to accept a patch of less value tied to intensified interior enforcement," Pelosi wrote.

results.title: Here come the China tariffs
results.body:
HERE COME THE CHINA TARIFFS -- The White House moved their timetable up by a day and President Trump plans to announce around $50 billion of tariffs on Chinese exports to the U.S. on Thursday at 12:30 p.m. EST. As discussed on the POLITICO Money podcast this week, the tariffs are meant as a response to estimates for what the U.S. lost to China in intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers last year. An official close to the process confirmed the $50 billion number but also said details could change at any time until Trump makes the announcement.

White House Council of Economic Advisors Chairman Kevin Hassett has been working on the list of hundreds of products to be targeted to avoid the biggest possible hits on U.S. consumers. "Kevin is trying to skew it to the smart side as much as possible," one senior official said. But the shear breadth of the products subject to tariff mean consumers will feel the pinch.

Per this WSJ report, China is likely to respond with their own levies aimed at states that Trump won in 2016. The tariffs on the U.S. would likely hit Farm Belt states and products including soybeans, sorghum and live hogs. The big question is whether this trade dispute with China will remain relatively contained. An exchange of limited tariffs like these would not likely be a totally destabilizing event though it's likely to hit U.S. farmers fairly hard.

Trump's tariffs could theoretically have a positive effect if they lead China to further open up their financial services and insurance markets to U.S. companies. But the big risk remains that China responds, Trump gets angry at their response and announces even more tariffs. That's the textbook definition of a trade war. And if it escalates it could do serious damage to the U.S. economy - much more than it would to China - slamming consumers, farmers and manufacturers and likely tanking the stock market.

OMNIBUS DEAL REACHED -- Via POLITICO's Heather Caygle, Burgess Everett, and Rachael Bade: "Congressional leaders have clinched an agreement on a massive $1.3 trillion spending bill that ... Trump, for now, appears grudgingly willing to support. Washington has until Friday to act before the government shuts down.

"Negotiators finally reached an accord to fund the government through September after abandoning many of the most controversial provisions lawmakers were trying to include in the must-pass bill ... and is likely the last major piece of legislation the president will sign before the midterm elections.

"The bill will, however, fix a snafu in the GOP's tax law -- the so-called 'grain glitch' -- that farm state lawmakers were seeking. It also includes a narrow gun safety measure and a compromise on a New York infrastructure project that had become a lightning-rod issue with the president." Read more.

WHAT'S IN THE BILL -- POLITICO's Sarah Ferris has the details on what's in and out of the omnibus, H.R. 1625 (115), from Gateway to border security. Overall the $1.3 trillion bill would add $143 billion in increased funding across defense and domestic programs in fiscal 2018.

THE FULL TEXT of the giant spending bill, finally posted around 8:00 p.m. Wednesday night, is here. It clocks in at 2,232 pages. The House is supposed to vote on it Thursday.

IT INCLUDES a provision calling on OMB to "submit a report to the Committees on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate on the costs of implementing the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act." It also extends a ban on redesigning the $1 bill, which is apparently a big issue for the vending machine industry.

FLOOD INSURANCE -- Via POLITICO's Zachary Warmbrodt (@zachary) on Twitter: "The omnibus would decouple expiration of the National Flood Insurance Program from government funding. The new deadline to reauthorize the NFIP would be July 31 -- a victory for House Republicans who want the Senate to get around to passing a long-term overhaul bill."

FINANCIAL SERVICES FUNDING -- Per POLITICO's budget gurus, financial services funding under the bill would be at $23.4 billion (up from $21.5 billion in FY17)

Summary of financial services funding is here.

Here's what a GOP Hill source told Zach about the omni: "Democrats can point to whatever isn't in the Omni as 'saving Dodd Frank.' Our 'riders' are named Mick Mulvaney, Steven Mnuchin, Jay Clayton, and Randy Quarles. And they're around longer than this Omnibus."

See any Easter Eggs in the Omni? Please email me at bwhite@politico.com.

Congress now has 48 hours to pass the funding bill to avoid a shutdown. President Trump supports the measure (at least for now). House conservatives in the Freedom Caucus hate the bill and will oppose it. But there should be enough Democrats to get the bill through the House on Thursday and to the Senate on Friday. But nothing is certain. And a short-term CR could be needed if any senator (see: Paul, Rand) decides to hold things up into Saturday.

** A message from FICO: Don't be fooled. VantageScore isn't an independent startup -- it's owned by the three credit bureaus. Allowing the credit bureaus to offer a credit score they own in mortgage lending decisions would consolidate their power over the entire credit reporting process. That's not good for competition or consumers. Read More. **

GOP GRILLS LIGHTHZER -- POLITICO's Doug Palmer reports here on the "bashing" administered to U.S. Trade Rep Robert Lighthizer on the Hill on Wednesday: "From the uncertainty caused by NAFTA renegotiations, to his imposition of tariffs on steel and aluminum, to his expected announcement this week of duties on tens of billions of dollars of Chinese goods, many lawmakers said that farmers and manufacturers in their districts are worried about lost sales and being hit with retaliation.

"Lighthizer brushed aside the economic analysis ... and assuring [that] Trump had no desire to launch a trade war. 'But on the other hand, you have to ask yourself, can we go on with an $800 -- and growing -- billion trade deficit,' Lighthizer said. 'So, we have to do something and the people who are benefiting from the status quo are always going to be against it. We understand that, and we have to balance their interest.'"

STEEL NO BIG DEAL? -- Via Platts: "Trump's Section 232 tariffs likely will be viewed in retrospect as 'a relatively small event' for the global steel and aluminum industries, BHP CEO Andrew Mackenzie said .. Speaking during the FT Commodities Global Summit in Lausanne, Mackenzie said the tariffs on imports -- 25% on steel and 10% on aluminum -- seemingly have been 'made smaller by a lot of the exemptions' the administration is now mulling for a number of countries and products."

ZUCK SPEAKS -- POLITICO's Nancy Scola: "Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg on Wednesday addressed the Cambridge Analytica controversy that has embroiled the company since the weekend, calling it 'a breach of trust between Facebook and the people who share their data with us and expect us to protect it. .. 'We need to fix that,' he said in a Facebook post.

"The CEO also outlined a series of steps the company is taking to shore up the security of the Facebook platform, including telling users when their data has been misused and turning off data access for applications that people haven't used within the past three months. According to sources inside Facebook ... employees have been clamoring for Zuckerberg and Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg to personally address the situation" Read more.

Zuckerberg did a bunch of other media interviews, including to the NYT here and ReCode here where he said he was willing to testify before Congress: "So I'm open to doing it if I'm the right [person]."

TOO LITTLE, TOO LATE? -- Per POLITICO's Steven Overly: "Facebook's slow, unsteady response to the furor over its handling of people's data is doing perhaps permanent damage to the D.C. reputations of ... Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg, its two most famous executives." Read more.

POWELL MAKES HIS MOVE -- It was only a quarter point hike, as expected, but Fed Chair Jay Powell erred on the hawkish side, as POLITICO's Victoria Guida reports here, posing a threat to Trump's hopes from significantly faster economic growth.

"Fed officials are now essentially split on the question of whether to hike interest rates a total of three times or four this year -- a response, in part, to recent tax cuts and increased spending by Congress, which the central bank fears could lead prices to spike. ... Fed officials upgraded their forecast for economic growth this year and next, projecting a 2.7 percent increase in GDP in 2018 and a 2.4 percent increase in 2019. But over the longer term, the central bank still expects growth to hover at or below 2 percent."

REGULATORY COMMENTS -- Cowen's Jaret Seiberg on the Powell presser: "Nothing discussed at today's press conference runs contrary to our view that policy continues to be a tailwind for regional and community banks. On the monetary policy front, our worry remains that the President could start attacking the Federal Reserve if rates keep going up as the FOMC is forecasting.

"On the CCAR stress test, Powell noted that Congress is considering raising the SIFI designation level to $250 billion of assets though the Federal Reserve would retain the power to designate smaller banks. He would not endorse having stress tests occur less frequently than annually though he acknowledged that Congress did give the Federal Reserve more discretion on this front."

WHAT'S NEXT? -- S&P's Beth Ann Bovino: "Despite the Fed's near-term outlook for only 3 rate hikes, we believe the Fed will likely raise rates slightly faster, with four rate hikes in total this year. This takes into account a stronger near-term economic outlook, helped by fiscal spending"

HAWKISH TILT -- Manulife's Megan Greene: "The Fed's March announcement and Jerome Powell's press conference offered no dramatic shocks, but the bias was decidedly hawkish relative to what we expected. ... What was more telling was the shift in the so-called dot plot, showing that most FOMC members were more hawkish about the Fed's rate path over the next three years"

GOOD THURSDAY MORNING -- Hope everyone made it through the snow OK. Hopefully it's the last one for the year. Email me on bwhite@politico.com and follow me on Twitter @morningmoneyben. Email Aubree Eliza Weaver on aweaver@politico.com and follow her on Twitter @AubreeEWeaver.
