** A message from CTIA and America's wireless industry: We need new rules for new 5G networks. FCC rules modernizing federal environmental and historic preservation reviews of new wireless infrastructure are a critical step. We need similar action by cities, states, the FCC and Congress to update local siting rules. Identifying a pipeline of new low-, mid-, and high-band spectrum is the other piece of the puzzle. These key steps will allow U.S. wireless companies to invest $275 billion, create more than 3 million jobs, and add hundreds of billions to the economy, according to Accenture. This will drive breakthrough advancements in remote health care, connected vehicles, energy, education and beyond -- making our lives better and safer. But the race to deploy 5G wireless networks is underway -- and policymakers must act this year so that the U.S. can maintain our global leadership in wireless. The EU, China, Japan, South Korea and others are doing everything they can to win. Learn more at Raceto5G.CTIA.org. **

results.title: Omnibus talks slow amid uncertainty on bill's timing
results.body:
With Eli Okun, Connor O'Brien, Jacqueline Klimas and Wesley Morgan

OMNIBUS TALKS SLOW AMID UNCERTAINTY ON BILL'S TIMING: Last night, the rollout of the massive spending package "appeared in flux" after talks between congressional negotiators and the White House moved slowly, according to a senior congressional aide, report Sarah Ferris and Kaitlyn Burton.

"Several issues remained open after administration officials participated in a lengthy meeting Tuesday afternoon with top leadership and Appropriations staffers that did little to break the logjam."

-- AND, EVEN AFTER THE OMNIBUS, FOR THE MILITARY, 'NOT EVERYTHING IS FIXED,' House Armed Services Committee Chairman Mac Thornberry warns, via our colleague Connor O'Brien, that "'it would be a mistake' to believe the two-year deal to boost defense spending 'fixes all our problems.'

"'We've got to manage expectations a little bit here,' the Texas Republican said during a hearing on the fiscal 2019 budget and acquisition reform with the secretaries of the Army, Navy and Air Force.

"'Not everything is fixed because we have a substantial increase in one year. The problems run deep,' he warned. 'The closer you look, the deeper the problems are.'"

-- ANOTHER CR? Omnibus soon -- or not, Congress is still racing toward a midnight Friday deadline to avert another government shutdown.

If omnibus talks still stall, look for congressional leaders to float another short-term continuing spending resolution to keep the government open another few days and give lawmakers some breathing room to pass the full-year spending package. If lawmakers do approve another CR, it would be the sixth stopgap for this fiscal year.

HAPPY WEDNESDAY AND WELCOME TO MORNING DEFENSE, where we'd like to remind everyone that with the federal government closed due to the spring snowstorm, events may be postponed or canceled. Email us at ghellman@politico.com, and follow on Twitter @greg_hellman, @morningdefense and @politicopro.

SCHEDULED FOR TODAY -- HASC SUBCOMMITTEE CONSIDERS GROUND FORCE MODERNIZATION: HASC's Tactical Air and Land Forces Subcommittee is slated to hear from Army and Marine Corps officials on their fiscal 2019 budget requests for ground-force modernization.

That discussion comes as the service patches its network for the near term, Breaking Defense writes.

-- SASC PANEL EYES MISSILE DEFENSE WITH ROOD AND ROBINSON: The Senate Armed Services Strategic Forces Subcommittee is scheduled to hear from Undersecretary of Defense for Policy John Rood, as well as leaders of the North American Aerospace Defense Command, Missile Defense Agency and Army Space and Missile Defense Command, on ballistic missile defense.

The hearing comes as the Pentagon is expected to imminently complete its Ballistic Missile Defense Review.

On Tuesday, U.S. Strategic Command chief John Hyten defended the Trump administration's view that the U.S. needs low-yield nukes to deter Russia, via Defense News.

QUOTE OF THE DAY -- NO SPACE OR CYBER WARS, JUST WAR: "There is no war in space, just as there is no war in cyberspace. There is only war," Hyten wrote in prepared remarks for Tuesday's SASC hearing -- a view he repeated in response to a question from Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.).

HYTEN BACKS SPACE CORPS -- JUST NOT YET, via your Morning D correspondent: "Now is not the 'right' time to create a Space Corps, U.S. Strategic Command chief Gen. John Hyten told the Senate Armed Services Committee [Tuesday].

"Earlier this month, President Donald Trump backed the idea of creating a military 'space force,' seemingly expressing support for a measure that had been opposed by the Pentagon and Air Force.

"'Someday, we'll have a Space Corps, Space Force, in this country,' Hyten said in response to a question from Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.). 'But I don't think the time is right for that right now.'"

ALSO TODAY -- SASC SUBCOMMITTEE CONSIDERS NAVY SHIPBUILDING: SASC's Seapower Subcommittee is scheduled hears from top Navy officials, including Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Research, Development, Acquisition James Geurts, on Navy shipbuilding programs.

On Tuesday, Navy Secretary Richard Spencer bristled at questions from Rep. Bradley Byrne (R-Ala.), whose district hosts a shipyard where Littoral Combat Ships are built, over the service's request for only one LCS in fiscal 2019, writes Defense News.

SENATE BLOCKS YEMEN WAR POWERS VOTE, Greg reports: "The Senate on Tuesday blocked a bipartisan resolution calling for a halt in U.S. military assistance to Saudi Arabia in Yemen's civil war.

"The Senate voted 55-44 to table a binding resolution that directs the Pentagon to cut off all support for the Saudi-led coalition fighting Houthi rebels in Yemen, including providing weapons, sharing targeting information and refueling warplanes. The conflict is widely considered a proxy war with Iran and has become a humanitarian disaster.

"The vote to table it came on the same day Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman met with members of Congress and President Donald Trump at the White House."

** A message from the Schar School of Policy and Government, GMU: "The Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University provided me a huge leg up on issues of operations, strategy, national security, and counter-terrorism that will make me much more competitive in my field" - Paul Helfgott, Student, Master's in Public Policy. Discover the Schar School difference at schar.gmu.edu. **

FIRST ON PRO: HOUSE BILL TACKLES AI -- Rep. Elise Stefanik is out with a new bill aimed at helping the Pentagon wrap its arms around the issue of artificial intelligence and its future impact on warfare, our colleague from Pro Cybersecurity Martin Matishak reports.

The measure from Stefanik, who chairs HASC's Emerging Threats and Capabilities subpanel, would establish an independent commission to help ensure America doesn't lag behind countries like China and Russia in the bleeding-edge field, which national security leaders have been warning lawmakers about in recent weeks. "We need to make sure that our adversaries do not leap beyond us," Stefanik said in an interview on Tuesday.

The panel would, among others things, study how the military is using AI and whether the government is working effectively with the private sector to develop the industry.

The New York Republican predicts the legislation would attract the support of HASC leaders, as well as other subcommittee chairs, and be incorporated into to the National Defense Authorization Act.

The full story for Pros is here.

SOUTH KOREA'S MOON FLOATS THREE-WAY KOREA TALKS, via The New York Times: "President Moon Jae-in of South Korea said on Wednesday that he and President Trump could sit down for a three-way summit meeting with Kim Jong-un if their individual meetings with the North Korean leader on denuclearizing his country proceed well in the coming weeks.

"Mr. Moon and Mr. Kim are planning an inter-Korean summit in late April at Peace House, a South Korean conference hall inside Panmunjom, the so-called truce village that straddles the Demilitarized Zone, or DMZ, separating the two Koreas."

But North Korea warns its detractors, while noting an "atmosphere for reconciliation" ahead of talks, via The Washington Post.

INDUSTRY INTEL -- WILSON DINGS BOEING ON TANKER DELAYS, via Connor: "Air Force Secretary Heather Wilson [Tuesday] knocked aerospace giant Boeing over further delays in the new KC-46 aerial refueling tanker.

"'Boeing is saying that they're going to deliver in the second quarter of '18,' Wilson told the House Armed Services Committee. 'The Air Force thinks it's going to be late '18, and Boeing has been overly optimistic on all of their schedule reports.'...

"Responding, Boeing said in a statement: 'There is no greater priority at The Boeing Company right now than the delivery of the KC-46. Boeing has continued to demonstrate its commitment to deliver the tankers as soon as possible and believes in our partnership with the US Air Force.'"

results.title: New CDC chief expected to be announced today
results.body:
OMNIBUS DELAYED AS FRIDAY SHUTDOWN LOOMS -- The rollout of a $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill was held up Tuesday night after talks between Capitol Hill negotiators and the White House moved slowly. The bill contains fiscal 2018 spending levels and has to pass by Friday to keep the government running -- or lawmakers need to hammer out a short-term funding patch. (There have already been five continuing resolutions.)

Why the delay? Immigration has been one of the biggest sticking points, with Republicans and Democrats trading offers across Tuesday.

NEW CDC CHIEF EXPECTED TO BE ANNOUNCED TODAY -- Robert Redfield, the Baltimore-based AIDS researcher, is the Trump administration's choice. POLITICO on Friday scooped that Redfield was favored for the role.

-- Critics point to Redfield's record in AIDS research. Specifically, they seize on an episode more than 20 years ago, when Redfield oversaw a failed effort at Walter Reed to develop an AIDS vaccine. A whistle-blower who came forward this week said Redfield's handling of study data left questions about his trustworthiness. The Army later acknowledged there were accuracy issues with Redfield's work, but it didn't find misconduct.

"Either he was egregiously sloppy with data or it was fabricated," former Air Force Lt. Col. Craig Hendrix, a doctor who is now at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, told Kaiser Health News. More.

-- But Elijah Cummings gave a vote of support. The Maryland Democrat says he fully supports "this deeply experienced and compassionate public health physician."

"Although I seldom agree with the Trump administration, I am in complete agreement that Dr. Bob Redfield is the best choice to lead the CDC," Cummings said in a statement. "Bob has devoted his life to improving the public health, including leading PEPFAR efforts around the world and as the clinical head of the Institute of Human Virology in Baltimore fighting the HIV and Hepatitis C epidemics in this region."

** A message from PhRMA: Analysis finds commercially insured patients at 340B hospitals are prescribed more medicines and/or more expensive medicines. This may result in higher cost sharing and higher premiums if the hospital does not pass the 340B discounts through to the patient or the payer. Let's fix the 340B program. http://politi.co/2IqKpF3 **

TRUMP CAN EXECUTE DRUG DEALERS ALREADY -- The state execution of drug smugglers that President Donald Trump has touted as a major part of his plan to combat the opioid crisis is already legal under a 1994 law passed at the height of the crack cocaine epidemic. But in 24 years, federal prosecutors have never once used it, POLITICO's Arthur Allen writes.

They hardly need to, considering the draconian penalties already available for punishing convicted drug smugglers. But even the most aggressive prosecutors believed the death penalty for these cases would be found to violate the Eighth Amendment prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment, experts said. More for Pros.

-- Meanwhile: Many Americans oppose the idea. That's according to a Morning Consult/POLITICO poll of nearly 2,000 voters, out this morning. While 47 percent of respondents favored the death penalty for people convicted of large scale drug trafficking, only 29 percent of voters favor the death penalty for people convicted of local drug dealing.

WELCOME TO WEDNESDAY PULSE -- Where the late-night Illinois returns had a couple of nuggets for health wonks. Rep. Dan Lipinski hung on in his primary -- despite fierce challenges from abortion-rights groups -- and Lauren Underwood, ex-HHS staffer, emerged as the Democratic challenger to Rep. Randy Hultgren.

The political news in Washington takes a brief backseat this morning to weather updates. Stay safe today, PULSE readers. And send tips to ddiamond@politico.com or @ddiamond on Twitter.

With help from Sarah Karlin-Smith (@SarahKarlin) and David Pittman (@David_Pittman).

HHS SAYS HOSPITALS' DEMAND FOR 340B PAYMENTS IMPOSSIBLE -- The agency on Tuesday argued in appellate court that it's technically not feasible to reverse its $1.6 billion in cuts to the 340B drug discount program.

-- According to the Trump administration brief , the funds already were redistributed to all hospitals' outpatient services. That means reversing the cuts would force Medicare to reprocess a large chunk of the 100 million hospital outpatient claims it annually pays, which the agency says would wreak havoc on its operations and providers. HHS made a similar argument to a lower court in December, and it said Congress also outlined in law that Medicare's hospital payment rates couldn't be challenged in court, a legal barrier that invalidates the hospitals' 340B lawsuit. HHS's arguments.

-- Details on the case: Hospitals are challenging the Trump administration's rule cutting payments for certain drugs in the program by 28.5 percent, arguing that the move flouts congressional intent for 340B program. A hearing in the case is scheduled for May 4.

TUNE IN: Join POLITICO online this morning for a conversation on how to provide high-quality care at lower costs to a growing population of aging Americans. Tune in to "Avoiding 911 - How to Improve Health Care in Nursing Homes and Bend the Cost Curve" at 8:00 a.m. Watch live here.

HOW HHS VIEWS OPIOID TREATMENT DRUGS -- POLITICO's Sarah Karlin-Smith dug into why Trump's opioid plan singled out naltrexone as a treatment for opioid-addicted prisoners, given that a federally funded study recently found that naltrexone and the much cheaper buprenorphine were similarly effective in treating opioid addiction.

Alex Azar: Naltrexone is 'best option' for opioid treatment in prison, post-detox. That's what the HHS secretary told reporters on Tuesday, although he added that HHS supports all forms of FDA-approved medication assisted therapy, especially for different populations.

Asked why the president's opioid plan specifically mentioned only naltrexone (Alkermes' Vivitrol), Azar initially said he believed it was an oversight, before offering an update that the preference came from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Administration.

-- Meanwhile, the NIH's National Institute on Drug Abuse doesn't "favor one drug over the other" given different patient responses and ongoing research into treatment, said director Nora Volkow.

And speaking of the NIH...

An opioid vaccine in the works? That's what Volkow said on Tuesday, noting that vaccines against heroin and fentanyl have been successful in animals and the NIH is working to bring them to humans.

What Francis Collins shared: Thirty-three companies also have expressed interest in working with NIH to develop non-opioid, non-addictive alternatives to treat pain, said Collins, adding that an in-development work plan would "involve sharing of information in very unprecedented ways." NIH is also trying to develop a biomarker to measure pain, so caregivers don't have to rely on "smiley face" assessments from patients rating their pain.

AZAR SAYS HIS DRUG PRICING PLAN WILL BE DIFFERENT -- For one, Azar noted he wasn't at HHS when previous proposals were laid out by the White House and the agency.

He added that the plan teased by the White House this week will include "additional actions as well as thoughts and request for input," which could signal formal requests for information or advanced notices of proposed rulemaking. Azar says he's aiming to tackle two issues - getting the best net price deals for government programs and private insurers as well as bringing list prices down after years of increases. But no other hints on specific policies from the HHS secretary, Sarah reports.

Family doctors to HHS: We're worried about push for 'conscience' expansion. That's what American Academy of Family Physicians board chair John Meigs, Jr., writes to HHS Secretary Alex Azar, offering comment on the agency's new Conscience and Religious Freedom Division.

HHS has said its new Conscience and Religious Freedom Division is necessary to protect health care workers from being compelled to participate in medical procedures that violate their religious or moral beliefs.

While AAFP supports physicians declining to participate in a procedure, with adequate notice, the organization doesn't support denying access to care to an individual patient on religious, ethical or moral grounds. Failing to provide that access is "an unacceptable shirking of our basic responsibility to care for our patients and contrary to the key underpinnings of the Code of Medical Ethics," Meigs wrote. Read letter.

Polls: Health care remains top issue heading into midterms. That's according to new survey data from the left-leaning Public Policy Polling, which finds that at least two-thirds of voters in key battleground states Arizona, Nevada, Pennsylvania, Tennessee and Wisconsin all scored health care as a top priority issue heading into upcoming elections. See the memo.

Acosta rolls out training grants for opioid victims. Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta traveled to Columbus, Ohio, on Tuesday to announce $21 million in job training grants for victims of the opioid epidemic, DOL officials said. The grants, first reported by POLITICO, will fund seven to 10 programs to fund job training for people affected by the crisis. More for Pros.

Georgetown adds faculty to McCourt School. Professors Donald Moynihan and Pamela Herd, a research team from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, are joining the five-year-old public policy school. Moynihan, an expert in public management and budgeting, will be Georgetown's first McCourt Chair. Herd, an aging policy expert, is the principal investigator of the Wisconsin Longitudinal Study. More.

** A message from PhRMA: Created a quarter of a century ago, the 340B program is greatly in need of a number of fixes to ensure it is targeted toward true safety-net entities and vulnerable or uninsured patients as intended when the program was developed. Independent economists, GAO and OIG have all raised concerns with the program and Congress has now echoed those concerns. Too many hospitals are profiting off a program meant to support needy patients. Learn why now is the time to fix the 340B program and how members of Congress are leading the charge through new legislation. http://politi.co/2IqKpF3 **

results.title: Omni train is still in the station
results.body:
With help from Stephanie Beasley and Brianna Gurciullo

OMNI TRAIN IS STILL IN THE STATION: With the clock ticking down to a Friday deadline to keep the federal government's doors open, a final deal on an omnibus package is still elusive, leading to speculation that a short-term continuing resolution may ultimately be necessary. A handful of thorny issues continue to dog the bill -- one of which is, you guessed it, the $900 million in Gateway funding over which President Donald Trump has threatened a veto. When asked Tuesday about Trump's opposition to funding Gateway, spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders responded: "The president specifically wants to address infrastructure on a broader scale, not put all our emphasis into one project. We certainly want to see the infrastructure across this country rebuilt, which is why we put forward priorities when it comes to that in a plan moving forward." When asked Tuesday about Trump's opposition to funding Gateway, spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders responded: "The president specifically wants to address infrastructure on a broader scale, not put all our emphasis into one project. We certainly want to see the infrastructure across this country rebuilt, which is why we put forward priorities when it comes to that in a plan moving forward."

Waiting for Godot: For his part, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has kept his powder dry on the $900 million New York and New Jersey lawmakers want to steer toward the mega-project as part of the omnibus, repeatedly refusing in recent days to go beyond voicing support for it. "I'm not gonna get into a back and forth with the president," Schumer told reporters Tuesday when asked why Trump has objected to the Gateway funding.

DON'T FAA-GET ABOUT ME: An FAA extension is still in play, but Sen. John Thune told reporters Tuesday its fate was linked to other items jockeying for position in the spending package. Your Pro Transpo team had an afternoon status update, but remember: It ain't over 'til it's over.

Gut check: POLITICO's Sarah Ferris has a quick breakdown of what was undecided -- and what was likely out -- as of Tuesday afternoon. You can probably guess where our two issues fell.

IT'S A WINTRY WEDNESDAY: Thanks for tuning in to POLITICO's Morning Transportation, your daily tipsheet on all things trains, planes, automobiles and ports. Lauren's back, so send your scoops, tips, sunbeams, spring weather and song requests here: lgardner@politico.com or @Gardner_LM.

"Gonna grab me a freight train and ride it all night long / Tomorrow morning daddy, I'll be gone, long gone" (h/t Allison Fultz of Kaplan Kirsch Rockwell)

LISTEN HERE: Follow MT's playlist on Spotify. What better way to start your day than with songs (picked by us and readers) about roads, rails and runways?

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

HOPE SPRINGS ETERNAL: Schumer said Tuesday that he hopes Congress passes an infrastructure package before the midterm elections. "We Democrats have put together a great infrastructure bill -- a trillion dollars, 10 million new jobs. Roads, bridges, sewer, water and new things like rural broadband," Schumer said. "We paid for our bill. The president didn't. Even if he doesn't go for our bill -- and I hope he will at the end of the day, as they see their tax breaks are not so popular and people prefer middle-class jobs -- but we certainly hope they'll put something real on the table."

** A message from the Partnership for Open and Fair Skies: The UAE and Qatar have funneled billions of dollars in government subsidies to their state-owned airline carriers, threatening 1.2 million American jobs and our entire aviation industry. More than 310 members of Congress agree that it's time to enforce our agreements and protect American jobs. http://www.openandfairskies.com/ **

CHUGGING ALONG: FRA posted fourth-quarter 2017 data Tuesday on railroads' progress toward implementing positive train control, showing that freights are still significantly further along than their passenger rail counterparts. Fifty-six percent of freight-owned route miles were PTC-operable by the end of 2017, compared to just 24 percent (the same as in the third quarter of that year) on the passenger side. Fifteen of the 41 railroads subject to the mandate reported having all necessary PTC hardware installed; another 12 are at least 75 percent done. Read through the tables here.

Us too: Meanwhile, NJ Transit officials said Tuesday they think they're making good headway on complying with the mandate, the initial deadline for which is Dec. 31. The agency met with officials from FRA, Amtrak, Metro-North and Conrail last week, POLITICO New Jersey's Ryan Hutchins writes. "I think they were pleasantly surprised with what we came with: a plan for how we're going to do that," Executive Director Kevin Corbett said.

Give us the deets: Thune and Sen. Bill Nelson, his Democratic counterpart on the Commerce Committee, sent a letter to FRA Administrator Ron Batory Tuesday asking the agency to divulge "detailed" descriptions of its plans to review PTC safety plans, test waivers and revenue service demonstration applications. They also pressed FRA to describe how it will provide guidance to railroads on alternative criteria passenger outfits could meet to qualify for extensions, as well as how regulators expect to handle any that don't qualify for a grace period.

IG REVIEW REQUESTED FOR BRIDGE COLLAPSE: Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao wants a DOT inspector general probe into the pedestrian bridge collapse in Florida. Chao wrote in a memo that the IG should "examine whether the project owner" -- Florida International University's board of trustees -- "and the design-build team and contractors responsible for the design, planning, construction, installation and testing of the FIU pedestrian bridge complied with all specifications and requirements applicable to this project by virtue of the department's provision of federal funding." Florida Sen. Bill Nelson asked the IG to include him on the request and to also evaluate how the Florida Department of Transportation and DOT oversaw the project.

Quick draw: Inspector General Calvin Scovel III promptly responded to Nelson Tuesday. "Given its safety sensitivity, we have made this matter a top priority and expect to formally announce the scope and objectives of our review and begin our audit work as soon as possible," he wrote.

Document dump: The Associated Press obtained documents showing that a design change made to the structure contributed to the project being behind schedule and over budget. "Though it is still unclear if the design change played a role in the failure, emails between the school, contractors, officials with the city of Sweetwater and permitting agencies show a project that ended up behind schedule, which had officials worried that further delays could jeopardize millions in federal Department of Transportation funds" through the TIGER program, the AP reported Tuesday. Another source of delays, per the report, was a "bottleneck" at the Army Corps of Engineers, which had stopped doling out permits due to budget cuts.

BARKLEY'S NEWS CORNER: United Airlines announced Tuesday that it's suspending its animal shipment service while it conducts "a thorough and systematic review" over the next six weeks. The airline's PetSafe program is tailored toward animals that can't travel in a plane's cabin -- The Washington Post writes that the German shepherd that flew to Japan instead of Kansas City last week was transported under that program. Meanwhile, Delta Air Lines got in on the Homeward Bound action over the weekend by sending a puppy to three different cities before finally delivering it to the correct destination, Fox 5 NY reports.

TSA: NO HAT TRICK HERE: TSA said that it can't provide any documentation about its protocols for searching data on air travelers' cell phones because there isn't any. The agency on Tuesday sent a letter to the ACLU, which requested the records via a Freedom of Information Act request, saying that it would not be possible to provide that information because it did not exist, our Stephanie Beasley writes. An ACLU branch is suing TSA for initially failing to respond to the FOIA request.

Too legit to quit: The ACLU Foundation of Northern California said it has received reports of TSA screeners searching travelers' portable devices and isn't yet convinced those reports were inaccurate. "While TSA says they are not searching the contents of electronic devices, they haven't provided documents to back that up," said Vasudha Talla, the staff attorney for that office. "The public deserves all available information about what isn't considered a permissible search by TSA."

MORNING SHIFT THEFT -- CASSIDY OUT AT DHS: Ben Cassidy, assistant secretary for legislative affairs at DHS, left his position last week, three current and former department officials told Morning Shift. A DHS spokesman confirmed the departure, but didn't provide additional detail.

-- "Toyota takes self-driving cars off road after Uber accident." The New York Times.

-- "Senators press car executives, regulator on explosive air bags." The Wall Street Journal.

-- "Orbitz hack may have compromised 880,000 credit cards." Bloomberg.

-- "Arizona says not time to rein in self-driving cars after Uber fatality." Reuters.

-- "Uber has hired Tammy Albarran, who helped lead the investigation into the company's culture, to replace its deputy general counsel." Recode.

-- "Ousted Uber boss Travis Kalanick returns. He'll be developing parking lots." USA Today.

THE COUNTDOWN: DOT appropriations run out in 3 days. The FAA reauthorization expires in 11 days. Highway and transit policy is up for renewal in 925 days.

Did we miss an event? Let MT know at transpocalendar@politicopro.com.

** A message from the Partnership for Open and Fair Skies: The UAE and Qatar have sent more than $50 billion in government subsidies to their state-owned airlines - Emirates, Etihad Airways, Qatar Airways. We applaud the Trump administration for reaching an historic agreement with Qatar to enforce our Open Skies agreement and stand up for American jobs. Now it's time for the UAE to play by the rules and bring an end to their subsidy-fueled expansion campaign. The future of the U.S. airline industry and 1.2 million American workers depends on it. http://www.openandfairskies.com/ **

results.title: Rauner, Pritzker set for historic clash in Illinois
results.body:
With Kevin Robillard, Zach Montellaro and Daniel Strauss

The following newsletter is an abridged version of Campaign Pro's Morning Score. For an earlier morning read on exponentially more races -- and for a more comprehensive aggregation of the day's most important campaign news -- sign up for Campaign Pro today. (http://www.politicopro.com/proinfo)

ILLINOIS RESULTS -- Bruce Rauner and Dan Lipinski barely held on. J.B. Pritzker romped. And we were waiting well into the night for results out of DuPage County.

-- "Lipinski beats Newman in Illinois Democratic slugfest," by Campaign Pro's Elena Schneider and Daniel Strauss: "Rep. Dan Lipinski, an avid foe of abortion rights and one of the most conservative Democrats in the House, fended off a fierce challenge from the left on Tuesday night in Illinois, all but assuring an eighth term in Congress."

-- Illinois voters also set the stage for the most expensive gubernatorial race in the nation's history. Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner narrowly defeated state legislator Jeanne Ives, 52 to 48 percent. It was a surprisingly strong showing for Ives, who attacked Rauner as insufficiently conservative, and a worrisome sign for the incumbent governor. Billionaire J.B. Pritzker, who sunk $70 million into his bid, easily clinched the Democratic nomination against several liberal opponents.

IL-04: 2015 Chicago mayor candidate Chuy Garcia easily won the Democratic nomination to replace retiring Rep. Luis Guti√©rrez.

IL-06: As of 5:30 a.m. Eastern, Kelly Mazeski held a 260-vote lead over Sean Casten in the Democratic primary to take on GOP Rep. Peter Roskam. But a significant number of precincts were still not reporting in DuPage County, which cited "certain technical difficulties ... in closing the precincts, unrelated to the Ballot Tabulation" for the delay.

IL-10: Consultant Doug Bennett narrowly captured the GOP nomination to face Democratic Rep. Brad Schneider. Bennett defeated attorney Jeremy Wynes by just 259 votes.

IL-12: St. Clair County State's Attorney Brendan Kelly cruised to the Democratic nomination and will face GOP Rep. Mike Bost in November. Story

IL-13: Betsy Dirksen Londrigan will face GOP Rep. Rodney Davis in the fall. Story

IL-14: Lauren Underwood swamped the Democratic field and advanced to a general election with GOP Rep. Randy Hultgren. Story

See full results here.

-- "Top takeaways from the Illinois primary," by POLITICO's Natasha Korecki: 1) The Pritzker steamroller; 2) Lipinski's ace in the hole; 3) Bruce Rauner's in big trouble in November; 4) The Chicago machine is humming; 5) Democratic energy is surging. Full story.

DEADLINE -- "Filing closes for Pennsylvania congressional races," by POLITICO's Elena Schneider: "House candidates in Pennsylvania completed filing for their newly drawn districts on Tuesday, settling a map that was upended by the state Supreme Court earlier this year when it ruled the old map unconstitutional. National and local operatives believe that the new map, drawn by a court-ordered special master in January, will give Democrats an advantage in flipping a handful of seats in 2018, aiding their effort to retake the majority in Congress. Republicans appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court to stop the imposition of the new map, but the court denied that request earlier this week. ... A whopping 14 Democrats are now running for Republican Rep. Pat Meehan's now-open seat (PA-05), which will likely turn into a safely Democratic seat under the new lines." Full story.

FIRST IN SCORE -- DSCC raises $5.1 million in February: The DSCC raised $5.1 million in February and has $25.7 million on hand. It had $22 million on hand at the end of January, and has no remaining campaign debt. It does have over $4 million in debt from the mortgage on its Capitol Hill building.

-- "DCCC raised $10.6M in February," by Elena Schneider: "The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee announced it raised $10.6 million last month -- its highest total for an election-year February ever. The DCCC has $49 million in cash on hand. This cycle, the committee has raised $125 million." Full story.

-- "NRCC raises $10.5M in February," Schneider reports: "The National Republican Congressional Committee raised $10.5 million last month, according to a filing with the Federal Election Commission today, coming just short of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee's February total." Full story.

-- Also of note: The RNC spent a whopping $200,000 for venue rental and catering at the Trump National Doral Miami last month.

Days until the 2018 election: 231

Upcoming election dates -- Indiana, Ohio, North Carolina and West Virginia primaries: May 8.

UP ON AIR -- "AFP starts airing ads against Heitkamp," by POLITICO's Kevin Robillard: "Americans for Prosperity is spending $450,000 on television and digital ads in North Dakota to criticize Democratic Sen. Heidi Heitkamp for voting against the Republican tax reform plan. The ads are the first significant spending by the powerful Koch Brothers network of conservative donors against Heitkamp. Groups backed by the network have already spent millions attacking Sens. Claire McCaskill (D-Mo.), Joe Donnelly (D-Ind.) and Tammy Baldwin (D-Wis.). The 30-second ad features a female narrator describing how Heitkamp 'took hundreds of thousands from well-connected special interests and then gave special interests billions in taxpayer handouts.'" Full story.

-- Senate Majority PAC airs 2nd ad hitting Hawley over Greitens: Senate Majority PAC is out with its second television ad attacking Republican Attorney General Josh Hawley over his investigation of scandal-tarred GOP Gov. Eric Greitens. "Attorney General Josh Hawley came to the governor's rescue, declaring him innocent," the narrator declares in the ad. "All Missourians should be worried. And we should be asking ourselves: Is Josh Hawley bought and paid for?" Watch the ad.

-- "DeWine ad hits Taylor as 'unfit and unqualified'" by Campaign Pro's Daniel Strauss: "A new 30-second ad from Ohio state Attorney General Mike DeWine's gubernatorial campaign hits Lt. Gov. Mary Taylor as unfit for the governorship. The ad, first obtained by POLITICO, is the first negative ad the DeWine campaign has released. The campaign plans to spend about $670,000 on the ad. The campaign is also unveiling an accompanying website to the ad." Full story. Watch the DeWine ad here.

-- "Pro-Taylor group hits DeWine in new ad" by Daniel: "A political committee supporting Ohio Lt. Gov. Mary Taylor in the state's gubernatorial race has released a new 30-second ad casting state Attorney General Mike DeWine's record as in conflict with President Donald Trump on 'immigration, guns and China.' 'If you like President Trump, then you won't like Mike DeWine,' says a narrator in the ad, sponsored by the group Onward Ohio." Full story. Watch the ad here.

RESIGNATION WATCH -- "Farenthold weighs resigning from Congress," by POLITICO's Jake Sherman, Rachael Bade and John Bresnahan: "Texas GOP Rep. Blake Farenthold is considering stepping down from Congress before the end of his term, according to multiple Republican sources with direct knowledge of private party conversations. Full story.

POLL -- Brown leads Renacci, Gibbons in Senate race, per Cleveland.com: Sen. Sherrod Brown holds a lead over two possible opponents in the Senate race, according to a poll conducted by Baldwin Wallace University's Community Research Institute. Brown leads Ohio Rep. Jim Renacci with 41 percent of the vote to 29 percent of the vote. In a race against banker Mike Gibbons, Brown leads with 41 percent of the vote to Gibbons' 31 percent of the vote. Baldwin Wallace polled 1,011 registered voters between February 28 and March 9. The margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points. Read more from Cleveland.com here.

INCOMING -- "Mississippi governor expected to appoint Hyde-Smith to Senate seat," by Strauss and Burgess Everett: "Mississippi Gov. Phil Bryant is expected to appoint state Agriculture Commissioner Cindy Hyde-Smith to the Senate seat being vacated next month by GOP Sen. Thad Cochran, according to multiple Republicans with knowledge of the governor's plans. Bryant has narrowed his shortlist in recent days. He said Monday that he wouldn't appoint Lt. Gov. Tate Reeves to the seat, leaving Hyde-Smith and Secretary of State Delbert Hosemann as the two most commonly mentioned names." Full story.

-- How do Republicans feel about the appointment? Expect the party establishments in both D.C. and Mississippi to line up behind Hyde-Smith after her appointment today. But that doesn't mean there isn't any grumbling. Hyde-Smith was a Democrat until 2010, and voted in the 2008 Democratic primary, which Bryant and his team believe won't be an issue in her race against state Sen. Chris McDaniel and Democrat Mike Espy. D.C. Republicans are more skeptical, but trust Bryant's judgment, noting he's personally interviewed and vetted each potential senator. Full story.

ENDORSEMENT WATCH -- "Gillibrand endorses Cuomo for governor" by Politico's Burgess Everett: "Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand is endorsing New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo over challenger Cynthia Nixon, the New York Democrat said in an interview Tuesday. And she hinted that Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer will join her in supporting the incumbent. ... "Gov. Cuomo and I are friends. But he also has done some amazing things for New York, such as passing paid leave in our state, passing marriage equality and working to end sexual violence on our college campuses," Gillibrand said. Asked what Schumer will do in the race, she replied: "You'll have to ask him. I'm sure he'll do the same." Full story.

-- Democrats short of 70 percent on Chamber scorecard: Entering the 2018 Senate cycle, Democratic Sens. Joe Manchin, Donnelly and Heidi Heitkamp all had records warranting close to the 70 percent score that earns a reelection endorsement from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. But all three ended up with identical 53 percent scores in 2017, according to the new Chamber scorecard released Tuesday. Heitkamp now has a 68 percent lifetime score, while Manchin is at 58 percent and Donnelly is at 65 percent. One Democrat running for Senate, Arizona Rep. Kyrsten Sinema, has a 75 percent score in 2017 and 76 percent lifetime score. But one of her potential GOP opponents, Rep. Martha McSally, had a 93 percent in 2017 and a 98 percent lifetime. Reminder: The U.S. Chamber spent zero dollars backing Democrats during the 2016 elections. See the full scorecard here.

WEB WARS -- Sinema out with two positive digital ads: Sinema is out with two digital ads, her first advertising of her Arizona Senate run. The first ad, featuring Sinema's older brother, a police officer and former Marine, plays up her independence. The second ad portrays Sinema as a nonpartisan problem solver. Watch the ads here and here.

And I can see from their look, they're like, 'You're going to f -- ing lose this thing. There's no way you're going to pull this off,'" Rep. Beto O'Rourke told POLITICO in the latest Off Message podcast.

results.title: Ex-Playboy model's lawyer says her coming forward has nothing to do with politics
results.body:
The lawyer representing former Playboy model Karen McDougal says his client's decision to speak out about her alleged affair with President Donald Trump has nothing to do with politics.

"Let me be clear," Peter Stris said. "Karen is a Republican. She voted for the president. She holds no ill will. If there was ever a case that was not motivated by naked politics, it's this one."

Stris added that McDougal is looking to "get out from under the thumb" of American Media Inc. -- the parent company of the National Enquirer and several other tabloid publications -- which Stris says has "effectively controlled her life for over a year."

"What she wants is to correct the lies that AMI has told about her motivations, her honesty," he added. "She does not want publicity."

McDougal alleges that she had an affair with Trump spanning 10 months in 2006 -- a relationship that Stris says was "consensual" and "important" to her.

She is now suing American Media Inc., claiming that she was misled about the details of the $150,000 contract she signed when she sold them her story. AMI, however, argues that McDougal has been free to respond to legitimate press inquiries about her relationship with Trump since 2016.

"Now AMI takes the position that she can [speak out], and we're thrilled," Stris said. "But the reality is, their private position is very different and for over a year, they've made her terrified," suggesting significant monetary damages should McDougal breach her contract.

CNN's Anderson Cooper is slated to interview McDougal on Thursday.

results.title: Senate Intelligence election security ideas encounter first test today
results.body:
With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and John Hendel

KICKING THE TIRES -- The Senate Intelligence Committee convenes this morning to get feedback on its raft of bipartisan election security recommendations, unveiled Tuesday. At the hearing, the proposals -- which range from specific measures like creating a voluntary state grant program to high-level guidance such as enhancing cyber threat information sharing between D.C. and the states -- will be put to the test via current and former Department of Homeland Security leaders, state election administrators and national election experts.

But early returns from the election community are encouraging. While many of the proposals looked familiar -- reflecting not only the persistent advice of cyber and election security experts but even a pre-existing Senate bill -- that's not necessarily a bad thing, said former DHS Deputy Secretary Jane Holl Lute, now president at security firm SICPA. "I'm not disappointed that it's predictable," she told MC. "Some things that are obvious need saying, and they need to be said by authoritative voices."

States, too -- sometimes resistant to federal election security assistance as potentially intrusive of their turf -- were mostly positive. "I think it's not just a step in the right direction but a timely one," Alex Padilla, California's Democratic secretary of state, told MC. "The sense of urgency is clear to secretaries of state across the country, and I'm hoping this is an indicator that it's not just important but urgent for Congress to act as well." Maria Benson, a spokeswoman for the National Association of Secretaries of State, told MC that states "are already implementing many, if not all," of the panel's recommendations, as her organization will testify today.

It's not all sunny, though. "One glaring omission is any call for voting system vendors and service contractors to take more responsibility for systems security, including periodically subjecting their code and maintenance systems to independent third-party security testing and providing those results to state election officials," said Bruce McConnell, a former DHS deputy undersecretary for cybersecurity and global vice president for the EastWest Institute.

At today's hearing, former DHS Secretary Jeh Johnson will talk about the conflicts he encountered when, in the waning days of the Obama administration in 2017, he designated election systems as "critical infrastructure." The move, intended to elevate election security as a federal priority, initially encountered strong resistance from states but has become less controversial since. "The 2018 midterm elections are now upon us. The first primaries in the 2020 presidential election are less than two years away," his written testimony states. "I am pleased that state election officials, to various degrees, now seem to be taking serious steps to fortify the cybersecurity of their election infrastructure, and that the Department of Homeland Security is currently taking serious steps to work with state and local election officials to strengthen their cybersecurity."

HAPPY WEDNESDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! A friend recently asked your MC host what mount he would ride into combat. I picked elephant. She picked rhino. I win. Send your thoughts, feedback and especially tips to tstarks@politico.com and be sure to follow @POLITICOPro and @MorningCybersec. Full team info below.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

FIRST ON PRO: HOUSE BILL TACKLES AI -- Rep. Elise Stefanik is out with a new bill aimed at helping the Pentagon wrap its arms around the issue of artificial intelligence and its future impact on warfare, Martin reports. The measure from Stefanik, who chairs the House Armed Services Emerging Threats and Capabilities subpanel, would establish an independent commission to help ensure America doesn't lag behind countries like China and Russia in the bleeding-edge field, which national security leaders have been warning lawmakers about in recent weeks. "We need to make sure that our adversaries do not leap beyond us," Stefanik said in an interview on Tuesday.

The panel would, among others things, study how the military is using AI, and whether the government is working effectively with the private sector to develop the industry. Stefanik, who also sits on the Intelligence Committee, noted that the Defense Department has working groups examining AI, but stressed, "it's clear that we need to do more."

The New York Republican predicted the legislation would attract the support of the leaders of the House Armed Services Committee, as well as other subpanel chairs, and be incorporated into to the military's annual policy bill, the National Defense Authorization Act. Pros can read the full story here.

BIPARTISANSHIP ON CDM, SORT OF -- Democrats said at a joint House committee hearing Tuesday that they wanted to see more progress on a Homeland Security Department program to strengthen federal agency cyber defenses. Their comments, at a hearing of Homeland Security and Oversight subpanels, mirrored Republican complaints about the Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation program. But Democrats were more willing to point the finger at the Trump administration for some of CDM's sluggishness. In a written statement, top House Homeland Security Democrat Bennie Thompson said agencies needed better training on some of the cybersecurity tools offered through the program, and still need a "full accounting" of devices connected to these networks.

"These obstacles are compounded by the staggering number of cyber vacancies throughout the federal government, both for rank-and-file civil servants, as well as key leadership positions," Thompson added. Rep. Gerry Connolly, a member of the Oversight Committee, said at the hearing that Trump budgets have been insufficient for the program and that has "impeded development."

DOE, A FAMILIAR QUESTION FOR YOU -- Leaders of the Senate Energy panel on Tuesday cajoled the Energy Department to do more on cybersecurity, from leading the way on responding to Russian grid hacks to boosting funding for its cyber operations. Secretary Rick Perry touted a newly established Energy cyber office and a requested budget increase as evidence the department understands it's an important subject. But the panel's top Democrat panned the moves as insufficient. "Establishing a new DOE cyber office with marginal [budget] increases is not a substitute for the meaningful action we need," said ranking member Maria Cantwell. "We don't need rhetoric at this point, we need action."

Panel Chairwoman Lisa Murkowski was more generous about the new office, saying she was "intrigued." Still, Murkowski expressed concerns about DOE's response to the recent government alert about Russian government hackers targeting the U.S. energy industry. Perry tried to assure her: "We work very closely with the Department of Homeland Security."

Cantwell also said a Trump administration-requested 10 percent budget increase on cybersecurity probably isn't enough for fiscal 2019. Cantwell has called for a doubling of cybersecurity funding, but said that proposal might still be too small. "My concern is we still don't have an assessment," she said. "If we don't have a risk assessment, how do we know what we are really budgeting towards?" Perry said discussions about such an assessment ongoing, adding that some cybersecurity-related funding is going up more than Cantwell mentioned, such as a 30 percent boost in funds to manage massive amounts of DOE data. In the past year, Cantwell has asked three times about when a cyber risk assessment might be finished.

R IS FOR RESILIENCE -- The government's tech standards-setting agency is publishing a handbook today to help organizations develop more cyber-resilient systems. The document -- from the National Institute of Standards and Technology -- is the first in a series of supplements to an earlier publication on secure systems engineering, and it focuses on cyber-specific considerations for manufacturing and product design.

Like NIST's popular cyber framework, the new publication is a high-level walkthrough of important considerations and not a step-by-step guide for developing secure systems. "It can be viewed as a handbook for achieving the identified cyber resiliency outcomes based on a systems engineering perspective," NIST said in the document.

YET ANOTHER BREACH -- Leading travel booking site Orbitz recently discovered a possible data breach affecting 880,000 payment cards, the company announced Tuesday. On March 1, Orbitz, a subsidiary of Expedia, discovered evidence that hackers may have "accessed personal information" on a legacy platform between Oct. 1 and Dec. 22, according to a statement. The affected data included personal information submitted during purchases made between January 2016 and December 2017. "Information that was likely accessed may include full name, payment card information, date of birth, phone number, email address, physical and/or billing address and gender," the company said. However, it added, "We do not have direct evidence that this personal information was actually taken from the platform."

Orbitz said it bolstered the "security and monitoring of the affected platform" and hired "a leading third-party forensic investigation firm and other cybersecurity experts" to investigate the potential breach. Affected users will receive one year of free credit monitoring services.

PRIVACY GROUPS PUT PRESSURE ON FTC'S FACEBOOK PROBE -- Per our friends at Morning Tech: A collection of privacy organizations including EPIC and the Center for Digital Democracy are throwing their backing behind the FTC's probe of Facebook's potential violations of a 2011 agreement it made with the agency. Facebook is confronting a firestorm of criticism for failing to prevent Cambridge Analytica from allegedly compiling a cache of data drawn from the social media profiles of some 50 million Americans. Under a 2011 consent decree with the FTC, Facebook agreed to get express permission and notify users before sharing their data with third parties. The social network could face massive fines if the FTC determines it violated the terms of the agreement. The agency has begun a review of Facebook's adherence to the consent decree, according to a source familiar with the matter.

"Facebook's transfer of personal data to Cambridge Analytica was prohibited by the 2011 Facebook Order," the groups argue. "My view, based on what has been publicly disclosed, is that Cambridge Analytica's acquisition of personal information from as many as 50 million Facebook users likely violated Facebook's consent decree with the FTC," said David Vladeck, a former director of the agency's bureau of consumer protection, who helped develop the 2011 agreement.

The company is launching a charm offensive on Capitol Hill this week with briefings scheduled with the Intelligence, Commerce and Judiciary panels in both chambers, Ashley Gold and Nancy Scola report. Facebook will also hold a nationwide briefing by phone Thursday for state attorneys general, a company spokesperson confirmed. Several attorneys general have begun raising concerns, and those in New York and Massachusetts sent a letter Tuesday asking questions.

The efforts come as lawmakers including Sens. Mark Warner and John Cornyn and Rep. Marsha Blackburn ramp up calls for Facebook to send CEO Mark Zuckerberg to testify in Congress.

RECENTLY ON PRO CYBERSECURITY -- Johnson Joy resigned as Housing and Urban Development's chief information officer. ... Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan defended special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. ... President Donald Trump congratulated Vladimir Putin on the Russian president's recent election victory. ... DHS picked consultant Matthew Travis for the No. 2 job at its main cybersecurity division. ... The Office of Management and Budget said upgrading the federal government's computer systems is a top priority for the administration.

-- Tax consultancy alliantgroup is announcing today that former Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge is joining the firm's strategic advisory board as chairman of cybersecurity and technology.

-- Also today, the Retail Information Sharing and Analysis Center is announcing that Tommy McDowell will lead the ISAC as senior director. Harpreet Kalra and Muktar Kelati will also join as senior analysts and Ryan Smith will become intelligence support manager.

QUICK BYTES

-- A new cybersecurity joint operations center based at Indiana University -- a joint effort of five universities dubbed OmniSOC -- launches today that's intended to protect each of the universities against cyber threats.

-- "CyberScoop has learned that Kaspersky research recently exposed an active, U.S.-led counterterrorism cyber-espionage operation."

-- The former head of Israeli spy agency Mossad has formed a cybersecurity firm. Reuters.

-- The Government Accountability Office revealed Tuesday that it denied a bid protest from Enterprise Services for a $3.3 billion NSA IT contract that went to AT&T.

results.title: Border wall, tip pool in omni talks
results.body:
BORDER WALL, TIP POOL IN OMNI TALKS: Lawmakers struggled Tuesday to cement the provisions in a $1.3 trillion spending bill, including potential funding for President Donald Trump's border wall, POLITICO's Burgess Everett, Rachael Bade, Sarah Ferris and Heather Caygle report. The negotiations, which also touched on a large-scale infrastructure project in the New York City area, appeared likely to spill into Wednesday, if not later in the week.

The border wall resurfaced, but in far less sweeping terms than previously discussed, according to POLITICO. "Talks to protect young immigrants facing deportation fell apart over the weekend, but congressional Democrats spent Monday and Tuesday pushing to freeze hiring of immigration enforcement officials in return for providing Trump [$1.6 billion] in funding on his border wall," the quartet reported. The White House reportedly floated a proposal to Democrats over the weekend that offered a two-year extension of the DACA program for $25 billion in border wall money, but Democrats rejected the offer.

Lawmakers also wrestled with whether to include $900 million for the Gateway project, a planned railway tunnel from New Jersey to New York, POLITICO reports. "Gateway supporters are trying to include language that would allow the project to apply for competitive grant money and prevent the Trump administration from squashing the project," the quartet write. "Trump has told Republicans he will veto a bill that funds the project specifically."

The Labor Department's tip pooling rule also factored into spending bill discussions, POLITICO's Andrew Hanna and Ian Kullgren report. "Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.) and the Labor Department are at work on a legislative compromise to prevent the Trump administration's proposed tip-pooling rule from allowing employers to pocket tips given to workers," they reported last night.

"But the compromise, intended for inclusion in the forthcoming omnibus spending bill, faces stiff resistance from Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.), the ranking member on the House Education and the Workforce Committee, according to two sources familiar with the negotiations," POLITICO reports. "Murray is the ranking member on the Senate HELP Committee."

"The legislative compromise would allow DOL to proceed with its rule permitting employers to require so-called tip pools in which tipped workers such as waitresses share tips with back-of-the-house workers such as kitchen workers," Hanna and Kullgren report. "But the legislation would make it illegal for employers to help themselves to the tip pool."

"As of Tuesday night, it was unclear whether the language would be included in the final spending bill, given firm opposition from Scott," POLITICO reported, citing sources familiar with the situation. "According to these sources, Scott believes that the legislative fix would encourage businesses to reduce base pay for back-of-the-house workers." More about the border wall here and the tip pooling deal here.

GOOD MORNING! It's Wednesday, March 21, and this is Morning Shift, POLITICO's daily tipsheet on employment and immigration policy. Send tips, exclusives and suggestions to thesson@politico.com, ikullgren@politico.com, ahanna@politico.com and tnoah@politico.com. Follow us on Twitter at @tedhesson, @AndrewBHanna, @IanKullgren and @TimothyNoah1.

SNOW DAY: Federal government offices are closed today due to the impending winter weather. Granted, there's not much snow yet from our perch in northwest D.C., but the Weather Channel radar shows the storm closing in on the beltway. Alas, there will be no snow day in Congress, however.

CASSIDY OUT AT DHS: Ben Cassidy, assistant secretary for legislative affairs at DHS, left that post last week, three current and former department officials tell Morning Shift. A DHS spokesman confirmed the departure, but didn't provide additional detail.

As the department's top legislative dealmaker, Cassidy facilitated congressional negotiations in recent months over the DACA program. He helped arrange a meeting between Trump and a bipartisan group of senators over the issue back in January, a source briefed on the confab later told POLITICO, only to see the president derail the session with a racist (and well-publicized) rant about "shithole" countries. The talks never regained momentum; the Senate devoted a week to immigration debate in mid-February, but failed to advance legislation. Again, Trump played the obstructionist, as the White House took potshots at the bipartisan measures with the best chance of passage.

The prospect of a DREAMer pact hasn't evaporated entirely, but it appears less likely by the day. Deal or no deal, Cassidy's departure means another vacancy among senior leadership at the department, where several high-level posts remain empty or filled by acting officials.

USCIS SUSPENDS H-1B FAST-TRACK: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services will temporarily suspend fast-track processing for all H-1B visa petitions subject to the fiscal year 2019 cap, the agency announced Tuesday evening. The premium processing service allows a business to have an H-1B petition for a high-skilled worker considered within 15 calendar days if it pays a $1,225 fee -- an assurance the petition will be handled in a timely manner. USCIS said the pause (which will last until Sept. 10) will allow it to deal with "long-pending petitions" that have been sidelined as premium requests have grown. The San Francisco Chronicle reported the possibility of the move earlier this month. USCIS will begin accepting petitions subject to the FY19 cap on April 2. More here.

SEXUAL HARASSMENT DEVELOPMENTS:

Farenthold considers exit: Rep. Blake Farenthold (R-Texas) may depart Congress before his term concludes, POLITICO's Jake Sherman, Rachael Bade and John Bresnahan report, citing multiple Republican sources. "Farenthold already announced he would not seek re-election in his southeastern Texas district, after POLITICO reported he settled a sexual harassment lawsuit with $84,000 in taxpayer funds," the trio report. "But he now is on the brink of leaving Congress well before the end of his term, which would allow him to dodge an Ethics Committee investigation into allegations of inappropriate office behavior." More here.

Judge won't toss allegations against Trump: A New York judge refused Tuesday to dismiss a lawsuit that alleged President Trump groped a contestant on "The Apprentice" in 2007, POLITICO's Josh Gerstein reports. The legal action was brought by Summer Zervos, who announced in the weeks before the 2016 election that Trump had groped her breast and repeated kissed her when she met with him to discuss employment opportunities. "No one is above the law," Schechter wrote in the decision. More here.

Former Mavericks employee steps forward: A woman who anonymously accused the former president of the Dallas Mavericks of inappropriate workplace behavior stepped forward in an article published Tuesday in Sports Illustrated. The woman, Melissa Weishaupt, penned a follow-up column where she pressed the team to respond to the accusations against Terdema Ussery, the former executive. "I'm using my name because I'm still not sure the Mavericks get it," she wrote. "Since the story broke, owner Mark Cuban has repeatedly claimed he oversaw only the basketball side of that franchise, not the business side. Sorry. It doesn't work that way." More here.

Weinstein Co. voids disclosure agreements: The Weinstein Company filed for bankruptcy late Monday evening, Brooks Barnes reported in the New York Times. As part of the filing, the company released anyone "who suffered or witnessed any form of sexual misconduct by Harvey Weinstein" from nondisclosure agreements, the Times reports. In October, the Times revealed that Weinstein had silenced sexual harassment accusers for decades with payments, a story that triggered an outpouring of misconduct claims against the Hollywood producer. More on the bankruptcy here.

NYC UBER DRIVERS SEEKS MIN WAGE: "Uber and Lyft drivers demanding a minimum wage mounted a campaign Tuesday to ensure they'll get one from their ride-hailing companies," Graham Rayman reports for the New York Daily News. "More than 15,000 drivers signed a petition calling on the city to pass a law establishing a minimum wage that would hike drivers' pay by 37 percent, the Independent Drivers Guild said. The guild also wants to cap the fees riders pay to the companies at 20 percent."

But the petition sparked backlash from NYC yellow cab drivers who want government-regulated cab fares to be the minimum rate of pay. "We reiterate to the Mayor and Taxi and Limousine Commission that we need a livable income and a halt to the race to the bottom, not proposals aimed at protecting Uber's bottom line," the New York Taxi Workers Alliance said. More here.

ROBB OFFERS TO DISCUSS CHANGES: NLRB General Counsel Peter Robb sent a letter Tuesday to the agency's union president, Karen Cook, inviting her to discuss proposed changes to field operations and case processing. The NLRB Professional Association criticized Robb for providing "multiple, inconsistent justifications" for restructuring the agency's regional offices in a missive last week. Responding Tuesday, Robb claimed the proposed organizational changes "came from NLRB employees from all levels." Cook expressed skepticism about Robb's claim. "With so much opposition at all levels, we'd like to know who the employees he consulted are," she told Morning Shift. Read Robb's letter here.

MIN WAGE, PAID LEAVE ADVANCE IN CONN: Connecticut's Labor and Public Employees Committee approved Tuesday a plethora of bills on fair wages and paid leave. The legislation aims to "expand Connecticut's family and sick leave laws, update sexual harassment training requirements, prevent unintended pay discrimination disadvantaging women and increase the minimum wage," Emilie Munson reports for the New Haven Register.

One measure under consideration would raise the state's minimum wage to $13.50 by 2020, up from the current $10.10. Other bills would require employers to provide at least 40 hours of paid sick leave and mandate sexual harassment training at larger businesses, the Register reports. "While the equal pay and anti-sexual harassment bills passed the committee with unanimous support, votes on paid family and sick leave and minimum wage were divided on party lines, with opposition stemming from Republicans," Munson writes. More here.

CHIPOTLE WORKER FILES APPEAL: Attorneys for a Chipotle worker found to be in contempt of court earlier this week filed a notice of appeal Tuesday and requested a stay of the judge's ruling. The worker filed a lawsuit against Chipotle last year, arguing that the company withheld time-and-a-half pay under the Obama administration' rule, even though the rule never took effect because the same court issued an injunction.

Attorneys for the worker argued that their lawsuit wasn't a violation of the court's order because the court, in issuing an injunction against enforcement, didn't stop the rule itself from taking effect. They also contend the federal injunction didn't stop lawsuits under state law. A U.S. District Court judge in Texas didn't buy that argument, and on Monday ordered the worker to withdraw its complaints and pay Chipotle's legal fees. The worker's attorneys on Tuesday asked the court to stay the contempt ruling pending appeal.

CALIF HOSPITAL UNION MOVES: "Both Dignity Health and Kaiser Permanente announced Monday that they had reached major contract agreements with labor unions representing thousands of employees at the two companies," Cathie Anderson reports in the Sacramento Bee. "The roughly 15,000 members of SEIU-United Healthcare Workers West concluded voting Friday, ratifying a five-year contract with Dignity that will increase pay by 13 percent over the term of the deal. ... Over at Kaiser, about 19,000 members of the California Nurses Association reached a tentative, five-year deal after voting two weeks ago to authorize a strike, if needed, if their concerns about patient care were not met." More here.

results.title: House farm bill talks at standstill
results.body:
With Catherine Boudreau, Sabrina Rodriguez and Maya Parthasarathy

HOUSE FARM BILL TALKS REMAIN AT AN IMPASSE: House Agriculture ranking member Collin Peterson said Tuesday that he shared additional details (though not the text) of proposed changes to the food stamp program in the farm bill with committee Democrats, but that they remain unanimously opposed to Republicans' "extreme, partisan" policies, Pro Ag's Catherine Boudreau reports.

"This opposition will not change," Peterson said in a statement, indicating that a bipartisan farm bill likely isn't feasible unless Chairman Mike Conaway walks back proposals to tighten eligibility and impose stricter work requirements on able-bodied adults participating in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program.

Democrats want details: The announcement follows a letter Peterson received last week from 19 committee Democrats demanding that he stop negotiating with Conaway over SNAP until they could see the text of the farm bill. They complained they had not seen the contents of any of the chapters -- let alone the nutrition title -- forcing them to rely on news reports to see what was being discussed. They also criticized how the talks had taken place in secrecy. Peterson pledged to heed their request, and farm bill talks have since remained deadlocked.

Conaway told reporters Tuesday that he is still trying to figure out how to move forward with Democrats, though no meetings are scheduled for this week.

"The plan has always been that once the ranking member and chairman sign off on the language, then [the farm bill] is released," he said. "I can't get my ranking member to sign off on the language. [Peterson] got a letter from his members saying he can't. I'm in a bad circle trying to get this done. So we're still trying to figure out how we get past this impasse."

Senate outlook: Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) suggested that the House side would have to come to terms if they wanted to get anything to fly in the Senate.

"I don't think it has any chance of getting through the Senate if it isn't bipartisan," Grassley said of the House bill during a call with reporters Tuesday morning. "Consequentially, we'll write our own bill and it'll be a bipartisan bill."

Grassley met recently with Senate Agriculture Chairman Pat Roberts to discuss what he'd like to see in the Senate version. "The staff is starting to draft a farm bill, and he told me he hopes to start the process after the Easter recess," the Iowa Republican said of Roberts.

HAPPY WEDNESDAY, MARCH 21! Welcome to Morning Ag, where your host can't get over the irony that the official first day of spring was marked by an impending snowstorm for the Washington area -- the only real flakes of the year, at that. Stay warm, ag friends. Send your best snowman photos or news to lcrampton@politico.com or @liz_crampton. Follow the whole team at @Morning_Ag.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers depend on free trade to export more than $100 billion of products annually. With farm incomes declining, exports help keep farms and rural communities afloat. But some in Washington support restrictive trade policies that would be devastating. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade. Learn more here. **

PROGRAMMING NOTE: President Donald Trump's plan to slap as much as $60 billion in tariffs on imported Chinese goods could eventually trigger a trade war that slams American farmers, according to David Dollar, a Brookings Institution fellow and former U.S. Treasury envoy to Beijing. Listen to his interview with Ben White in the latest POLITICO Money podcast.

TRUMP COULD HAND OFF RFS SPAT TO CONGRESS: Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue said Tuesday the Trump administration may ask Congress to take over mediating the long-running dispute between the ethanol industry and some oil interests over the price of biofuel credits, write Pro Ag's Helena Bottemiller Evich and Pro Energy's Eric Wolff.

"I think the White House is trying to determine whether they need to make a call on a decision or allow Congress to go back and fix it," Perdue told reporters at the National Press Club on Tuesday. "We've had some members of Congress call and say, 'We've been working on this -- let us have it.'"

White House playing referee: Trump has convened four meetings to settle the dispute, which has pushed corn-state senators and Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) and Sen. Pat Toomey (R-Penn.) to opposite sides of the debate over whether to lower the cost of biofuel credits, known as Renewable Identification Numbers.

A fix could be found in a bill to overhaul the Renewable Fuel Standard from Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) and Rep. John Shimkus (R-Ill.). Details about the bill are scarce but it's rumored to include a national octane standard, and possibly a new kind of RIN for sales of high ethanol blends of gasoline.

SECTION 199A MISHAP THREATENS SMALL BUSINESSES: Paul Kroeker can't believe that "ineptitude" on Capitol Hill may just put him out of business. Kroeker owns an independent grain elevator and lumber company in Henderson, Neb., that handles about three million bushels of corn and soybeans each year. But the new Section 199A language in the Republican tax law has hurt him immensely as he tries to compete with three grain cooperatives in his area.

Already costing money: For the 2017 crop, Kroeker has lost 30 percent of his business from corn growers because farmers just can't turn down the lucrative deduction they get when selling to co-ops over other types of businesses. Some producers could be able to write off their income entirely.

"The longer this drags on, the more business I lose," Kroeker told Pro Ag's Catherine Boudreau in an interview on Tuesday. "It will be a catastrophe for businesses my size."

Legislative hold up: Congressional leaders have been trying to include a fix to the so-called grain glitch in the fiscal 2018 omnibus spending package, but House Speaker Paul Ryan said Tuesday he opposed Senate Democrats' demands that a low-income housing tax credit be expanded in exchange. Plans to roll out the spending package were derailed late Tuesday after congressional leaders failed to reach agreement on a number of disputes. Among the roadblocks: how to fix "fire borrowing," in which federal agencies must dip into other funding accounts for firefighting and prevention, instead of receiving emergency dollars like the response to hurricanes.

Meanwhile, businesses like Kroeker's hang in the balance, and he is frustrated that fixing the Section 199A deduction has become a political bargaining chip. "There's been a lot of tears in my household," he said, noting that he has traveled to Washington to bend the ear of Nebraska's congressional delegation and members of the House Ways & Means Committee -- most recently last week. He has also tweeted hundreds of times to get their attention.

FAMILY FARMS STILL IN CONTROL: Agricultural production has shifted to larger farms during the last three decades, but family farms still dominate as they've absorbed more acres and production, according to USDA. Family farms account for 99 percent of all U.S. farms and that hasn't changed over time, reveals a new report on consolidation in ag released on Tuesday from USDA's Economic Research Service. Even among the largest farms raking in at least $5 million in sales, family operations account for 78 percent of farms.

Tech bump: Advancements in technology are the driver of ramped-up consolidation across crop production and livestock as developments have allowed farms to manage more acres and animals, the report states.

"Larger, faster, and more precise tractors, planters, sprayers, and harvesting equipment reduce the time a farmer must devote to field tasks on a given acreage, freeing a farmer to manage more acres," it reads.

Upgrades in pest management -- such as new chemical herbicides, genetically engineered herbicide-tolerant seeds and seed treatments -- have freed up labor. Tailored feeding of animals, along with improvements in disease prevention and reproduction have also helped.

Corporate influence: Big companies do own and operate farms -- especially poultry and hog ones -- but their main role in ag is to coordinate supply chains and contract with family farms to raise commodities, the report states.

Listen in: An author of the report, USDA economist James MacDonald, was scheduled to host a webinar today to discuss the report's findings, but it was rescheduled to March 27 due to inclement weather. Information on how to re-register can be found here.

ROW CROPS:

-- Tons of food went to waste in Puerto Rico as FEMA ignored pleas: Walmart and other supermarkets in Puerto Rico were forced to throw out tons of perishable fresh foods after Hurricane Maria when their pleas for emergency fuel were ignored by FEMA, according to congressional investigators. POLITICO's Lorraine Woellert has more.

-- U.S targets junk food warning labels in NAFTA talks: The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative has put forth a proposal in the NAFTA renegotiation that aims to limit the ability of Canada and Mexico to require consumer warnings on sugary drinks and other processed foods, the New York Times reports. The proposal would prevent the use of any warning signs or symbols, as officials in Latin America and Canada are discussing more ways to warn consumers of health risks.

-- Pence pledges farm bill support: On National Ag Day, Vice President Mike Pence mentioned the farm bill only briefly during remarks at USDA but promised that "we're going to pass a farm bill that delivers for America's farmers just as they work every single day to deliver for us," POLITICO's Blake Paterson reports.

-- Mexican presidential front-runner taps NAFTA lead negotiator if he wins: Three-time presidential candidate Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador said that if he wins, he will name Oxford-educated Jes√∫s Seade Hel√∫ to replace Kenneth Smith Ramos as Mexico's chief NAFTA negotiator. Seade has previously served at the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and WTO. Pro's Sabrina Rodriguez has more.

-- Monsanto invests in gene editing company: The St. Louis-based seed giant on Tuesday announced that it would pay the agricultural start-up Pairwise $100 million over five years to use and develop its gene editing technology in corn, soybeans, wheat, cotton and canola crops exclusively with Monsanto, including the option to commercialize products resulting from the partnership. Separately, Pairwise said it raised $25 million during its first round of financing, with Monsanto's venture capital arm and the investment firm Deerfield Management each investing $12.5 million and becoming minority shareholders. Reuters has more here.

-- Fast-track authority sought: President Donald Trump formally requested a three-year extension of trade promotion authority to negotiate free trade agreements that he can submit to Congress under fast-track approval procedures.
