Congress last passed trade promotion authority in 2015, in one of the hardest-fought congressional trade battles in years, Pro Trade's Doug Palmer writes.

-- Another view on tariffs: A coalition of labor and business groups that supports tariffs on steel and aluminum imports estimated in a study that close to 19,000 steel and aluminum jobs would be created and that the overall impact on U.S. jobs would be "negligible," Doug writes.

-- Concern on trade policy: Sen. Orrin Hatch, one of Trump's biggest supporters in Congress, warned on Tuesday that protectionists in the Trump administration have put the United States on a "dangerous course" that will hurt American leadership, Doug reports.

-- Mississippi governor expected to appoint ag commissioner: Gov. Phil Bryant is expected to appoint Mississippi Agriculture Commissioner Cindy Hyde-Smith to the seat being vacated by GOP Sen. Thad Cochran, POLITICO's Daniel Strauss and Burgess Everett report.

-- Jones against Chinese chicken: Rep. Walter Jones asked the House Appropriations Committee to make sure Chinese-processed poultry is not allowed in school lunch programs, claiming that "foreign countries are regularly trying to export low-quality, high-risk foods to make a profit." Read more here.

-- Revolving door: Edge Dairy Farmer Cooperative announced Tuesday that it has elected Brody Stapel to lead the group. Stapel, a dairy farmer from Cedar Grove, Wis., will replace John Pagel, who died unexpectedly last month. Edge's board also selected Wisconsin-based farmer Todd Doornink to serve as vice president.

THAT'S ALL FOR MA! See you again soon! In the meantime, drop your host and the rest of the team a line: cboudreau@politico.com and @ceboudreau; hbottemiller@politico.com and @hbottemiller; chaughney@politico.com and @chaughney; lcrampton@politico.com and @liz_crampton; srodriguez@politico.com and @sabrod123; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and P.J. Joshi, at pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers are the most productive in the world. Our farmers and ranchers exported more than $129 billion worth of products in 2016, accounting for 20% of all farm revenue in the U.S. Agricultural exports also support more than one million American jobs - most of them in the nonfarm sector. These jobs provide stability for rural families and communities. Free trade is essential to maintaining the strength of our agriculture economy. But some in Washington now support policies that would restrict trade. That would be devastating to family farms across the country, and would cause higher prices for consumers. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade to keep our agriculture economy strong. Learn more here. **

results.title: Why Trump's school safety commission omits students and teachers
results.body:
OMNIBUS HELD UP, MUST PASS BY FRIDAY: The rollout of a $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill was held up Tuesday night after talks between Capitol Hill negotiators and the White House moved slowly. The bill contains fiscal 2018 spending levels and has to pass by Friday to keep the government running. Immigration has been one of the biggest sticking points, with Republicans and Democrats trading offers late Tuesday afternoon. POLITICO's Sarah Ferris and Kaitlyn Burton report.

WHY TRUMP'S SCHOOL SAFETY COMMISSION OMITS STUDENTS, TEACHERS: The new White House commission on school safety will consist of just four Cabinet secretaries -- prompting concerns from parents, students, teachers and school administrators who feel they should play a bigger role. But the Trump administration says it's about getting to work quickly.

-- Education Secretary Betsy DeVos on Tuesday testified during a hearing of the House Appropriations subcommittee that oversees education funding. While she was there to discuss the Trump administration's fiscal 2019 budget proposal, she offered new details about the commission's makeup. DeVos will chair the commission, which was recently unveiled by the White House in response to the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., last month that left 17 people dead. Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar and Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen will join her, she told lawmakers.

-- "Is that it? Just four Cabinet secretaries? No experts? No Democrats?" asked Rep. Katherine Clark (D-Mass.). DeVos replied, "This is an urgent matter and we want to ensure that we're able to move and operate as quickly as possible and without getting bogged down by a lot of bureaucracy."

-- What does DeVos mean by "bureaucracy"? Keeping the commission to just four federal officials who have jurisdiction over school safety issues means the group can "get up and running as quickly as possible," said Education Department spokeswoman Liz Hill.

-- "Advisory commissions with non-Federal employees have to follow Federal Advisory Committee Act rules, which adds significant bureaucratic bloat," Hill said in a statement. "FACA imposes many bureaucratic hurdles, such as requiring a charter that must be approved by the General Services Administration and the appointment of an Agency Committee Management Officer and a Designated Federal Officer, as well as other requirements that would delay the start of this important effort."

-- Input from students, parents and teachers "will be critical," Hill added. "The Commission will receive input from and hold meetings over the coming weeks and months with students, parents, teachers, schools safety personnel, administrators, law enforcement officials, mental health professionals, school counselors and others holding a wide variety of views."

-- Still, education groups want to ensure they're heard. "It is critical that parents have a seat at the table whenever decisions are made that impact their children, and particularly on the critical issue of school safety," said Jim Accomando, president of National PTA, which represents parent-teacher associations nationwide.

-- "As school building leaders, principals must be heard on school safety and student well-being issues," said L. Earl Franks, executive director of the National Association of Elementary School Principals. Noelle Ellerson Ng, associate executive director for policy and advocacy at AASA, The School Superintendents Association, said that "by keeping it only to Cabinet members, it's necessarily political ... I would venture a guess that the commission described by Secretary DeVos today isn't set it up to be super productive."

GOOD WEDNESDAY MORNING, MARCH 21. The D.C. region could get its first real snowfall today in two years. This native New Englander is skeptical -- but will embrace the cozy weather. Talk to me at cemma@politico.com or @caitlinzemma. Send events to: educalendar@politicopro.com. And follow us on Twitter: @Morning_Edu and @POLITICOPro.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

SCRUTINY FROM BOTH SIDES OF THE AISLE: DeVos' appearance before the House Appropriations subcommittee on Tuesday also drew scrutiny from members on both sides of the aisle. Rep. Rodney Frelinghuysen (R-N.J.), chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, told DeVos that he wants a meeting with her and is "concerned that we have kind of a disconnect here." Frelinghuysen said his comments were "more to the secretary's staff" than to DeVos, and that he has said the same thing to other agency chiefs. But he told DeVos, "You've been on the job for a while" and "it's important for members who pay the bill to meet with the secretaries before they come to the committee."

-- Rep. Tom Cole (R-Okla.), the Republican chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee that oversees education funding, told DeVos that he's "concerned" the Trump administration is "continuing to request cuts" Congress has rejected. The administration's proposal calls on Congress to reduce fiscal 2019 discretionary spending at the Education Department by $3.8 billion below current levels.

-- Lawmakers pressed DeVos repeatedly on whether racial bias and discrimination is a problem when it comes to school discipline practices. DeVos said only that "there is no place for discrimination and there is not tolerance for discrimination" and that "we will continue to uphold that." DeVos also acknowledged data has shown disparities.

-- At the same time on Tuesday morning, a House Judiciary subcommittee held a hearing targeting Obama-era guidelines meant to address racial disparities in school discipline. Republicans charged that those Obama guidelines contributed to law enforcement's failure to identify and stop the school shooter in Parkland, Fla. POLITICO recently reported there's no evidence to suggest that those policies had anything to do with the massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.

ANOTHER SCHOOL SHOOTING AS LAWMAKERS TALK SCHOOL SAFETY: DeVos' appearance on Capitol Hill came just after news broke of another school shooting -- this time at Great Mills High School in Southern Maryland -- that left two students injured and the shooter dead. The shooter, identified as 17-year-old Austin Wyatt Rollins, was confronted by a school resource officer stationed at the school. "This is the beginning of a very long and tragic process," said James Scott Smith, superintendent of St. Mary's County Public Schools. "It looks as though the SRO did exactly what SROs are trained to do, and yet we still have loss of life ... we have students and staff impacted." The shooting comes just days before hundreds of thousands of students are expected to call for an end to gun violence in marches nationwide.

-- News of the shooting trickled into the House Appropriations subcommittee hearing with DeVos. "Do you believe we have a crisis with gun violence in our country? That's a yes or no question," Rep. Rosa DeLauro (D-Conn.) asked. "I believe we have a crisis of violence in our country, yes," DeVos replied, omitting the word "gun" from her reply. DeVos stressed the need for strengthening background checks and measures that can remove a person's access to guns if that person is deemed a danger to himself or herself or others.

-- The shooting was also raised at a Tuesday afternoon forum on school safety held by House Democrats. Stacey Lippel, an English teacher and survivor of the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, was asked about the Trump administration's support for training and arming school personnel, like teachers. She said, "I had seconds to respond, so if I had a gun it probably would've been useless or dangerous to my students and myself. When you're put in a situation like that, you're just trying to secure your students." But having school security officials or officers who are trained to use a weapon is another thing, she said.

FIRST LADY ADDRESSES CYBERBULLYING SKEPTICS: Melania Trump on Tuesday addressed critics as the White House convened a discussion on cyberbullying and internet safety. "I am well aware that people are skeptical of me discussing this topic," she said. Critics and pundits have pointed to the president's tendency to light into enemies on Twitter and in speeches, deeming it ironic that the first lady would choose cyberbullying as her issue. "I have been criticized for my commitment to tackling this issue, and I know that will continue," she said. "But it will not stop me from doing what I know is right. I am here with one goal: helping children and our next generation." More from The Associated Press.

TEXAS FINALIZES DRAFT SPECIAL EDUCATION PLAN: Texas education officials this week finalized a draft plan that would overhaul the way the state teaches students with disabilities -- while acknowledging there's limited money available. The plan comes after a federal investigation concluded earlier this year, finding that Texas education officials substantially reduced the number of students receiving special education services, failed to identify children with disabilities and illegally denied tens of thousands of students those services required by law. The federal probe was sparked by a 2016 Houston Chronicle investigation that found Texas education officials arbitrarily capped at 8.5 percent the number of students who could receive special education services, while the national average of public school students receiving special education services is about 13 percent.

-- Texas education officials note that the draft plan, which was ordered by federal officials, was informed by extensive feedback from teachers, parents, administrators, advocates and more. Among the corrective actions, the Texas Education Agency says it will allocate $65 million to school districts to help them locate and identify students who've been improperly denied special education services under federal law.

-- The Texas Education Agency says the draft plan is designed "so that it can be sustained with existing appropriations" for special education. The agency says it "cannot legally commit additional funds outside of those that are appropriated by the Texas Legislature and the U.S. Congress. A sizeable amount of stakeholder feedback is related to funding. While that feedback may warrant additional action, any recommendations for action are most appropriately heard by state and federal legislators." State education officials are accepting public comment on the plan through April 6 before the plan is submitted to federal officials later that month. Check out the plan.

WHERE'S THE 'HOMEWORK GAP' STUDY?: Federal Communications Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel urged the Education Department Tuesday to release its "homework gap" study -- a report on student access to online educational resources at home commissioned by the Every Student Succeeds Act.

-- "That study is more than nine months overdue. Nine months? That's a school year," Rosenworcel said during an event on school broadband access held on Capitol Hill. "I think it would be justice right now to make sure that we get that study released so we can all see what the homework gap looks like nationwide." A coalition of education groups echoed similar sentiments in a letter sent last month to the Institute of Education Sciences, the department's data and research arm.

REPORT ROLL CALL

-- The left-learning Center for American Progress is out with a critical look at whether private school vouchers are effective.

-- The Food Action & Research Center, a nonprofit, says in a new report that nearly 1.1 million low-income children benefited from afterschool meals in October 2016, compared to 200,000 children in October 2011.

SYLLABUS

-- Florida Gov. Rick Scott wants armed police at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School after disturbing incidents in recent days: POLITICO Florida.

-- Parkland students say they are not aligned with any political party: POLITICO Pro.

-- Tennessee governor proposes $30 million for student safety plan: Chalkbeat.

-- Bill that would deny adult education to some immigrants clears the New Hampshire Senate: NHPR.

-- Arizona governor rolls out school safety package: The Associated Press.

-- Indiana's plan to measure high schools with a college prep test is on hold for two years: Chalkbeat.

-- Kansas lawmakers consider less ambitious educational goals: The Associated Press.

results.title: What's the China strategy?
results.body:
With help from Doug Palmer and Sabrina Rodriguez

WHAT'S THE CHINA STRATEGY? President Donald Trump is expected by Thursday to announce a plan to hit China with tariffs, investment restrictions and potentially other trade limits, but will these actions actually get Beijing to rein in an industrial policy that it only seemed to double down on when its legislature met this week?

U.S. trade actions might eventually bring China to the table to talk about American concerns with Beijing's industrial overcapacity, state subsidies and lack of market access for U.S. companies. But still unclear is whether the administration has any specific thresholds for progress on those issues and what China might do for the U.S. to reverse the tariffs or investment curbs, according to administration officials and outside advisers.

"It's a little bit of a red herring for the business community to be overly critical that there aren't clear off-ramps for China, because it's really unclear if the Chinese would even take them," said one outside adviser to the administration who has been briefed on the planning on trade actions against China. The adviser added that the administration is entering entirely uncharted waters in terms of testing China's reaction.

The expected 300-page report the administration is putting together as part of its Section 301 probe into China's intellectual property and technology transfer policies makes some recommendations on what China should do to curb those practices, a source familiar with its contents told Morning Trade.

But the tariff action Trump is ready to move ahead with seems geared more toward creating shock value and gaining leverage against China than achieving the methodical engagement that U.S. businesses would prefer.

"There's a recognition that you have to punch a bully in the face," said an administration official involved in the planning. "That's the best explanation of what's going on here." Read the latest on the China trade action here.

IT'S WEDNESDAY, MARCH 21! Welcome to Morning Trade, where your host wants to pause all the trade news this week to bring you a story about Japanese cats that wear hats made out of their own hair. Thoughts? Or maybe you just want to talk about trade. Let me know: abehsudi@politico.com or @abehsudi.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers depend on free trade to export more than $100 billion of products annually. With farm incomes declining, exports help keep farms and rural communities afloat. But some in Washington support restrictive trade policies that would be devastating. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade. Learn more here. **

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

BUSINESSES WANT TO USE 301 THREAT TO BRING CHINA TO THE TABLE: A major U.S. business group is pressing congressional trade leaders to use upcoming hearings with U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer as an opportunity to question the administration's overall strategy behind expected trade restrictions on China.

"The overall focus of the Section 301 investigation should be to bring China to the negotiating table for a meaningful resolution of specific, sector-by-sector issues with the ultimate goal of removing the offending practices and policies. Premature, unilateral sanctions alone are unlikely to achieve this objective," National Foreign Trade Council President Rufus Yerxa wrote in a letter sent Tuesday to Republican and Democratic leaders of the House Ways and Means and Senate Finance committees.

Lighthizer is scheduled to testify on Trump's trade agenda in front of the Ways and Means Committee today and at Senate Finance on Thursday.

"Unilateral imposition of tariffs prior to any meaningful negotiations with China will raise charges that the U.S. has ignored its WTO commitments and will turn the focus from China's unjust behavior to the legitimacy of our own action," Yerxa warned.

TRUMP FORMALLY REQUESTS THREE-YEAR TPA EXTENSION: Trump on Tuesday formally requested a three-year extension of trade promotion authority to negotiate free trade agreements that he can submit to Congress under fast track approval procedures. The move comes amid growing concern among Republicans over the direction of Trump's trade policy.

"I hope my administration can continue to work with the Congress to pursue new and better trade deals for America's workers, farmers, ranchers, and businesses," Trump said in a message to Congress. "Extension of trade authorities procedures is essential to fulfill that task and to demonstrate to our trading partners that my administration and the Congress share a common goal when it comes to trade."

Congress last passed trade promotion authority in 2015 in one of the hardest-fought congressional trade battles in years. It allows the White House to submit trade deals to Congress for a straight up-or-down vote without any amendments.

Trump's request means Congress has until July 1 to try to block renewal by passing a resolution of disapproval. Trump came into office promising to negotiate "better" trade deals, but so far he has not concluded any. In his message, he refers to the ongoing NAFTA negotiations and possible new trade deals in Africa and Southeast Asia. To read the administration's full report on why it wants a TPA extension, click here.

HATCH COOL TO IDEA OF GIVING TRUMP MORE TARIFF POWERS: Senate Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch on Tuesday poured cold water on the idea of giving Trump power to raise individual U.S. tariffs to the high levels that U.S. companies sometimes face in other countries like China, India and even the European Union.

"I can't speak for Congress, but all I can say is 'I don't think so,'" Hatch told reporters when asked if he thought Congress would approve such a plan. "We're not very enthused about the raising of tariffs. We think it's better to have open markets and to move on from there. The more we can do that, the better off the United States is."

A reciprocal tariff dream denied: Trump has spoken repeatedly in recent weeks of his desire to pursue a "reciprocal tax program," prompting reports that the White House is actually considering asking Congress for legislation. But any such bill would have to get through the Senate Finance and the House Ways and Means committees, whose leaders both believe the United States benefits from its low tariffs regime, even if exporters face higher tariffs abroad.

Hatch, who has announced plans to retire at the end of the year, delivered a speech on Tuesday that expressed concern about the direction of Trump's trade policy and dangled the possibility of revoking the White House's trade promotion authority if it departs too far from congressional negotiating objectives in revamping NAFTA.

The Utah Republican also urged Trump to narrowly target China in any trade action under Section 301 and emphasized that Congress must have the final word on the fate of NAFTA, despite Trump's frequent threats to withdraw from the pact. For more on his speech, read Doug Palmer's story here.

CAN MAKERS WARN OF PITFALLS IN STEEL TARIFF-EXCLUSION PROCESS: U.S. can manufacturers are urging the Commerce Department to let companies file joint requests for excluding certain products from tariffs on steel and aluminum.

"My fear is DOC may find our industry filing nearly 1,500 applications in the coming days, overwhelming DOC staff with exclusion requests, if only individual requests are filed," Robert Budway, president of the Can Manufacturers Institute, wrote in comments to the Commerce Department.

Budway said the exclusion process raises three concerns. First is the inability of companies to seek exclusions for groups of closely related steel products, leaving open the possibility that a company could be forced to submit more than 300 individual applications for different sizes and specifications of tinplate steel. Second is the concern over an apparent prohibition on joint applications for the same product. Finally, granting an exclusion to individual applicants could create a "competitive imbalance" if one company is granted an exclusion but another company is not for the same product.

ROSS: KING OF SPAIN TO SPEAK AT SELECTUSA SUMMIT: King Felipe VI of Spain will be one of several "notable foreign dignitaries" to speak at the annual SelectUSA Investment Summit in June, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said Tuesday. "We are getting more and more excited about this year's event," Ross said at a meeting of the department's Investment Advisory Council, according to a copy of his prepared remarks. "The theme is 'invest here, grow here, succeed here.'"

Felipe, 50, has been king since 2014. Spain was the 10th largest foreign investor in the United States in 2016, just ahead of China, according to the Organization for International Investment. However, China's investment in the United States skyrocketed 534 percent between 2011 and 2016, compared to just 36 percent for Spain over the same period.

The Investment Advisory Council, which includes a mix of companies, economic development groups and the OII, approved a number of recommendations aimed at attracting more investment from abroad. One called for "the complete and immediate repeal of all Section 385 regulations" introduced in 2016, which the council said has made the United States a less attractive place for foreign investments by increasing costs. Another urged the Trump administration to issue a written statement saying the United States welcomes foreign investment, similar to ones issued by past presidents.

Ross, in a statement to POLITICO, seemed to downplay the necessity of such an action without ruling it out. "The president made clear in Davos, and many times since then, that 'America is open for business,' in reference to the fact that he is committed to increasing investment here in the United States," he said. "We welcome the recommendations of the Council, but we would also remind them that words are different than action, and President Trump has done more to encourage investment here in America than any president in history." For more on the IAC meeting, read Doug Palmer's story here.

ROSS KEEPS THINKING ABOUT THAT SEAFOOD TRADE DEFICIT: Ross said one of his "pet peeves" continues to be the fact that the U.S. has a trade deficit in seafood.

"I hate the idea that with all the waters surrounding us and with all the waters inland that we have a trade deficit in fish," Ross said Tuesday in response to a question at a House Appropriations Committee hearing. "I've put a lot of pressure on the fisheries management group at NOAA to try to deal with this situation. I think there's some potential that some of the constraints that we've had on fresh catch here maybe need to be relaxed a little bit."

Ross said he's also focusing his attention on seafood imports, although he didn't say what specific action he is advocating. "It seems to me that we should be very careful about importing seafood from places that do not adhere to the same standards we would have for aquaculture here in the U.S.," he said.

L√ìPEZ OBRADOR TAPS NAFTA LEAD NEGOTIATOR CHOICE IF HE WINS: Mexican presidential front-runner Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador reiterated Tuesday that a new NAFTA should not be signed until after the July 1 election, adding that he has already chosen the lead negotiator if he wins. Mexico does not want "that in haste, the error is made of signing something that will harm us - that will affect our national producers," L√≥pez Obrador, often called by his initials AMLO, said in a video shared on his social media accounts.

L√≥pez Obrador said that if he wins the election, he would have Oxford-educated economist Jes√∫s Seade Hel√∫ replace current chief NAFTA negotiator Kenneth Smith Ramos as Mexico's chief NAFTA negotiator. Seade has served as an economist at the World Bank, senior adviser at the International Monetary Fund and a deputy director-general to the World Trade Organization.

The announcement runs counter to comments last week from L√≥pez Obrador's economic adviser, who indicated that AMLO would be open to keeping the same negotiating team after the election.

MEXICO'S RULES OF ORIGIN PROPOSAL COMING SOON: Mexico plans to present its own automotive rules of origin proposal in the next ROO intersessional meeting. The proposal is expected to include changes to how the three NAFTA countries calculate what percentage of cars is made in North America and how far Mexico will go in upping the regional content percentage.

Mexico's proposal will take from both the U.S.'s and Canada's proposals, but will not go as high as the U.S.'s ask that 85 percent of the parts of a car come from the three NAFTA countries, according to Mexican newspaper Reforma. The U.S. has also proposed that 50 percent of the parts of a car come from the U.S., but Canada and Mexico have repeatedly labeled it a nonstarter.

"Mexico agrees that there are aspects within the rules of origin provision that need to be modernized and Mexican officials have been identifying how to address this," a source close to the talks told Morning Trade. "When it comes to rules of origin, Mexico wants a trade agreement that addresses the rapidly changing nature of this industry. Yet, 50 percent U.S. domestic content is not an option."

NAFTA AUTO TALKS COULD SHIFT INTO HIGH GEAR: Mexico and Canada might not have to worry anymore about that U.S. demand that a car contain 50 percent American content to get a tariff cut. Canada's Globe and Mail newspaper reported Tuesday night that Lighthizer dropped that contentious demand in a meeting with Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland last week in Washington.

CIVIL SOCIETY GROUPS TO USTR: DON'T BLOCK COLOMBIA'S OECD ACCESSION: More than 30 human rights and civil society groups criticized USTR on Tuesday for using Colombia's accession to the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development to pressure the South American government into changing its drug-pricing policies. In a letter sent to Lighthizer on Tuesday, the groups urge the U.S. government to "stop promoting the interests of pharmaceutical companies even at the expense of people's health in Colombia."

The letter is a response to the U.S. drug industry's push for Colombia to drop a controversial patent challenge before it is allowed to join the international forum with 35 member nations. Last month, Lighthizer outlined for Colombia what USTR expects its government to complete in return for the U.S. offering a positive opinion at the April OECD trade committee.

REPORT SHOWS NORTH AMERICAN BUSINESS UNITY ON NAFTA: A new survey released by banking giant HSBC has found that most businesses in the United States, Canada and Mexico are on the same page when it comes to NAFTA's benefits. Roughly half of the 750 companies surveyed across North America said they felt the pact would have a positive effect on their businesses over the next two years. Only about 9 percent of U.S. businesses had a negative view of NAFTA, which was smaller than the 16 percent in Mexico and 13 percent in Canada that felt the same way.

The survey found that 77 percent of U.S. businesses expected their trade volumes to increase in the next 12 months with Mexico and Canada as the most important markets for expansion. Still, 60 percent of those companies surveyed think that governments are becoming more protective of their domestic businesses. Read the full reports here.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

-- USTR tries to limit the ability of NAFTA members to put consumer warnings on sugary drinks and highly processed foods with a proposal on food labeling, The New York Times reports.

-- Canada's envoy to the U.S. says there has been substantial progress in NAFTA discussions over the past few days, The Canadian Press reports.

-- Trump's China trade actions are causing very little stir in the stock market, Bloomberg reports.

-- China's state-run Global Times explains how subsidized U.S. soybeans hurt Chinese farmers.

-- The U.S. rejected alternatives to solar safeguard tariffs requested by the EU, Reuters reports.

-- G-20 finance ministers agreed to "further dialogue" on trade, Reuters reports.

-- African leaders are on the verge of forming the largest free trade area since the WTO, CNBC reports.

THAT'S ALL FOR MORNING TRADE! See you again soon! In the meantime, drop the team a line: abehsudi@politico.com and @abehsudi; mcassella@politico.com and @mmcassella; dpalmer@politico.com and @tradereporter; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny. Also follow us @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Trade.

** A message from Farmers for Free Trade: America's farmers are the most productive in the world. Our farmers and ranchers exported more than $129 billion worth of products in 2016, accounting for 20% of all farm revenue in the U.S. Agricultural exports also support more than one million American jobs - most of them in the nonfarm sector. These jobs provide stability for rural families and communities. Free trade is essential to maintaining the strength of our agriculture economy. But some in Washington now support policies that would restrict trade. That would be devastating to family farms across the country, and would cause higher prices for consumers. President Trump and Congress should protect free trade to keep our agriculture economy strong. Learn more here. **

results.title: More omni delays
results.body:
SO, TODAY. REALLY: Maybe? The schedule on that elusive omnibus spending package slipped again on Tuesday, with the hope now that the measure will be released Wednesday.

The provisions holding up the spending bill are largely outside the tax sphere, as Burgess Everett, Rachael Bade, Sarah Ferris and Heather Caygle noted. But there is some intrigue over that so-called "grain glitch," the part of the new tax law that gives farmers good reason to sell to cooperatives instead of independent companies.

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) is largely the holdup there, having so far resisted a proposed trade from Democrats that would allow for a grain glitch fix and an expansion of the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit.

Senate Republicans -- some of whom played a central role in crafting the fix -- are more willing to go along with the exchange, and there are certainly Democrats who would be interested in seeing both incentives on the omnibus.

Those negotiations have already been somewhat topsy-turvy, but House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady (R-Texas) told reporters on Tuesday that Republicans on his committee were still talking with both Ryan and the Senate. "We think it's important to move it in the omnibus if there's an opportunity to do it, so we're just staying at the table to figure it out," Brady said.

For his part, Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) said Ryan would have to know that a grain glitch fix would come with a price after Republicans largely went solo in passing their tax cut last year, even as plenty of lawmakers in his party are also interested in correcting the mistake. "I've received more mail from the reddest areas of my state about this issue than any other issue. It's a mess. It was made a mess because of the way they handled the tax reform bill," Durbin said. "For the speaker to believe that we're going to walk away from this problem without addressing other problems is na√Øve."

Online update! The grain glitch fix might still be in flux, but it's pretty clear that online sales tax legislation won't make the omnibus. But there was this development on Tuesday: The Trump administration formally asked the Supreme Court to take part in arguments next month over the South Dakota online sales tax law, as your Morning Tax author noted -- perhaps a sign that the administration has a fair amount of interest in the case.

QUITE A WEEK ALREADY so far, and thanks for joining us this Wednesday -- where your Morning Tax author really never figured that a snow event would block his efforts to get out of town for a few days.

What have you done lately: It's now been 33 years since Rick Hansen, a Canadian paraplegic athlete, kicked off his Man in Motion wheelchair tour -- in which he traveled some 40,000 kilometers (around 24,000 miles) through 34 countries over 26 months to raise money for spinal cord research.

Let us know if you find that omnibus text hanging around. Email: bbecker@politico.com, teckert@politico.com, bfaler@politico.com, cwilhelm@politico.com, alorenzo@politico.com. Twitter: @berniebecker3, @tobyeckert, @brian_faler, @colinwilhelm, @AaronELorenzo, @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Tax.

** A message from the Intuit Tax and Financial Center: This tax season, government and industry are engaged in a system-wide collaborative known as the Information Sharing and Analysis Center or "ISAC." The IRS, state revenue agencies and leading industry members are all working together to protect taxpayers and eliminate cyberfraud from the tax filing process. To learn more, visit http://bit.ly/2G5x7zz **

THE CAPITAL GAINS ARGUMENT: Now that Larry Kudlow is headed to the White House, there will be plenty of people watching to see if one of his pet issues -- indexing capital gains to inflation -- will get new life. As The Wall Street Journal noted, Kudlow himself has suggested that President Donald Trump could take that step without the help of Congress. But that's also the sort of step that at least one previous Republican administration -- George H.W. Bush's -- rejected, and the administration would likely have to index other parts of the tax code to inflation as well to tamp down distortions.

THE DAY IN POLITICS: Americans for Prosperity, part of the Koch political orbit, has a new fact sheet that seeks to fight what it calls myths being perpetuated about the new tax cut -- including that around 5 out of every 6 dollars' worth of benefits goes to the top 1 percent and that the $1.5 trillion tax cut will "explode" the national debt. "History shows, however, that economic growth following tax reform actually results in more tax revenue for the federal government," the group wrote.

Speaking of the Kochs: On the other side of the political spectrum, the liberal coalition Not One Penny is announcing today that it's putting up billboards in the brothers' hometown of Wichita, Kan., that argue that regular families will be left behind while the Kochs get big tax cuts.

Also from the left: Democrats on the Joint Economic Committee, led by Sen. Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.), have a new interactive map that seeks to illustrate how many years an average family could live off of $193,000 -- the sort of tax cut that the super-wealthy might see.

THE DAY IN RESEARCH: Heather Boushey and Greg Leiserson of the Washington Center for Equitable Growth have a new article laying out a roadmap for progressives to present their kind of tax system. That doesn't just include raising more revenue from the wealthiest families, to funnel into areas like infrastructure and the Earned Income Tax Credit. In an effort to boost growth and living standards, Boushey and Leiserson argue in Democracy Journal for corrective levies like a carbon tax, scrapping the preferential treatment of capital gains and equalizing the tax treatment of corporate and pass-through income. "Together, these changes would deliver broad-based increases in Americans' quality of life," they wrote.

-- The American Accounting Association is out with a new paper maintaining that the 2004 law that gave multinational corporations a low tax rate for offshore income -- which is not remembered fondly by some tax analysts -- wasn't all that bad. Critics of that measure say it led largely to stock buybacks, and the domestic investment promised by companies never materialized -- a dynamic they expect might also play out with the new tax law. But the accounting association argues that while there was certainly stock buybacks after the 2004 law, "repatriation resulted in an increase of R&D of about $30 billion, or about 11 percent of the total of $268 billion brought home by the large sample of nearly 400 companies included in the study."

INTERNATIONAL UPDATE

YOU, TOO? Finance Minister Bill Morneau of Canada is now openly musing about whether Ottawa needs new methods to tax Silicon Valley powers, Bloomberg reports. The European Union is expected as soon as today to roll out a new tax on the revenues of companies like Apple, Facebook and Google that would also cut down on the benefits of setting up in low-tax countries on the continent, leading Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and top GOP tax writers to accuse the EU of singling out American corporations. "We are looking at it carefully because we need to understand what if anything happens to our tax base based on a changing of the economy towards a different business model," Morneau said at a meeting of Group of 20 finance ministers in Buenos Aires. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has previously brushed aside the idea of taxing Netflix.

NOT PLAYING AROUND: Zambia has sent a nearly $8 billion tax bill to First Quantum Minerals -- an amount that's almost 85 percent of the mining company's revenues. The company said it "unequivocally refutes this assessment which does not appear to have any discernible basis of calculation," but it's also not the first time the two sides have clashed. "Last year Zambia cut power to mines, including the Kansanshi pit owned by First Quantum, and two operations held by Glencore, after a fight escalated over tariffs," Bloomberg reports.

STATE NEWS

OUT OF HERE: The Wisconsin Senate wrapped up a two-year session by finishing off one of Gov. Scott Walker's priorities, The Associated Press reports -- a $100 per child tax rebate. "The Senate agreed with the Assembly on the $100 child tax rebate but scaled back provisions that would establish a sales tax holiday, making more items subject to the tax than the Assembly did to save $38 million in revenue. Under the Senate version of the bill, sales tax would be waived on clothing costing less than $75, a computer costing less than $750, computer supplies costing less than $250 and school supplies costing no more than $75."

Zambia and Congo have more than half the world's reserves of cobalt.

** A message from the Intuit Tax and Financial Center: This tax season, government and industry are engaged in a system-wide collaborative known as the Information Sharing and Analysis Center or "ISAC. The ISAC's mission, is to combat tax cyberfraud by securely sharing information via a public/private partnership, harnessing the expertise of Federal and State tax authorities and the private sector tax services industry to work together to protect the American tax system from cybersecurity threats, leveraging applied data science and analysis to defeat strategic threats. Within the program's first year, ISAC helped reduce tax identity theft by 40% and protected an estimated $6 billion of refunds from fraud. Learn more about the effort at http://bit.ly/2G5x7zz **

results.title: Interior's 'bellwether' lease sale today
results.body:
'BELLWETHER' LEASE SALE TODAY: Interior will hold its region-wide lease sale today for all available parcels in federal waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Secretary Ryan Zinke said today's sale -- which Interior has touted as "the largest in U.S. history" -- would serve as "a bellwether" on where oil and gas companies want to spend their money drilling. The auction will offer up 14,776 blocks across about 77 million acres.

Priming the pump: National Oceans Industry Association President Randall Luthi reminded offshore oil and gas explorers of today's big sale. "The good news is that as commodity prices and market conditions have slowly improved, the Trump administration has worked to safely reduce regulatory burden and also incentivize industry investment by offering a 12.5 percent royalty rate for shallow water leases," Luthi said in a press release. But other observers were already downplaying expectations -- particularly since it doesn't include any of the new areas Zinke is considering opening up, S&P Global reports. "Industry's views on the tracts available [today] do not necessarily say much, if anything, about industry's interest in [the eastern Gulf of Mexico] or Atlantic one to six years from now," Christopher Guith, of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce's Global Energy Institute, told S&P.

Keep in mind: Last summer's auction to oil and gas companies raised far less money than officials initially anticipated, Pro's Ben Lefebvre reported. That underperformance may illustrate how DOI's plan to cut royalty rates isn't necessarily the solution needed to stem the long-term decline in oil and gas companies buying up the Gulf of Mexico. BOEM plans to announce the results today during an 11:30 a.m. conference call.

WELCOME TO WEDNESDAY! I'm your host Kelsey Tamborrino, and Andeavor's Stephen Brown was first to identify Tonie Nathan as the first Jewish politician to win an electoral vote in a presidential election. Nathan ran on the Libertarian ticket in 1972. For today: Since the 1974 Congressional Budget Act laid out the standard appropriations process, how many times has Congress passed all its required appropriations measures on time? Bonus points if you can name the fiscal years. Send your tips, energy gossip and comments to ktamborrino@politico.com, or follow us on Twitter @kelseytam, @Morning_Energy and @POLITICOPro.

POLITICO Space is our new, free weekly briefing on the policies and personalities shaping the second space age in Washington and beyond. Sign up today to start receiving the newsletter right at launch on April 6. Presented by Boeing.

PRUITT RACKS UP PRICEY FLIGHTS: In his first year on the job, EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt spent more than $105,000 on previously undisclosed first-class flights. That figure comes from records EPA turned over to House Oversight Chairman Trey Gowdy on Tuesday, but does not include an additional $58,000 on charter flights and a military plane. The most expensive trip listed in the new documents? A $16,217 trip in December to Morocco where Pruitt touted American natural gas exports, POLITICO's Emily Holden, Anthony Adragna and Alex Guill√©n report.

New questions on security: Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse sent a letter to EPA's inspector general asking the office to look into Pruitt's 24/7 security detail, including the administrator's use of it on non-official business such as jaunts to Disneyland, the Rose Bowl and college basketball games. "The request presents new questions concerning Administrator Pruitt's travel outside Washington, including about the aggregate cost to taxpayers, comparisons of costs incurred under previous administrators, and the cost and burden to the agency of reassigning personnel to accommodate the Administrator's travel," a spokesman said. Whitehouse's office, which declined to release the letter due to sensitive security information included in the document, said it obtained documents showing multiple agents accompanied Pruitt to those destinations unrelated to his official duties.

WE'LL KEEP THE LIGHTS ON: Batten down the hatches, folks! Between incoming snowfall and a quickly approaching funding deadline, omnibus negotiations are navigating quite the storm. Congressional leaders failed to release the $1.3 trillion fiscal 2018 omnibus text before midnight, as they'd hoped. And it's looking grim for the bill that last week negotiators said was almost complete. Talks between Capitol Hill and the White House have moved slowly, Pro's Sarah Ferris and Kaitlyn Burton report, with several issues still on the table after administration officials participated in a lengthy meeting Tuesday afternoon with appropriations leadership.

"Everything that remains is going to be pulling teeth to resolve," said a senior congressional aide with knowledge of the meeting. In all, four of the 12 subcommittees have yet to close out their bills, according to a Democratic appropriations aide, including Interior-Environment. The House is aiming to vote on the bill Thursday, though timing could be affected by the snowstorm expected to hit Washington today. Read more.

More trouble on the horizon: Count House appropriators among those decidedly not on board with using the omnibus to advance a controversial Mississippi flood control project long-sought by outgoing Senate Appropriations Chairman Thad Cochran. "The problem is adding things that would be looked at by the House as an earmark," Rep. Mike Simpson told reporters. "We can't do that." But Simpson added he wasn't directly aware of the provision nor whether leadership planned to include language related to the Waters of the U.S. regulation.

Simpson's got plans: Though he predicted Congress would need into the weekend to clear the spending bill, Simpson said he'd be home one way or the other for knee replacement surgery ... and he's got big plans. "I'm thinking I'm going to take it out to Walter Reed and put it with Sickles' leg," he said. "We're going to go out and do a toast to Sickles' leg."

** A message from Chevron: Chevron and local partners are helping to provide DOERS with the hands-on technical training needed for today's jobs in the manufacturing and energy industries. Watch the video: http://politi.co/2HBMVHd **

IF AT FIRST TRUMP DOESN'T SUCCEED: Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue suggested Tuesday it might be time Congress takes a whack at resolving the ongoing dispute over the price of biofuel credits. "I think the White House is trying to determine whether they need to make a call on a decision or allow Congress to go back and fix it," Perdue told reporters at the National Press Club. "We've had some members of Congress call and say, 'We've been working on this -- let us have it.'" President Donald Trump has been a part of four meetings to remedy the dispute between the ethanol industry and some oil interests, to no concrete avail.

What would a bill look like? Sen. John Cornyn and Rep. John Shimkus have some ideas. The two have been working on a bill for well over a year to overhaul the Renewable Fuel Standard, a likely vehicle for the fixes Perdue referenced, Pro's Helena Bottemiller Evich and Eric Wolff report. But the text of the Cornyn-Shimkus bill has been kept under wraps. "Interest group representatives who have seen parts of it remain mum, though it is rumored to include a national octane standard, and possibly a new kind of RIN for sales of high ethanol blends of gasoline," Helena and Eric write. A spokesman for Shimkus said the lawmaker has "contacted staff and officials at the White House, USDA, and EPA to say that any administrative changes to the RFS at this time would be counterproductive to legislative efforts to reform the program."

(SOON) GOOD TO GO: Energy Secretary Rick Perry's suspension of uranium transfers for the remainder of the fiscal year has left Sen. John Barrasso on the verge of lifting his hold on Anne White's selection to be assistant secretary for environmental management provided he gets some additional assurances from DOE. "I appreciate very much what he said," Barrasso told ME. "We're trying to wrap some things up with the department to make sure they follow through with that."

WON'T GO AT IT ALONE: EPW ranking member Tom Carper told reporters he's working with the administration on an agreement that might speed floor consideration of EPA deputy nominee Andrew Wheeler, but said some within his own caucus won't ever consent to letting Wheeler through by unanimous consent. "[It's] really hard to ever see that one going by UC," he conceded. Remember lower-level nominees may be stuck in confirmation limbo indefinitely amid a push on federal judge confirmations and Cabinet vacancies.

THIS IS NOTABLE: Rep. Jim Bridenstine's nomination for NASA remains stalled in the Senate where it lacks the votes needed to move forward. But 12 House Democrats joined Republicans Tuesday to take matters into their own hands and urge Senate leadership to hold a vote on Bridenstine. Read their letter here.

NOT GIVING UP: Retiring Rep. Joe Barton isn't giving up on his push to complete a DOE reauthorization bill this year and plans to develop draft legislation within the next month. The Texas Republicans tells ME he'll soon sit down with Perry, DOE officials and Energy and Commerce Democrats for a meeting on the effort. Chairman Greg Walden first tasked Barton with leading a "comprehensive review" of the agency back in February 2017.

COLD CRACKS: PHMSA will hold its hearing today into the damage at two of Cheniere's LNG storage tanks in Sabine Pass, Texas, that resulted in a leak of about 40 cubic meters of gas. PHMSA opened an investigation into how the cracks developed in the two tanks, an incident Cheniere reported in late January. Cheniere has sought an informal settlement with PHMSA, saying that the government's corrective damage order detailing the damage contained "factual errors and unsubstantiated statements and misleading statements." Meanwhile, FERC told Cheniere last month to keep the two tanks out of service until more is learned about the situation.

NO WORRIES: PJM Interconnection gave the OK Tuesday for FirstEnergy to retire a 1,278 MW coal-fired power plant in West Virginia, saying the shutdown wouldn't hurt the power network's reliability, Eric reports. The plant in question is supplied by Murray Energy, whose CEO Bob Murray had pressed DOE to avert a closure of the plant. But in an analysis report not made public, a PJM spokesman said the operator did not identify any impacts to the grid from the closure of the two generating units at Pleasants Power Station. Read more.

FERC GRANTS EXTENSION FOR COMMENTS: FERC granted a 30-day extension on Tuesday for public comments on its regional grid resilience proceedings. At the commission's meeting last week, Chairman Kevin McIntyre said interested parties shouldn't limit themselves to responding to RTO comments. They should feel free to comment on any part of the proceeding.

WHAT HAPPENED IN PUERTO RICO? Six months after Hurricane Maria struck Puerto Rico, information about the botched federal response is still trickling out. After pleas for emergency fuel by Walmart and other supermarkets went unreturned by FEMA in the aftermath of the hurricane, retailers were forced to throw out tons of food, POLITICO's Lorraine Woellert reports. Congressional investigators Tuesday released emails from the supermarkets, which were sent to members of Congress for help gathering FEMA's attention. In a letter to Gowdy, Democrats request a subpoena to force DHS to provide documents related to FEMA's disaster response.

But that's not all: Ranking members from various House committees called on FEMA Administrator Brock Long to address concerns they have with his agency's response. Separately, a group of 13 senators sent a letter to the Army Corps of Engineers about the drawdown of personnel in the territory while power has yet to be fully restored.

MAIL CALL! FILL US IN: Walden, Shimkus and Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee Chairman Gregg Harper sent a letter to EPA, requesting further details on the agency's reorganization plans. Read it here.

GREENS CHEER: A federal district court in Alaska gave the go-ahead this week for a case to move forward related to the seismic impact of offshore drilling in the Arctic and Atlantic oceans. The case, League of Conservation Voters vs. Trump, is the first legal challenge from the LCV, though it was joined by other greens, including the Natural Resources Defense Council and Sierra Club. Read the opinion here.

SWAMP THINGS: The editorial board of the conservative Weekly Standard offered harsh words for the overspending tendencies of Trump's Cabinet on Tuesday, including Zinke and Pruitt. "Trump is frustrated, our sources tell us, by these micro-controversies and what they say about his administration. He's thinking seriously about making examples of those who've been poor stewards of taxpayer money," the board writes. "Good for him." Read it here.

QUICK HITS

-- Complaints about falsified pipeline endorsements draw no response, The Wall Street Journal.

-- National Park Service warned lease sale Tuesday could harm national monument in Utah, The Washington Post.

-- Drillers snap up federal leases near Utah's wilderness monuments, Reuters.

** A message from Chevron: See how Chevron with local partners are helping DOERS get the hands-on technical training needed for jobs in the energy and manufacturing industries. Watch the video: http://politi.co/2peUrjJ **

results.title: Watching the omnibus bill
results.body:
THE WHEELS ON THE OMNIBUS TURN 'ROUND AND 'ROUND: Omnibus watch took up another evening for the capital's reporters and wonks, as Congress failed to nail down a final product: a mammoth, trillion-dollar-plus spending bill meant to keep the machinery of government churning just ahead of the deadline.

APPLE EHR INITIATIVE TO EXPAND API USE?: The consumer tech giant's recent entry into electronic health record display could prompt EHR vendors to invest more in application programming interfaces, especially if they want to get other commercial tech companies to integrate their records into apps.

It's been fewer than two months since Apple announced its pilot with a handful of vendors, allowing patients at certain provider sites to download their EHRs directly through the iPhone Health app instead of using a provider portal. But it's not clear yet how the partnership is going -- vendors and providers have generally been reluctant to share details about user numbers during the beta phase.

For Cerner, the partnership is going well enough to expand the number of participating provider sites from four to nine, company vice president John Gresham told POLITICO.

The partnership could also lead to new integrations. Jonathan Bush, CEO of athenahealth, told POLITICO the company is working "really hard" to convince Apple to come up with an appointment calendar interface in addition to the EHR download. Bush pointed to services like Kayak and OpenTable as good consumer-facing apps to emulate.

Pros can get the rest here.

ADMINISTRATION EXPECTED TO ANNOUNCE NEW CDC CHIEF TODAY: Robert Redfield, the Baltimore-based AIDS researcher, is the Trump administration's choice. POLITICO on Friday scooped that Redfield was favored for the role. The public health agency has been without a permanent leader since Brenda Fitzgerald stepped down almost two months ago following mounting questions about financial conflicts.

eHealth tweet of the day: Jenny Gold @JennyAGold "5 phone calls later, I still haven't been able to get my medical records transferred from one practice to another. IN THE SAME HEALTH SYSTEM. $%$$ing #healthcare."

TUNE IN: Join POLITICO online this morning for a conversation on how to provide high-quality care at lower costs to a growing population of aging Americans. Tune in to Avoiding 911 -- How to Improve Health Care in Nursing Homes and Bend the Cost Curve -- March 21 at 8:00 a.m. Watch live here.

WEDNESDAY: Your correspondent can't resist a cheap joke, which is why he's really tingling with anticipation for the usual comedy of errors whenever D.C. faces even the lightest dusting of snow. Whether it's people forgetting to remove snow and ice from their sidewalks, or oddly terrified and passive drivers, your correspondent is constantly amused by the shell-shocked reaction of the entire city. Share your terror of snow at dtahir@politico.com. Discuss winter wonderlands (in spring!) socially at @ravindranize, @arthurallen202, @dariustahir, @POLITICOPro, @Morning_eHealth.

VA QUESTIONS DEEPEN: The various questions surrounding the Department of Veterans Affairs continued to swirl Tuesday:

-- Minnesota Democrat follows up on POLITICO reporting: Sen. Tina Smith wants to know more about the VA's pending contract and implementation of its Cerner EHR after POLITICO raised questions about the first phase of the software rollout at some of the Department of Defense's Pacific Northwest facilities. In a letter to VA Secretary David Shulkin, Smith asks for more information on budget and personnel devoted to the plan, and more detail about VA providers' ability to get data from both VistA and Cerner's EHR.

-- Meanwhile... A bill further overhauling the VA's health delivery system is on hold, the Washington Post reports, due to objections from Nancy Pelosi's office. Pelosi apparently believes the bill, the Caring for Our Veterans Act (S. 2193 (115)), would outsource too much care to the private sector, among other objections.

There's a micro and macro view to the bill here, of course. From a micro perspective, the bill would legislatively secure VA providers' right to provide telemedicine across state lines, which the Trump administration had already worked to resolve administratively. It would also require the VA to report to Congress on the effectiveness of telemedicine in its system.

More broadly, the bill adds to the wider drama surrounding the department. Shulkin's job security has been under question for weeks, amid some conservative frustration that he has been slow to adopt their their preferred policies. (Among their other department priorities: expanding privately furnished care.)

HITAC TODAY: If you're cold or dreading being outside amid the flurries, perhaps today's virtual meeting of the Health IT Advisory Committee will tide you over. The committee is scheduled to consider Trusted Exchange Framework draft recommendations from the relevant task force. You can read the draft here. The task force wants clear goals with non-duplicative requirements, among several suggestions.

AHIMA MEMBERS TOOK THE HILL: The American Health Information Management Association's members took to the Hill on Tuesday to advocate for two bills -- the Overdose Prevention and Patient Safety Act (H.R. 3545 (115)) and Protecting Jessica Grubb's Legacy Act (S. 1850 (115)) -- intended to change privacy laws governing substance use data.

"We are facing one of the nation's deadliest substance abuse epidemics, and it's time for the laws put into place decades ago to reflect the needs of the industry today," said Pamela Lane, the association's vice president of government relations.

SENATORS WRITE LETTERS: Sens. Sheldon Whitehouse and Bill Cassidy really want Alex Azar to push fee-for-value payment models, having written a letter to the HHS secretary on the issue. They warn that if HHS slackens, the private sector will pull back accordingly.

PDMP IN THE STATES: A couple of PDMP bills in the states to track:

-- Florida Gov. Rick Scott signed House Bill 21 earlier this week. The bill, intended to offer a battery of responses to the opioid crisis, contains some relevant provisions to the state's prescription drug monitoring program. It allows VA and Indian Health Service providers to access the PDMP and allows the state to share data, but it also requires the system purge data that's more than four years old, among other adjustments. It marks a notable transformation for Scott, who came into office trying to scale back the program.

-- Colorado may join the trend of states requiring prescribers to query the PDMP, as a new opioids bill was introduced earlier in the session. The legislation also requires the PDMP to allow direct access from an EHR.

TANGENT TIME: In a report examining potential overpayments to hospitals accounting for $4.4 million, HHS's Office for the Inspector General returns to a familiar hobbyhorse: the need for unique device identifiers.

The report examined hundreds of claims concerning recalled cardiac medical devices, and concluded that hospitals should've properly reported receipt of rebates for some of these devices, with potential overpayments flowing from them.

Of course, OIG has an idea for helping with these problems: putting unique device identifiers in claims forms, which would allow CMS to more closely track such devices. Trump's CMS has not stated a definitive position on the matter.

results.title: Congressional leaders on verge of massive spending deal
results.body:
Congressional leaders are nearing agreement on a massive $1.3 trillion spending bill to fund the government through September, staving off a shutdown if both chambers can act by Friday night.

Most major issues, including funding for a massive New York transportation project and the border wall have been resolved. But negotiators are still haggling over a plan to fix a snafu in the GOP's tax law -- the so-called "grain glitch" -- that ag state lawmakers are seeking.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) is opposed to the latest proposed "grain glitch" fix, delaying the announcement of a final deal, according to two sources. But a Democratic aide disputes that the grain glitch standoff is the only thing holding up a deal, saying multiple issues, including provisions related to guns, are still in question.

The Big Four -- Pelosi, Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) -- will meet later Wednesday morning to hash out the final details with text expected to be posted at noon.

Congressional leaders are still hoping to avoid the need for a short-term spending bill to keep the government open for a few days beyond Friday. But if the spending bill is released Wednesday as planned, the House will likely vote on the measure Thursday, giving the Senate just one day to clear the deal before funding expires.

Under this timetable, any single senator could cause a brief government shutdown under Senate rules and push work into the weekend. Kentucky GOP Sen. Rand Paul has pointedly refused to rule out doing so.

The bill provides nearly $1.6 billion for border security, but does not include any money for an increase in detention beds or federal deportation agents, a key priority for Democrats in the talks.

The deal provides $641 million for new fencing, including levees, but does not allocate money for a concrete wall, according to a source familiar with the agreement. The proposal also includes nearly $1.3 billion for other border security technologies.

Negotiators also agreed to a compromise of sorts on the Gateway project. President Donald Trump had vowed to veto the must-pass spending bill if it included funding for the $900 million tunnel project, a top priority for Schumer and other New York and New Jersey lawmakers.

The bill doesn't provide the specific funding for the project but does include funding increases for other federal transportation accounts, including Amtrak, that will allow tunnel construction to begin. And there will be more than $500 million available for Gateway this year that doesn't require administration approval under the terms of the deal, and the project can apply for billions more, according to a source familiar with the negotiations.

Pelosi is holding up an agreement on one of the final sticking points, according to two sources familiar with the issue: a deal to fix a glitch in the GOP's tax law in exchange for a temporary boost in the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit.

One of the sources said Pelosi is blocking an agreement between Ryan, McConnell and Schumer because of concerns about her own growers in California -- even as some Democrats from agriculture states join Republicans in their desire to fix the problem.

The so-called "grain glitch" lowers the tax bills of farmers that sell grain to cooperatives but at the expense of other farmers. Democrats at one point had sworn off allowing Republicans to iron out problems in their partisan tax bill passed last December. But many vulnerable swing-state and swing-district Democrats also want the relief for their own agriculture sectors back home.

Pelosi's opposition comes just a day after Ryan also rejected a separate deal on the matter that had the backing of Pelosi, Schumer and McConnell. Democrats sought an expansion of the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit that Senate Republicans were ready to grant, but Ryan vetoed the proposal. Since then, a source familiar said Ryan, McConnell and Schumer have agreed to an increase in the annual housing credit for the poor for four years as well as some changes to income averaging rules.

House Democrats are worried that the language as drafted doesn't protect small farmers or specialty crop co-ops, according to a senior aide. Pelosi and Rep. Collin Peterson (D-Minn.), ranking member on the House Agriculture Committee, both oppose the current language.

In the end, congressional leaders ended up abandoning negotiations on many of the most controversial provisions lawmakers were trying to include in the must-pass bill -- likely the last major piece of legislation to reach Trump's desk before the midterms.

There is no agreement to protect so-called Dreamers, as Democrats had initially sought, or cuts to funding for sanctuary cities, as Republicans had wanted.

Lawmakers also gave up on efforts to stabilize Obamacare markets through subsidies known as cost-sharing reduction payments after both sides failed to settle a dispute over restrictions on abortion.

The deal does not include a provision to protect special counsel Robert Mueller if he's fired by Trump -- as Schumer and Pelosi had wanted -- but it does provide for an increase in funding to fight Russian hacking ahead of the November elections.

The proposal includes an increase in the FBI's budget to combat Russia cyberattacks this year and provides an additional $380 million for technology grants that will allow states to secure election systems.

results.title: FBI Director Wray on McCabe's firing: 'I am committed to doing things objectively and independently'
results.body:
FBI Director Christopher Wray said this week that he is "utterly unyielding" in his commitment to running the bureau free from political influence, suggesting in an interview with NBC news that the firing of former Deputy FBI Director Andrew McCabe was not politically motivated.

"I am committed to doing things objectively and independently and by the book," Wray told NBC News when asked about McCabe's firing. "I think that has to extend not just to our investigations, our intelligence analysis, but it also has to extend to personnel decisions and disciplinary decisions."

McCabe was fired late Friday night, a decision Attorney General Jeff Sessions said he made based on a yet-to-be-released report from the Justice Department's internal watchdog that found McCabe had leaked information to the media without authorization "lacked candor" in interviews with investigators. His firing came one day before he was set to officially leave the FBI, likely denying him access to the pension benefits he would have received had he been allowed to retire as scheduled on Sunday.

McCabe, in a length statement issued after his firing, said his dismissal amounted to an effort by the administration of President Donald Trump to discredit him. McCabe said he was "being singled out and treated this way because of the role I played, the actions I took, and the events I witnessed in the aftermath of the firing of James Comey."

Trump, who took to Twitter to celebrate McCabe's firing in the hours after it was announced, has been a longtime critic of the former deputy director. The president has suggested online that he believed McCabe was biased against him because his wife's campaign for a seat in Virginia's state legislature accepted money from a super PAC controlled by former Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, a close ally of Hillary Clinton's.

Despite the president's clear distaste for McCabe, Wray told NBC that he does not feel any political pressure from the White House and that the president has never asked him to do anything in relation to the Russia investigation of special counsel Robert Mueller. Wray refused to specifically address reports from earlier this year that he had threatened to resign under pressure to fire people at the bureau, although he did not deny those reports.

"I want to be careful about what I can say about the process," Wray said of McCabe's firing. "But I will tell you that my commitment to making sure that our process is followed, that it relies on objective input and that most importantly, it is not based on political or partisan influence, is something I am utterly unyielding on."

THE BUZZ: WHERE'S ZUCK? Hard to imagine that just a few months back, the political cognoscenti were electric with buzz that Palo Alto-based Facebook boasted not one, but two brilliant young tech gurus who appeared to testing messaging -- and the political waters -- for a 2020 White House challenge to that old school business model, Donald Trump.

-- THE IDEA WAS FUELED by the optics: the hip, hoody-wearing CEO Mark Zuckerberg was off on a national "listening tour," driving to places like Nebraska to hear from "real people", while also hiring veteran political consultants with D.C. cred. And the Queen of "Lean In,'' COO Sheryl Sandberg, was knocking them dead on a book tour.

But that was then, and this is the week of Cambridge Analytica.

-- STATUS CHANGE: With the company's image blowing up around him, the company's stock price barrelling downward -- a $52 billion hit since the story broke last Friday -- and the chief security officer Alex Stamos on the way out the door, Zuckerberg has apparently gone into the (tech) witness protection program. He didn't even show at the company's "All Hands" meeting at Facebook HQ yesterday (a session of 30 minutes? That's not even enough time to check out the legendary Facebook snackbar.) And meanwhile, the heat is on... .

-- "For now, the company is sending lower-level staffers to brief a half-dozen congressional committees about how data on more than 50 million users ended up in the hands of Cambridge during the 2016 campaign. But Facebook's Washington, D.C., troubles show no signs of abating amid news that the FTC has opened a data-privacy investigation into the company and its stock price takes yet another hit." Story.

Story.
